review_body: We were delighted by this beautiful hotel. It was, we thought, a luxurious and special place. We stayed eight nights in total, before and after a railway trip out of Tokyo. The public areas were spacious, elegant and distinctively decorated; our favourite was the superb Momiji Lounge with its views of the hotel's impressive garden. Breakfast in the Momiji was always a treat. The Japanese restaurant and the Club Lounge were also beautiful places. Our two rooms were less distinctive, but they could not be faulted: attractive, comfortable, convenient and wonderfully warm during a period of chilly, rainy weather. All the staff with whom we had contact, without exception, were excellent: so courteous and helpful. We were especially appreciative of the porters and bell staff -- they went out of their way to help -- and the perfect housekeeping service. The hotel's location was superb, close to Shinagawa Station, and there was a frequent shuttle service up the hill to the hotel. We would love to stay here again -- it really was a memorable stay.

Big expansive hotel. Luxurious too. The hotel was very comfortable with more than a few lovely restaurants to choose from. The tour arrangement available at the hotel was a good part of my stay. For an expensive city, the hotel came at a good price.

We stayed at this hotel for four nights in total. The first room they put us in was small, and needed to be renovated. We asked for an upgrade for the next two nights, which was given to us at the price of 2000 yen per night, which was reasonable. The upgraded rooms, while better than the first one, needed refurbishment and some cleaning. The carpets in the hallways leading to the rooms definitely need replacement. We stayed on the 3rd, 8th, and 9th floors. This is a consistent need in the corridors. The breakfast buffet is very good. Nice selection of choices, both western and Japanese. The coffee was excellent. The staff in the restaurant were accommodating and pleasant.When we checked out for the second time (we stayed two different times), the hotel staff charged us for a late check out (9000 yen), even though we had an itinerary that stated we had paid for a ‘guaranteed late checkout’. This was something we debated with the check in staff person and the manager, and we believed it was all taken care of. Upon check out, however, they charged us the 9000 yen. Had we known that, we would have checked out on time, and left our luggage with the bell desk. It seemed like a ‘bait and switch’ to us.The location of the hotel is very convenient to the Shinagawa station. There are several other hotels in the near vicinity. If we go back to Tokyo, we will look at other options to the Grand Prince shin Takanawa.

I only stayed the one night (as I was going on a 14 night Cruise) the hotel was Very clean the Staff were very helpful. My room had a small balcony from which I could see Mt fugi in the distance.You have a choice of restaurants to have your meals in I choice the Japan one for my first taste of what Japan had to offer.When I go again in will stop in the same hotel

We picked this hotel because it’s walking distance to Shinagawa station which is convenient for getting to Haneda airport and taking the Shinkansen train. We had two separate stays in a week - before and after our trip to Kyoto. The first time our room was on the 12th floor, good view and renovated and we were very happy with it. The second time we were on the 3rd floor and the room was considerably more dated and configuration was odd - no drawers, closet didn’t have doors. But otherwise room was spotless, beds comfortable. Bathroom had big tub, good water pressure and scented bath salts, hair brush, shower scrub towel, razor, toothbrush and toiletries provided. No body lotion. Room had thermal water kettle, tea bags and instant coffee, complimentary water bottles. We booked with the breakfast buffet which was pricey but excellent for both western and Japanese options. There’s a 7-11 downstairs which is very convenient. The hotel was fairly empty when we stayed no doubt because of the coronavirus and all the staff had masks. Not sure how crowded it gets normally. Overall would stay again but try to get a renovated room.

The room is spacious, I love this hotel, clean, cozy, so traditional and so calm. The staffs are friendly, helpful and they can speak english well. They have a shuttle every 15-20 minutes to take you to the station. They also have an airport bus limousine so it's easy for you to go to the airport. Make sure you have a reservation for the bus. the schedule is for every 1 hour. I like the garden at the back of the hotel, it's like a japanese garden and so beautiful and relaxing. Really love this hotel.
My room was lovely, the bed was so comfortable.The breakfast in the morning was delicious and there was a good variety available for all tastes.Reception area and the gardens outside were beautiful.

Clean rooms. Ok for the price. The hotel is accessible by the Keisei access Express via Shinagawa station. Be aware that the hotel is bout a 10 min walk uphill from Shinagawa station. So you hv to be relatively mobile to take the train w luggage

It is a super clean hotel with dedicated friendly staff. Anyway, this hotel is really big.The room was fine and everything worked out pretty well! I liked the entrance of the hotel very much and the small garden.

I stayed here as all my preferred hotels in Tokyo were booked due to the Rugby worldcup in Nov. I paid twice what I would pay for services that were otherwise standard or sub-standard. The lounge sucks. The Westin and Sheraton Miyako have far better exec lounges and service. This wouldn't be my first choice for a hotel in Tokyo. Also note I stayed here for a night only because all other hotels were fully booked.

This hotel is located within a group of hotels and sits on some gorgeously manicured grounds, which I highly recommend you explore if you have time (~30 minutes).The hotel is somewhat close to a train stop but it's up a slight hill - this is not the end of the world, but is not ideal, either. There are a multitude of restaurants and shops in the immediate area which do appear to be catering to tourists (which is fine).The hotel has a huge lobby which is nicely decorated, and a rather intimidating check-in area devoid of any warmth or personality. The check-in desk is placed smack in the middle of the room and makes the whole process seem a little too "formal". Checkin was nice, but absolutely robotic. In the event that you would like to stay a minute past checkout, you will be politely informed that that is not offered without a fee.The room itself was decent but quite underwhelming - I stayed on a high floor (Superior King Room, Non Smoking) with a decent view, but the room was absolutely stifling hot. I had to leave my window open in order to get it to any degree of being even slightly cool, as the hotel (as lots of larger hotels do) can only cool OR heat the building at one time, and the hotel had already been set to "heat" mode. This was a bit frustrating and disappointing.The room had an acceptable layout but the bathroom felt very, very dated and slightly cramped. My particular configuration was a shower-over-tub and did not mirror the experience that I had in the rest of my hotels in Japan (which tended to be a tub, adjacent to a shower stall). There was a small balcony attached to the room, which was essentially useless (size wise) but does provide a cute aesthetic.All said and done I would stay in this hotel again in a pinch, but I think the prices are a bit high for the accommodation that you are receiving. The service from the staff was impeccable, but as mentioned, slightly robotic.

Superlatives leave me when I attempt to review this marvelous LARGE hotel. Absolutely everything works and works WELL. There at least 5 restaurants to choose from within the hotel and lots of others a few minutes walk away. The Momiji Lounge offers a Daily Guests Special evening dinner which is excellent and good value.Shinagawa railway station is only a 5 min walk away, providing easy access to downtown Tokyo. Six very efficient LIFTS service the accommodation tower.

We’re told to expect small rooms in hotels in Tokyo....well ours was just as big as any North American rooms. The hotel (hotels) on this property are gigantic. The staff are super friendly and attentive. From check in to the bellman to the courtesy shuttle, I’d recommend this hotel. Breakfast in the Slopeside restaurant was great each day. Super close to the Shinagawa train station and lots of eateries.

A very large hotel complex that is a easy 10 minutes slightly uphill walk from Shinagawa train station. Rooms are a good size, clean and well appointed.The buffet is excellent quality and there is a 7 Eleven in the basement for stocking up on snacks.The only down side I could find was that the gym is tiny for a complex of this size. No weights whatsoever just a swiss ball, two bikes and two treadmills.

We stayed here as part of a group tour and were out and about so didn’t get much chance to try any facilities. There are a number of food choices that did include some more western style dishes. Service was excellent Staff were friendly welcoming and had reasonable English. The room was the largest of our whole trip and had the most comfortable bed as well. Hot water in the room for tea making but I suggest you bring your own teabags if you like breakfast tea. The reception lounge area is very noisy as it’s always busy so it’s difficult to find a quiet place to just sit. Good location

We stayed here for 3 nights as part of a group tour. We found this hotel to be huge compared to others on our trip, very luxurious reception area, large bedroom with a nice little balcony overlooking the gardens. Bathroom was good size with plenty of hot water, although the towels could have been fluffier.Location was fine being a short walk from the station but we found there wasn't much to walk around on an evening re shopping (it was very high end). Breakfast was lovely with lots to choose from and of a good quality.We enjoyed the experience of being allowed to ring the large garden bell at 4pm too.The 7-11 on the basement floor was also very handy, with reasonably priced beers, snacks and wine.

The hotel is about 600m from the main station, and adjacent to the conference center. Lots of shops nearby for shopping or for meals. Hotel room is big and modern, check in is very fast. Shuttle bus is available at 20 minutes interval. Very convenient place.

I picked this hotel as the normal hotels in Shinagawa (Marriot) were more expensive than normal.Pros: Rooms were quietGood location, easy walk to stationNegatives:Although I'd requested a non-smoking room, I was given a smoking room - smell was intolerable the first night - I asked to move and nothing available - no follow up from hotel to check all was okRoom is very hot - air con inefficient - thankfully balcony opened and cool air obtainedHotel is very sterile - no personal service Would I stay here again - only if better local hotels were much too expensive!

Hotel is close to Shinagawa station, easy walk to get there. It was our first time to Japan and we don't speak the language. Hotel staff were nice and even checked in with us to make sure everything was going well. Room was very nice, quiet and comfortable. 7-11 located in the building was very convenient. Overall great experience, would definitely stay here again.

This is the most comfortable hotel in Shinagawa. The room is large and the breakfast is great. At night, there is a live performance in the lounge, and you can feel unusual. It is convenient to be near the Shinagawa station.品川エリアでは最も快適に過ごせるホテルと思います。朝食はラウンジでいただきましたが、パンがとても美味しかったです。リーズナブルですし、また利用したいと思います。夜には生演奏が行われていて、とても素敵でした。

Room are very clean.Prompt Housekeeping service.Location good. And hotel provide fegular transport to Shingawa station.The station is accessible to May major station.If not to keen to go too far the station has many. story of meals western to local delights.And at the station there is a big supermarket.Staff were warmth and friendly.Makes their guest feel at home.

A hotel that mixes a past vision of what a grand Japanese interpretation of a western style hotel. With a maze-like matrix of buildings and staircases which are found in most older Japanese hotels. Beautiful grand lobby. Rooms are a bit dated in style but were very clean and in nice shape and of western proportions. Bathrooms were also dated but very clean. I did have an issue with my mattress. It had divots where clearly most patrons slept. I requested they flip the mattress but that found just turned up another divot. Most hotels have a cycle for new mattresses which I hope is soon for the room or floor or whatever order they perform such updates. The service was top-notch as were the restaurants albeit on the hotel expensive side. The VIP lounge was also a strange long shape but very nicely appointed. Having a balcony in this day and age of airtight rooms was also a very nice plus for someone who loves outdoor space. The pricing was actually quite bargain by Tokyo standards. I would recommend this hotel highly IF it replaced the mattresses.

Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is conveniently located 7 minutes walk from Shinagawa Station. The access to Shinagawa Station is lined with retail shops and restaurants.The hotel is modern, artful, and elegantly decoeated. The highlights of the hotel facilities are the restaurants and the Japanese Garden.Room is super clean, very comfortable and very roomy for Japanese standard. No noise is audible as it is facing to the garden.Breakfast buffet offers a wide varieties of high quality Japanese and Western food.Staff are very helpful and friendly as most of Japanese hospitality workers are.There's.a frequent shuttle service to Shinagawa station.The hotel is highly recommended for business.

Nice hotel with great location close to Shinagawa station. However service is slow and staff training and English proficiency is poor ! I have stayed 4 nights and experienced it several times.Rooms are confortable and clean.Fitness room well not really with only 4 pieces of equipment .Would recommend if you need to be close to Shinagawa otherwise pass plenty of better options.

We stayed here on 2 occasions and found some of the reception staff were not that proficient in solving a request we had and it wasn't until we're sought assistance from a Japanese friend of our that we were finally able to get an answer to our request. Besides that the rooms are average and perhaps showing their age now. The breakfast buffet is quite good but our preference is the sister hotel "Grand Prince Takanawa", which is a1 minute walk through a lovely garden next door.

The hotel is located very near to the Shinagawa Station - close to the metro and the bullet train. It is a huge hotel with big rooms by Japan standards. The rooms are clean and have a small balcony attached. I just had breakfast in the hotel. The breakfast buffet has both Japanese as well as Continental food and is sumptuous. The service is good. The restaurant staff as well as the housekeeping staff is friendly and warm. There is a 7/11 departmental store situated at the B1 level of the hotel which is very helpful. If you opt for green services in the room, the hotel rewards you with a voucher of 500 yen, that you can redeem for any of their services. Overall a comfortable stay.

Check in was the only disappointing aspect of the hotel. The receptionist at the time was very vague and unhelpful and was more worried about taking my credit card details and worrying about an early check in rather than exhausted travellers which we were.Hotel and the amenities were great

The Grand Prince is in a good location close to the station. Rooms were clean and neat with a good view... but, the hotel has an impersonal feel as it is so big and seems more suited for groups or conferences rather than couples.

The Grand Prince is a gorgeous hotel if your planning on a long stay. Rooms are very spacious and extremely clean with a lovely balcony so perfect space to decompress after a day of Tokyo madness. Shinagawa station is a few minutes walk away and connects to the Yamanote line and the Narita express so access to all major parts of Tokyo are easy. Hotel bar downstairs is a must when you arrive or if you need to unwind. Definitely would recommend.

spent the weekend there to enjoy the pool. be sure to book a room with club access, the free drinks and food are well worth it. rooms are good, nothing terribly special, helpful staff and enjoyable gardens.

We stayed here as part of an Aussie-based tour group attending the Rugby World Cup.The rooms were large and very comfortable. Bathroom ensuite was large also with the quirky heated toilet seat plus other attached gadgets.Staff were extremely polite (as one would expect in Japan). Breakfast was included in our tariff but it was truly extensive.Very close to the main railway station (500m) where there are many cheap eateries.

I stay 2 nights for business trip. - large room.- Clean.- Wifi in the room.- 3 styles breakfast as Western buffet, Japanese set and American set.- poor lobby service. They cannot process the receipt. I have to wait for a long time until someone who knows how to do come.- Close to Station but you have to walk up hill.

Some staffs in the lobby are pretty rude. I overheard a guest next to me when I checked in. It was an elderly with hearing disability asking for help for wi-fi, and the staff only wrote down one word, "TV", to the old man without further explanation. C'mon, Prince hotel is not some small local hotel, especially the front desk! At least get someone who can speak more English or show some effort to explain. We would really appreciate that. Later that night, when my wife and I returned from a walk in the neighborhood, she asked the front desk for few bottles of water Prince hotel offers in each room. Front desk shocked us with "turn right, go straight and go to B1, there's a 7-11". Who the hell would answer that to their guest?!?!?!?!?! Let me teach you, Prince hotel, if you don't like to offer that like all other hotels in Japan I've been to, just tell us "I am sorry, but our hotel does not offer extra water. If you would like some water, please visit the 7-11 located at B1 of our hotel. Sorry for any inconvenience. Thank you for your stay"

飯店提供在房內瓶裝水喝完，我們去櫃檯想詢問是否能拿額外的瓶裝水。櫃檯先生竟直接回答「turn right, go straight to b1, there is 7-11」。他可以直接回答「sorry we don’t offer extra bottle water」，我也能接受，但竟然是這麼粗魯的回覆。入住過多家王子飯店，這次的經驗大概是讓人感受最差最糟糕的一次。該集團應該認真思考，加強集團大廳員工的禮儀訓練。也建議大家，若是入住該旅館，大廳人員態度惡劣應該直接反應。

Very big hotel in good position and near Shinagawa station, one of the biggest Tokyo stations, servicing also Shinkansen and Jr Lines . We stayed here just one night, coming back to Tokyo from Kyoto by Shinkansen and we choose it for its useful position. Common areas and main entrance hall are very nice and stylish, but our room, even if very big for the Japanese standards, needs some renovation in furniture a little bit "old fashioned". People at the check in/check out desk are efficient and polite. I only would suggest the property to better explain in their web site where the shuttle bus in Shinagawa station starts from , because we had problems to find it and to focus the correct station exit to reach it, so we gave up and caught a taxi.

We stayed in this hotel for 6 nights and were delighted with the comfort & location. Beautiful room with lovely views. Staff was professional, but appear uninterested. It was my 40th and although my travel agent asked for an acknowledgment, they completely ignored her request. My hubby ordered a ¥11,000 room service breakfast on my bday, and they didn’t offered anything in acknowledgement(perhaps just a coffee, or a cake, small chocolate, a card, or a flower? Nothing). For the price they charge, they could definitely deliver a higher lever of personalisation. They have great facilities, but when we went to the pool we were told that our little 3-year-old - who is toilet trained - was not allowed at the family pool, she would have to go to a tiny plastic pool instead (the water was barely reaching her waist...!). That was disappointing as one of the key reasons why we booked this hotel was because we wanted to use the pool, as it’s very hot in August in Tokyo. We were also charged around ¥3,500 to access this family pool area. Moreover, our little one was not allowed at the nice pool (in a different area), because they don’t allow under 16-year-olds there. Which we didn’t realize when we did the booking. For that reason, I wouldn’t say this hotel is family friendly, as a family friendly venue would allow families in all areas. Overall we had a good time as the location was amazing, the room was incredibly comfortable & spacious. But we were indeed underwhelmed by their restrictions towards families and their poor level of customer service.

We stayed in this hotel 5 nights, with the whole family we booked 4 rooms altogether. My husband had asked beforehand to have all rooms on the same floor and that went well.The check in starts officially at 15:00 but we arrived early, at noon. We tried to check into at least one room earlier than 15:00, but there was no way, the staff really played it by the rule and only after 15:00 all rooms were released. The rooms are clean, practical (with water boiler and tea set) have an empty fridge (which you can stock up yourself with items from the 7-Eleven shop in the hotel) and have a balcony.The hotel is a 5 minute walk to Shinagawa station and if you prefer to take a bus, the hotel offers a shuttle bus service from around 9 in the morning til 9 at night. There are plenty of restaurants and shops around the hotel.The hotel has 2 outdoor pools, of which only one is accessible with kids under the age of 16. Both pools are not free of charge. There are also several restaurants in the hotel, which looked nice, but we did not try.All in all we enjoyed our stay there.

Really great hotel. I look for hotels with great views and this was the correct hotel for it. You can see the Tokyo Tower and the skyscrapers surrounding it. There are a lot of rooms here but everything was well maintained and clean. The entrance is the best as it fits around the Japanese culture and is not western. There is also a Japanese garden which was lovely too. The location is great for transport as the Shinagawa station has trains going to every side of Tokyo. The rooms are great size compared to other hotels I have been to in Japan. There is also a 7eleven so you can get snacks and essentials easily. Definitely recommend to anyone who is new to Tokyo.

This hotel has nice garden...room is big and clean...convention room is good and big ...large lobby with severals sofa and reception area is so nice to check in or check out...good food for breakfast....near train station

Breakfast on the first day required guests to line up as the restaurant supposedly "full". Once we entered the restaurant we noticed numerous tables empty with no setup. Staff do not set up tables with cutlery and place settings - no service. Coffee urn hidden at the back of the restaurant in a corner and empty - we had to ask the staff to refill. Breakfast buffet choices limited and fruit choice was predominantly canned fruits.On trying to use the swimming pool told that all guests were required to pay an extra fee to utilise the swimming pool facilities. The extra cost per person was approximately $30. After complaining to the staff that this fee was unconscionable and not what one would expect from a "5 star" hotel we were told it was their policy to charge guests to use the pool.Although the hotel is conveniently located close to Shinagawa Railway Station I would not recommend this hotel if you are seeking a resort-style hotel to relax.

My family of eight visited Tokyo July 2019. We had been expecting tiny rooms and instead got full sized rooms - four of them. They each had king sized beds, a room safe which was bolted down, and a mini fridge.We had chosen the breakfast included option which gave us use of the club lounge. This is an amazing option. You can use the lounge any time and enjoy complimentary food and alcohol. This doesn't replace meals but is like having access to your own kitchen at home -only better. This option also allows access to the pool at no extra charge.It is near Shinagawa Station and we got around Tokyo using public transit. We could have stayed in a more downtown location but if I visit Tokyo again this is where I would want to stay. The hotel has a massage service and my husband and I had a couples massage in our room which was incredibly relaxing. We ate dinner twice at the hotel and were entertained by a piano player who played American movie music which was wonderful.The staff at the hotel were very kind but their English was poor. This surprised me because they are marketing themselves to an international clientele and better English from the staff would be appreciated.

It was an excellent stay from 15th June to 19th June; The hotel provided good service, and they treated customers very well. The Japanese people are very friendly and kind and obedient. Tokyo has alot to offer - shopping centres, Imperial Palace East Garden, Rainbow Bridge, Tokyo Tower etc.We had a good guide who was very helpful. Japan is a country -all should visit.

quality of rooms , accessibility, 7/11 in the basement, and great breakfast. register for the Sheigu program and you will have better offers!morover, the park is a real peacefull area in may time frame in aim to calm down before or after shinagawaa station. use the shuttle if any luggages.

First of all there are many properties with a similar name. This particular hotel is quite modern and elegant. The property includes grounds with mature plantings and walking paths. It is indeed beautiful. Rooms are on the small side but quite clean, modern and functional. Many have views of the property. A cluster of hotels sits on a hill in a busy bustling area a short distance from a very large rail station which is more like a multi-story mall. The bullet train has a stop here. Restaurants in hotel are fairly small and comfortable with Japanese and Western items. Buffet breakfast is very unique and satisfying with a large selection of fresh items. English is spoken but most employees are more comfortable speaking Japanese. A few simple words of Japanese go a long way to making your stay even more enjoyable. There is a large Conference center and a small area for landline online access and printer for a nominal fee. WiFi is free. Westerners and Japanese both enjoy this hotel in almost equal numbers. If for whatever reason you need to stay comfortably near connecting rail this may be one of your best choices. Viator tours has this property as one of there pick-up locations. You may well wish to book a tour of Mount Fuji with return to hotel by bullet train to experience many aspects of modern Japan in a wider context. Tour guides speak English well and give you quite an introduction to all things Japanese on the journey to Mount Fuji. Of course the mountain access to tours is seasonal.

Friendly staff. Rooms spacious and comfy and clean. Great service. Free WiFi intermittent goes on n off. Not stable. Free shuttle to Shinagawa train stn. There is a 7-11 store in the basement. Closes @ 2am.

Positive Walking distance to Shinagawa Station, shuttle bus to the station, near restaurants and shops around the station, excellent breakfast buffet, nice Japanese garden, 7/11 on premises. Concierge level lounge nicely stocked.Not so goodHuge hotel, busy, not overly friendly or helpful, lengthy check-in process with not enough staff. 2 employees checked in a long line of guests while 1 other employee disappeared and talked business with another one on the other side of the counter. They should have picked a different time. Carpet on the concierge level needs updating.

Rooms are great-well stocked bathrooms-razors,shaving cream...toothbrush/toothpaste and great toilet seats-I mention this as toilet seat design was a very evident Japanese thing in 3 cities I visited recently

This is a great location and the amenities around here are excellent. Within 3 blocks to the train station that will take you anywhere. The club rooms are not worth the price and the service given at the clubroom is a complete fail. Do not waste your money on that service. As for the rooms they are adequate, but the bathrooms are from the 60's, again a real disappointment. Need somewhere that is full of amenities and you don't mind a mediocre room this is your spot. Otherwise look around lots of choices.

This is a very lovely hotel with a beautiful Japanese garden and walking distance to Shinagawa Station & many eateries. Despite having to host thousands of us for an incentive trip, they are attentive to details and keep a good 5 Star Hotel standard. The lobby lounge Momiji is very nice and quiet and I enjoyed the live piano playing in the evening as I met my friends, soaking in the beautiful ambience with greenery outside the tall glass panels. I left something in the room after checking out and the housekeeping was able to locate and help me pass to a friend with email verification. And they speak English and reply very promptly!! Thank you once again for the awesome experience. I would certainly recommend it to my friends.

Finally Checked Into The Famous Hotel In Japan. Spacious And Comfortable Room ☺️Very big comfy room with lots of high tech gadget to use around, will be here for 4 nights 5 days to enjoy the beautiful ambience and scenery of this room.

There is a shuttle to the hotel from the train station (east exit I think). We didn't know about this so we caught a taxi (about $15) from the other side of the station. The hotel is very impressive. Staff are very professional and look after you. Check in was very good-quick and efficient. The room was large, but a little dated. A bedside table and lamp only on one side of the bed. Lighting very poor for reading. We had the Club option which was very convenient for us. The breakfast was good. Afternoon tea snacks from about 3-5 and from 5-7 there was unlimited drinks and canapes. Actually you could continue drinking until 9.30pm! With the price of drinks, especially wine in Japan, it was very good value. There were no hot canapes which was a shame. The shuttle service was good. Very few people were using it when we were there. Unfortunately the airport shuttle doesn't start until 9.30am so we had to catch a taxi as our flight was at 11am. That was disappointing as it cost us $76!!!!!

Excellent service with all requests attention to efficiently.Nice rooms and staff. Location fantastic with many eateries nearby. Rooms big and clean what a 5 star hotel should be. Very accommodating to all requests and as usual so polite and pro active.

We arrived Tokyo, Shinakawa station, by Shinkansen and the hotel is near the station. We are big group with luggage and have tried to contact hotel about the situation, the staff said reservation is not needed. When we were at the station, there is no sign or bus stop, we have to asked other hotel guest and waited 15 minutes to find out the we can not get in the shuttle bus because we stand next to the line, we try to ask the driver for the seat for small children and elderly but the driver do not speak English so we end up walking to the hotel on top of the slope. The distance is only 500 meter but with our luggage, children and elderly, we was tried to get to the hotel.Check in process is quick and we were satisfied with the room size but during winter time, only heater, you can not adjust anything for the air condition system and that night. We have to open the window.Overall, satisfy with the service and room.

Stayed at this hotel during my recent visit to Tokyo. Was a great experience and lovely location. Clean room and breakfast was varied. Lovely welcome on checking in and would stay again for sure. Shop in basement is a god send.

Pleasant hotel with spacious rooms and a location ideal for transport links. Just a couple of issues, no swimming pool and the buffet diner is booked solid every night, so if you arrive tired and just want an easy meal you can't get one here.

Renovated and clean, this hotel is over 40 years old. You may consider this halfway between a business hotel and a resort hotel. you can easily tell that this hotel has been renovated from an older structure. the renovations have made these accommodations up to the standards of newer modern hotels. The bathroom being one unit with the toilet and shower together in one room is a telltale sign that this is a business hotel in Japan. Although clean and somewhat convenient, prices from 20,000 yen seem a bit on the expensive side to me. I guess it's location, location, location...

Nothing stood out. Our checkin process was an issue, as they booked us into a single/twin bed room (2 single beds), and we requested a king room. We were told that none were available, so we decided to stay elsewhere. Upon this information, they double checked and still none were available, so we told them to cancel our reservation and we would move down the street. However, miraculously, one room appeared and we were checked in. The room itself was clean, but nothing special and needed an update. It appears that the hotel may be doing some updates, as there was a note in our room that construction was happening on the floor above (we didn't notice any noise, so that was a relief). We were on the club floor (likely the miraculous appearance, as they didn't want to give us this room originally), but the club lounge was closed for reconstruction. As in many Asian hotels, the thermostat is only AC or heat depending on the season, so you can't really adjust the temperature much. Our room was a bit too warm, but there was a small balcony and sliding door to let in fresh air. Our stay included breakfast, and it was average. The food selection was good and fresh, but the service was quite lacking. The breakfast buffet is a full self-service buffet. There is no one to seat you, no one to bring water or coffee, and no one to clear your dishes. The tables are bare, so you have to find the utensils and napkins yourself. The coffee is hidden at the farthest corner of the room. I had to find someone to ask where it was and the only person I could find was the hostess outside of the restaurant. Again, the food selection was good, but be prepared to do everything yourself. The hotel is located close to Shinagawa Station, so it is easy to get around Tokyo, but there isn't much to do nearby the hotel. Be prepared if you have luggage, as it is an uphill walk from the station to the hotel.

The hotel was in a great location with easy access to restaurants and the train station. The hotel is quite large with bars and restaurants. Breakfast was included in our room rate and breakfast was very nice. The selection was fantastic and the food was very good.However, the rooms were tired and crowded.

We stayed at this hotel during a business trip. The staff is exceptionally pleasant and helpful, even if Japanese is not well understood. The rooms are nice and roomy, and especially clean, with modern amenities. Excellent Club Lounge for a wide range of breakfast and snack-time foods and beverages. Definitely worth considering and i would return again.
user_name:
goalee111
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Situated about 5 mins walk from Shinagawa station. There is a free shuttle bus if u opted not to walk especially if u have luggages. Is a Hugh hotel n there are a few prince hotels nearby under the same management if u choose to stay there. The room is a little small n is clean n modern. Staff are friendly. Many eateries near the train station. There is also a direct train to the haneda airport for about 420 yen or airport limousine at 720 about 20 mins drive but the timing is not convenient as it only runs at certain hours. As with most hotels in Japan there are the basic amenities like shampoo , tooth brushes n so on. We will stay here again as the price is reasonable.

High end hotel that was great value in my view. All the facilities you could thinks of, multiple restaurants, bars, cafe and even a 7 11 store. We didn't use any restaurants as we were trying to maintain a travel budget but the food looked wonderful.Great location with a shuttle bus operating every 20 minutes to Shinagawa station. It is only 5 minute walk to the station. Lots of restaurants, bars and cafes nearby. This was great location to launch into exploring Tokyo. Would highly recommend and would definitely not hesitate in booking here again.

One of the key reasons for choosing this hotel was the availability of rooms that can sleep four adults. The other is its proximity to the train station that helped us get to the Haneda Airport in less than 30mins on an early morning.Arriving at the station and coming out from the Takanawa exit, the hotel is a comfortable 5 min walk up a quite gentle slope. Check-in was without fuss and the room while was a bit tight for four of us still allow us to move around and have quality sleep. The small fitness center was also available to us with no charge. Service from the concierge was good which provide us with ample information. The room service was also commendable as they responded to our requests in a timely manner.We had breakfast at the various cafes near the train station and as mentioned by reviewers before, the seven eleven is very handy. Although the Shinagawa station does not has any subway station, it did not pose any issue to us as it has trains that took us to the major stops and where needed allow us to transfer to the subway or other trains.We thoroughly enjoyed the experience at a good value and quality luxury hotel.

Hotel is fairly faceless, goo for business travel. Location is very convenient for Shinagawa station with subway, JR, Shinkansen access. Only about 20 minutes by train from Narita airport. Room is large, with a cute balcony. Dehumidifier was very much appreciated. Wi-fi is free throughout the hotel and works very well. Buffet restaurant is good, with both Japanese and non-Japanese options. I preferred the Japanese one for (i) good pre-packaged selection, for both breakfast and dinner; (ii) quiet atmosphere and exceptional service.Fitness room was a disappointment - small, stuffy and has just 2 treadmills and 2 bikes. Nowhere near enough for the huge hotel.

We spent three nights at Grand Prince Takanawa - it is part of the Prince group of hotels and is close to Shinagawa station. A mini bus basically picks you up during the day from Shinagawa station which avoids a 7 minute uphill walk from the station. The lobby and the restaurants are fantastic - it is a busy hotel and the rooms are comfortable and clean. The buffet breakfast has huge spread - but is expensive. However if you wish there are nice cafes at the Shinagawa station building. Access to all of Tokyo is fantastic via Shinagawa station and so it is ideal for a base hotel. They also have an airport drop off bus to Haneda. Overall a great hotel for tourist purposes.

This can not say that location is centrally , but i could find each and everything near to hotel as tourist or business traveler.Main thing it is just walking distance for Shinkansen station, it can say like less than 10 minutes walk.many Indian restaurant could find within 10-20 minutes walking distance.I had spent 2 night stay at this hotel and al was pleasant.Breakfast quality and variety also awesome.

Family of 3 adults stayed at this hotel (ninth floor) for four nights in late November. Our room was clean and spacious with three, good sized comfortable beds. There was no need to bring toiletries as toothbrushes, hair brush, shampoo, conditioner, body wash and shower cap were provided.Check in was fast and trouble free. Hotel staff were very polite and efficient. The hotel is close to Shinagawa Station, restaurants and shops. There is a shuttle bus that runs between the hotel and the train station. There is also a 7-11 store nearby to buy drinks and snacks.Thoroughly enjoyable stay. Can recommend this hotel.

With a sprawling hotel lobby, well laid out and large rooms and multiple restaurants for different cuisine, ATM, money changing, shops and whole lot of luxury its a beautiful place to stay and maybe spend more time with in the hotel to get to know it better. Access from hotel lower levels to main street to walk down to Shinagawa station for trains and bullet trains and close proximity to malls the hotel is truly luxurious.My stay was even comfortable with helpful staff and guest relations desk to handle local tours and guide guests for all their needs. The friendly guest relations team comprising of Ms. Kanako Hirano, SatsukiTusha were helpful and a special mention need to be made of the very elegant and knowledgeable Ms Kodirova Zebiniso who was also very supportive and helpful.. The entire staff present themselves so well and attend to your needs and are efficient. Only one draw back is that the check in process is bit long and the check out is even longer and a bit slow hence guests may need to factor the additional bit of time in their itinerary.

Football Stadium like experience, huge lines, huge and impersonal hotel...rooms could do with some revamping, not sure why it was so packed at the time (maybe because typhoon), old reputation, not impressed, never again sorry...

Stayed at grand prince new Takanawa for total of 9 nights.. rooms are spacious and comfortable which come with balcony.. toilet maintenance could have been better for the price. Shuttle bus from Shinagawa Station is a major plus since you have to walk 10-15 mins upslope from Shinagawa Station to hotel if you miss the shuttle which ends at 9plus pm.

Its a conference hotel. Facilities where adequate nothing to be excited for. Location is secluded and a distance from any major shopping or entertainment area. At best 10-15 mins by Taxi. I do not recommended this hotel for vacationers, family and tourists. A bit of walk to the train station too. Did not like food served in the conference had to settle with eating in the restaurant outlets inside the hotel which was ok. Experience can be better.

Booked this place at the last minute for a trip involving two families, each with two young children. Rates work out pretty well closer to the travel date using websites like booking.com. Stayed here one night for the reasonable rate and easy connection for our onward journey. Hotel is very near to the Shinagawa station, though not really walkable with luggage as it is up a hill. There is a convenient shuttle bus that takes you round all the Prince brand hotels clumped on the hill next to the station. It is definitely more of a business hotel, so don’t expect anything catered specially for the children. Nevertheless, the room was comfortable and fairly spacious by Tokyo standards. We had a club king room and the bed was large enough for the adults and baby. There was a comfortable sofa for the older child to sleep on. Bathroom was decent, but be aware that it has a bathtub and shower in one. This is quite different from what appears to be standard in other Japanese hotels where the shower and bathtub are separate. The Club Room offered breakfast at the Club level and we happily took it. A nice little spread with a little for most tastes. It was obviously catered to the business types complete with hushed atmosphere and we felt somewhat out of place with our young and rather messy little ones. Staff were professional and fairly helpful. We ate up and got out as soon as we could. Check out seemed to be a little slow. Perhaps things were lost in translation. Hard to say.

Stayed here for 4 nights for a conference. The hotel lobby and grounds are beautiful, the Japanese gardens are gorgeous and lovely to walk through. However it is a big hotel, with the rooms being very dated. They are clean but could do with some updating.Great breakfast selection in the buffet and also have the option of eating at the Japanese restaurant for a traditional Japanese breakfast. Also handy to have the convenience store downstairs and it is just a short walk (5-10 mins)to the JR station or you can hop on the free shuttle.
Walking distance from Shinagawa Station, quality hotel with excellent rooms, breakfast, dinner facilities or easy assess to alternatives.Comfortable bed, nice room with all facilities you would want.

Checked in on 28/Oct for 2 nights and that I will be staying again on 1/Nov for 3 nights. This was not noted in the system, when I checked back in on 1/Nov. I was told they can only have me for 2 nights. So I asked where am I going to stay and the guy said “I don’t know, the guy who checked you in didn’t note your extended nights down”. After insisting that he has to fix this for me, he finally found me a room. But I have to move to the next hotel “Takanawa”, which was fine since they’ll do the transfer for me. Thought that was the end of the horrible experience.But when I wanted to have Japanese breakfast which was only available at New Takanawa, they couldn’t bring my luggage back from Takanawa to New Takanawa so I could get a cab there to airport after breakfast. I stayed here for 3 times, this is my worst experience.

This is by far the nicest hotel of our 21 day tour of Japan. A beautiful remodeled hotel with very large rooms and bathrooms. I do not want to leave because it is so much nicer than the other hotels we have stayed in. Most comfortable beds of the trip as well. Excellent service in the hotel though English skills are weak. Still very accommodating lovely staff. Breakfast buffet was good but not the best of the trip. It is walking distance to shinagawa station . Beware we were not advised so heed this good advice. When you buy tickets to return via subway. Buy tickets to your transfer station.,When you get to the transfer station you need to go out and then buy a second ticket on the JR line to Shinegawa. It is not part of the regular subway system fare structure.This was confusing since everything is automated and you need to put in a station for the correct fare. Luckily nice Japanese English speakers helped us. Down the street is a nice food court. The hotel lacks an indoor pool but it’s sister hotel the Prince Takanawa down the street has a nice lap pool indoors that you can use for 1050 yen with your room key.

i stayed 5 night in september 2018. I used to stay in Prince hotel direct in Shinagawa but i changed to this one and this was a great idearoom is large, great view, big king size bed... the lobby and services are great too! definitely a good choice, in 5min you are at shinagawa station, perfect for your meetings and shinkansen

Checking in was a breeze and, despite the large size of this hotel, the staff were very welcoming. My club suite room on the 16th floor was generally well designed and had the amenities one would expect for a hotel in this category. The WiFi was a bit fiddly to set up - you first have to switch on the TV, work out how to set it to English with the remote control, and then navigate down the menu on the screen to access the access code - but was fast and reliable thereafter. The lounge/office was spacious with four tasteful abstract art images and inoffensive decor. It was well laid out and comfortable to work in. The Nespresso dolce gusto machine was a welcome addition and definitely kept me caffeinated.There were a reasonable number of power sockets but all were solely in the Japanese 2-pin format - there didn't seem to be any multi-purpose sockets or adaptors that would help international guests use their appliances. The lighting was relatively good and the provision of an air purifier (also in the bedroom) was a thoughtful gesture. I liked the fact that the windows were not sealed and that one could access a modest balcony.The bathroom is the weakest link. It had very poor lighting even when the slats in the louvre window to bedroom are opened to allow in some natural light. I guess it would be very unpopular with people trying to apply make-up. The designer taps on the twin sinks look great but the laminar flow water coming out of them invariably gets deflected out of the sink as soon as you try to wash your hands. Consequently, you spend time trying to mop up the flood to prevent damage to the room and to any toiletries nearby. Otherwise it's fine - the shower, for example, works very well. Perhaps inevitably, there is a 'smart' toilet that automatically detects you as you enter and responds by raising the cover on the toilet seat. If you are bored, see if you can get to seat without activating the motion sensor! The bedroom had a very comfortable bed with crisp white linen. Happily, the curtains block the light very effectively so one can get a good nights sleep. There are power sockets on both sides of the bed, which is handy when one wants to re-charge a phone but still have it nearby. Equally happily, it's possible to find your way to bed without leaving any lights on!The Club Room worked very well. There is a light supper option, from 5-7 pm, which may well allow many people to skip dinner. Typically, it features cold savoury options such as a pork rillette with dark chocolate, smoked salmon, a salad with raw fish and tomatoes, and a selection of cold meats. There is also a good selection of drinks including sparkling wine. The service was excellent and food and drinks got replaced promptly, when necessary.

仕事で毎回利用していますが、本当に残念なホテルです。全ての人ではありませんが、大体のスタッフの方はとても不親切で、同じサービスを提供する仕事をするものとして、言葉遣い、会話のトーンなど、とても不親切で丁寧でないと感じるスタッフが多いと感じました。特にフロントの方々、電話の対応がとても残念です。あと一点、お風呂場に関しても、部屋によってカビ臭い匂いや、タバコ臭い匂いがしたりします。仕事でなければ絶対に泊まりたくないし、同じ日本人としてとても残念に思います。I always stay in this hotel for business purposes but this hotel is totally disappointing. the service standard of staff is very low and the way they speak to costumer is I feel they have no respect. the frontdesk staff is not friendly and as a Japanese this service level is not acceptable, i DO NOT recommend this at all.The bathroom smells very bad sometimes and I can tell that somebody was smoking before. Hairdryer is always broken so I have to call them ask them for another one.

My first time to Japan, I stayed at the Prince Shinagawa. While it wasn't a bad hotel, it made me stay away from Shinagawa the next few times I was in Tokyo. This time, my boss was staying at Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa, I decided to give it a try. The hotel surprised me in a good way in many areas.Getting to the hotel is easy. It is a 5 minute walk once you get out of Shinagawa Station (Central Gate - Takanawa exit). It is uphill which can be challenging if you have big luggage. They do have a shuttle from the station that runs from 8 am to 9:20 PM. It shows up every 20 minutes (:00, :20, :40). The hotel is the last stop so it can take about 10 to 15 minutes before you are back at the hotel. It is usually faster to just walk but it is convenient when you are tired.The hotel itself has a large and beautiful lobby. When I checked in, I was immediately surrounded by very helpful staff who offered me help with my luggage. Check-in was smooth and quick. I had a non-smoking room and I was worried that it was one of those converted rooms where you can still smell the smoke. My room was fine and did not have any smell. My room also had an air purifier which also helped with the quality of air in the room. The size of the room was generous by Tokyo standards. In fact, I would say that it was one of the bigger non-ryokan rooms I had in Japan. This is great was it made packing some of our bigger bags a lot easier.I would be remiss if I did not talk about the staff at the hotel. In my mind, they are the star of the hotel. They were super friendly and always smiling. They helped me with taxis, restaurant reservations, and answering my questions quickly. My stay at the hotel was broken up into two different stays. They were able to hold my luggage for me until I return. The main negative and why I did not give the hotel 5 stars is that it got really crowded during the weekend. It isn't their fault but it is a popular hotel for tour groups and a few airlines have their crew staying there too. When it got crowded, the staff tried their best to direct traffic and keep the elevators flowing. It helped a little but not enough to take away the feeling of feeling crowded.Shinagawa is a convenient station to start your day as it is well connected. It is also a lot quieter than Tokyo, Shibuya, or Shinjuku. I would not hesitate to stay at Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa again.

Good sized room with desk and single lounge chair. We were on the 15th floor so had a great outlook. Really good speed wifi and lots of power points throughout the room. Located close to the train station & restaurants. Stylish reception area & bar. Staff were very friendly & helpful.

This is a well situated very large hotel. The staff are friendly and the rooms are clean and the beds comfortable. The let down for us was breakfast in Momiji. It's a set breakfast but all the food in brought out at the same time, so everything is pretty much cold by the time you get around to eating it all. This process also makes for a very crowded table. The other disappointment was the chocolate bar. It tries to be a little upmarket but there is no atmosphere and, while the chocolates ate very tasty (and not cheap), the coffee is served in takeaway cups.

Like a Connery Bond move, the high tech is hidden behind art deco, and for the most part this works. The staff work really hard to accomodate, and the infrastructure is there to support them. So while their might be more flashy, prestigious hotels, this one is definitely comfortable and classy. The pond and garden inside the grounds are a nice touch, as are the flowered walkways between the hotel buildings.Breakfast was fresh, and amazing. so much so that I often did not feel the need for lunch. There was a very wide and capable selection of breakfast options, too many to do justice to to be fair. but the fresh fruit selection in general and the Pear and Pineapple in particular was on point. I would definitely reccommend this hotel

This hotel located near to Shinagawa stations only 10 minute walk, this stations connected with JR Yamanote line so its easy to go to other area in Tokyo if we stay here.the front office staff are very helpful and the concierge also provide the extra box to wrap up our luggage with reasonable price.The room also quite large for Japan standard. overall this a good hotel

We stayed here for one night after a business meeting in Tokyo. Our reservation was for 'The Club Floor Stay'. This stay plan includes, obviously, a room on the so-called 'Club Floor' and use of the Club Lounge.Arrival and check in: There is a shuttle bus from Shinagawa station. You can walk it easily but it is up hill and mid-summer with a suit case you might as well jump on the bus that seems to be about every twenty minutes. As we were staying on the Club Floor, we could check in there. All very smooth and efficient.Service: This is very much a Japanese hotel. Of course, foreigners do stay here but the service and attitudes are completely Japanese. What does this mean? Well, it means that the service is excellent, extremely polite, attentive and efficient. But all the usual Japanese sensibilities are present. I have no opinion on the matter other than to note, for example, the signs at baths and pool saying "People with tattoos are not allowed to use these facilities. If we find even one tattoo, no mater how small (whatever the age), you will be asked to leave immediately". Which I found a little comical as it conjured up images of a team of people hunting high and low on guests for even one tattoo, no matter how small. I have no idea of the relevance of the age (of tattoo or guest, I am not sure).Room: We were on the fifteenth floor, room 3554. Wonderful view out over Tokyo. By day and by night. But it would have been a lot better if they did not have solid panels for the balcony rail. So, great view when standing up but nothing to see when sat down. The room was well appointed with a big king bed. Very comfortable.Pool: Two shallow pools, the Diamond Pool and the Sky something. I don't think that either of them was more than 1.2 metres deep, but it was pleasant enough to splash around and relax on the loungers. The Diamond pool shuts at, um 18:00, I think, but the Sky pool is open until later and the lights come on in the evening, when youngsters under sixteen years of age are not allowed.Club Lounge: This alone would not justify the price of the package. It is bright, yes, with a view to the opposite side of our room (i.e. not a view of the Tokyo Tower), but it is not particularly spacious. Free drinks and nibbles and that in the evening includes alcohol. People on the Club Stay plan have breakfast here.Breakfast: I don't know what breakfast is available downstairs but in the Club Lounge, this was probably the lowest level of the overall stay. A two-star breakfast at most. I've had better in a standard business hotel. And it is a cramped affair with care being needed to stop plates overflowing off of the little table.Other facilities: We enjoyed using the bath in the Sakura Prince Tower ("No tattoo, no matter how small"), which was available as part of our stay plan. The bath was not particularly hot but there is a wet and dry sauna, if that is your thing. The Japanese garden is really lovely. The bell there is from the seventeenth century and the koi pond, shrubs and bridges contribute to a really delightful setting.

This is one of many Prince hotels in Shinagawa / Takanawa, perhaps the newest one? Quite big, well kept, nice decor, lots of restaurants and a lovely garden with two pools. One is adults only and naturally much more quite than the familiy version. Club floor was great, impeccable service and friendly staff. The choice of refreshments was perhaps not the biggest, but there were a few nibbles and some good wines. In addition to beer, spirits and sodas.A really well run 5 star establishment!

Well located near Shinagawa station this hotel offers good value for money - big, clean hotel with tons of tourists. Awkward that you need to pay for the swimming pool (approx 50$ for 2 adults + 2 kidz) and unacceptable that you can’t use pool if you have a tattoo... wake up: we are 2018 and a tattoo doesn’t mean you are part of a criminal gang! PS: powder brings light in the room :-)))

A short 5-minute walk from the westside of Shinagawa Train Station. There are a couple of other Prince hotels in the area that you will pass to this property. The lobby is open and inviting. The staff warm and friendly as most of the Japanese people that you will encounter during your visit to Japan.The rooms are very nice and large and filled with all the necessities. We were up on the 6th floor with a very nice view looking out into the city. It was quiet and relaxing. Could barely hear people talking in the hallway.The hotel has a number of restaurants and a very nice lobby bar overlooking an outside garden oasis. The outer garden is well manicured and delightful. A very large pond with fish and turtles complete the peacefulness of this property in the middle of Tokyo.

Stayed at the hotel for two nights. Nice at reception on arrival. Got an upgraded room.The room was top notch. Did not have breakfast on the buffe but in a restaurant in the hotel. It was okay. The hotel also has a pool area which unfortunately I did not have time on my stay to try this offer. But I had the opportunity of a visit to the bar in the evening. There me and my wife had some drinks which was not well balanced. So we had to ask for sugar and lemon juice to balance the drinks ourselves. This is the first time I have had to do this in a bar before. It's not good service. I Was also a little hungry so I ordered a pizza margarita. I should not have done that. It was terrible. Like a frozen pizza from the supermarket. The hotel is fantastic. Super service at the front desk. Lovely view from the room. Just do not make use of the bar.

This hotel has been delightful for our family and our needs. The location, room, accessibility and transfers were awesome. The location has been pivotal for our tours. We went to Kyoto, Mt. Fuji and Kamakura, have been picked up on time by the tour personnel. There were staff in the counters but staff standing nearby were always ready to help. There has shuttle buses to the different Prince Hotel for free which paved way for transport to and from Shinagawa station. Walking was a little but uphill but manageable. If my 7 yr old daughter can do it, it’s doable. The food for their breakfast buffet was amazing. Fresh, authentic and very good! We never got tired of it. My children enjoyed and tried all what they can taste and pretty much enjoyed it. Our room were pretty much enough for the 5 of us but not enough space to entertain a visitor. Overall our experience with children for vacation with this hotel was an excellent one. Definitely can go back and choose this one again.

The hotel is a Oasis of peace in busy Tokyo. The rooms are spacious and clean. The beds are comfortable and of good quality. The hotel has a nice swimming pool. The only drawback is the lack of a well-equipped gym. The hotel is definitely recommended for families who stay in Tokyo for a few days. The staff is very friendly and service oriented, most of them understand some English.

As we returned to Tokyo after a multi-city performing tour across Japan in 2017, we chose to stay here for our final days on this segment. We enjoyed the shared garden with the two other Prince Hotels in this area, and loved the view from the room. It is the newest of the hotels in this region, and we appreciated the updated amenities. The hotel staff all knew a good amount of English, and we had no issues with communication. Lovely people!

Great location bear station and clean. Many restaurants around hotel so convinient.However really shocked to find out I needed to pay to use the pool. It was ¥3000 per person approx £20 per day. Plus it's more if you need a sunbed, ¥5000 for a sunbed. I've never had to pay to use the swimming pool at a hotel and also at a cost of over £100 for the both of us for a day........ wow

The room was quite nice and spacious for the price and even included a balcony. Staff were always very helpful and accommodating (though occasionally it was difficult to communicate in English). Property includes a beautiful Japanese garden that makes for a great stroll. Location a convenient 5-10 minute walk from a central train station. Overall would recommend.
user_name:
djX6308BU
New York City, New York

review_body: Stayed at the place on business in July 2018 and found it mostly very comfortable. I was in a club room and the room itself was a good size and the bed comfy. I did find the air conditioning to be pretty ineffectual, but Tokyo in July was always going to be warm! The club floor was nice with a decent range of drinks and snacks, although it closed at 9pm sharp!The buffet breakfast was excellent (if expensive 3700 yen)) with a very good range and regularly restocked. The 'gym' was, umm, a little lacking in the building where I was based. It consisted on two treadmills and two static bikes! I did discover a much better equipped place in a linked building (called Sakamora I think) which was a lot better, but didn't open early enough (7am). Overall, I would be happy to stay there again and very likely will!!

i stayed here for 3 nights and the room was nice, they have balcony in my room, buat the bathroom was really dark. I recommend you the restaurant for breakfast in the lower floor, same as seven eleven store, because the 1st floor breakfast restaurant serve all japanese food, the restaurant on the lower floor serve like western, chinese, etc

Stayed there from 26Jun18 to 29Jun18. Convenient location with easy access from Haneda Airport by train. Hotel is within walking distance from Shinagawa Train Station (JR) and Takanawadai Station (Tokyo Metro). But if you are arriving via Haneda Airport and have heavy luggage(s), I recommend taking free hotel shuttle bus from Shinagawa Station instead. I made the mistake of walking to the hotel with my heavy luggages. This was because albeit gentle, it was still an upslope walk all the way from the station to the hotel. Do note the timing and route though as the last bus is at 9pm+ and it serves other hotels within Prince Group located in the vicinity as well. Superior Modern King Room that I stayed was clean, spacious and had a good sized bathroom.One addition plus point is a 7-11 at the basement level of the hotel. It was my saviour when I craved for a simple late night supper.

The hotel (or the convention centre next to the hotel) was having an event when I arrived. There were hundreds of people queuing from all directions of the hotel entrances. I was lucky to come in through main door to realised that they were not queuing for reception.Also note that there are several prince hotels so they have very similar names. It was very confusing and we went to the wrong hotel. Location is good but I suggest using the hotel shuttle if you have many bags. It’s a five minute walk up hill from the train station. The hotel let me have early check which was great after long flights. The room is spacious as compared to most other hotels, with a balcony. Good wifi signal.The pools were not open and I was told by staff that they only open in summer (July). But it was 31 degrees. Didn't check out breakfast at hotel.

We stayed six nights. Ok but not new rooms. The hotel looked really nice on the website also informing about a summer open swimming pool. That made the high price acceptable. Received too few breakfast coupons on check in. After having looked around a bit, we asked front desk who said that the swimming pool was closed (emptied despite 30 deg C outside). No apologies. Our daughter was very sad about this. Sent an email with complaints but just a simple apology no compensation. Upon my repeated written request for compensation still no compensation in any form. Also then (day before leaving) was informed that we could use the indoor swimming pool in the next door hotel for an extra fee. (!) Mistakes or misunderstandings can happen but these can be managed well or not so well...this was the latterAccording to our daughter this is the worst hotel she has stayed in.

Pretty quiet area of Tokyo. About a 5min walk to Shinagawa Station. Hotel staff is impeccable. Ordered room service and they arrived just as stated. Complimentary newspaper each day. Lobby is one of the largest that Ive experience. Hotel has it's own 7-11 and several restaruants. Complimentary shuttle to the Shinagawa station if you dont want to walk. I think the shuttle provides ride to the airport as well. Will stay here again.

The room is very spacious compared to other common hotel in Tokyo. I tried the tempura restaurant dinner there, and we reserved the private room with private chef on it. It was an amazing experience for us enjoying Japanese style-tempura dinner. Around 10 minutes walk to the station, but kind of hilly. And Airport Limousine Bus stops in here, so it is very convenient and cheap. Before I tried go to Haneda Airport by taxi around JPY6,000 and to Narita Airport by Alphard taxi around JPY23,000, all is one way price.

I am staying at this hotel for a work trip and while the lobby, service, accessibility to the train, Japanese gardens on property, and proximity to shops/restaurants make this a 5/5 hotel, it is the actual room that is more on par with a 2/5. My room is definitely old with peeling wall paper, stains on the walls, chairs, and a bathroom that has seen better days. It does not matter whether I have the room cleaned or not as it still has dirt, i.e. leaves/grass (not from me), feathers, layers of dust on the built-in furniture, pink mildew in the tub, etc. I also realized that I was not the only creature staying in the hotel room on my first morning when I met a jumpy spider. I am disappointed that I am paying over 200 USD for this kind of room.

Gorgeous property in the heart of Tokyo. Beautiful gardens and outdoor rooftop pool. Rooms were large and modern with flat screen tvs, comfortable mattresses, and modern decor. Within walking distance to the train station. Would highly recommend this hotel. Several restaurants on upper levels. Deals are often available through Priceline.

This hotel provide the best and comfortable experience in Tokyo. It is walking distance to the Shinagawa Station - best access for transport to other parts in Tokyo. The rooms are very clean, comfortable and pleasant to stay. Lobby and restaurants are very clean and spacious.

Tokyo was the last leg of our Japan holiday - and Shinagawa proved to be an excellent location on the Yamamoto line; a major stop for all services. Hotel is 5-10mins Walk - or shuttle bus provided. Quality of furnishings was average - but ok for the room rate. Service was mostly efficient - but we object to an hourly charge for late checkout; haven’t come across that before- either offer it or don’t. Hotel’s Japanese garden was beautiful and provided a relaxing start to the day.

I stayed in a king suite. The rooms design was a bit dated, but my room, along with hotel was up-kept very well. Very clean. The bathroom silicone was clean and professionally applied. My preferred maintenance check. It was nice to have a 7-11 right inside the hotel.There is a shuttle bus every 20 minutes to and from Shinagawa station that you should use, as the hotel is 500 metres up a hill from the station. There is a different subway station 400 metres away on flat ground in the opposite direction.

Prince Hotels chain is really famous and good in Japan, so I am always positive there will be no problems with any hotel they have. New Takanawa was a new choice for me, but I was very happy with the stay. Rooms are spacious, extremely clean and comfortable. Breakfast is delicious and has lots of varieties from asian to european choices. Reception staff is not so fast unfortunately, but I experienced this in every hotel I stayed in Tokyo so I was not surprised.. For business and leisure I can only recommend this hotel. Thank you for a great stay!

We were at the end of a long holiday and spent two days in Tokyo. This hotel is not near any of the hotspots but has close proximity to Shinagawa station as an advantage so we were able to get around quite easily. Our room was very large and beautifully appointed. We were on level 16 and had majestic views. The staff were quite exceptionally helpful. The restaurants were very expensive so we ate outside where there were a number of offerings. The hotel is very large , modern and efficient. The real winner for us was the very large and well appointed room

This is a beautiful hotel which creates a good impression from the moment you arrive at its very attractive entrance. The lobby is huge and very attractively decorated. Our room was very spacious and comfortable with all amenities you need. The staff are very attentive and give great service. There was an extensive choice of quality food for buffet breakfast. The hotel is in a very convenient location close to shops, train station and a good variety of places to eat.

We had a truly wonderful experience with the hotel staff and facilities. Check-in was fast and easy. Although it was only a 5 minute walk to Shinagawa Station, the free shuttle to and from the hotel was very convenient when we had a lot of shopping bags to carry. The superior twin room with extra bed was very spacious for the three of us, especially compared to other hotel rooms I’ve experienced in Japan. The garden was beautiful and the sakura trees were in full bloom making our first night there a dream. There is a 7-11 store in the hotel which was convenient to pick up any late night snacks or drinks. We tried the Shimizu Restaurant and the food was excellent and reasonably priced for a hotel restaurant. During our stay, we had an emergency medical situation and Assistant Manager Hanako Fujikake provided extraordinary service. She made a highly stressful situation better by helping us call for an ambulance, helping us extend our reservation for another 10 days in the same room, and followed up with us whenever she saw us in the hotel. Many of the hotel staff inquired how we were doing, which was very nice. If you take advantage of the Greener Cleaning option, you will receive a voucher that can be used at any of the hotel facilities.

You need a map to find your way in the lobby! Actually, there are maps located here in there at the lobby level to help clients find the restaurant of there choice among the many they have, located at different levels. The morning buffet was challenging at first, so many clients at the same time. But we managed to find a quiet spot, at the far end. The choices are impressive, from the typical Japanese menu to the full ''American'' type. The garden, located at the back of the hotel is breathtaking, specially during Cherry Tree blossom season, there are about 17 different types of Cherry Trees. More so, we could walk to a train station near by which helped us reach any of our selected destination in Tokyo.

Beautiful impressive entrance. Our room was large enough to fit our suitcases etc (not always possible in some hotels). Breakfast had a great choice of dishes with ample room for guests. A 711 was a handy store for snacks and bits and pieces on the lower floor.A few minutes walk to the Shinagawa station with plenty of restaurants and shops close by.

Had one of the best conferences , the hotel staff was very polite and helpful .Would say that they really went out of the way to keep us comfortable through out the stay .To keep a group of 1000 + people comfortable is not easy but for them it was a breeze ,service with a smile and a bow takes a new meaning in Japan

Recently my wife and I had an overnight stay at the Grand Prince Hotel, this hotel being selected due to its closeness to Shinagawa Railway Station (about five minutes walk from the hotel).This is a very big hotel. It is modern and very nicely furnished. The checkin staff are efficient and business like, but not overly friendly. Checking in is a bit like going to a bank, you line up and wait for the next available service officer to serve you. Same when you are checking out. The most pleasing aspect of our room was its size. It was a large room with plenty of space to spread your things around, without tripping over them if you have to get up during the night. The bathroom, on the other hand, was relatively small and a bit dull really, BUT they did have one of those fantastic Japanese toilets. You really feel as though you are in the drivers seat when you use these toilets. The room looks as though it has been fairly recently remodelled and the layout changed. The large king size (twin double) bed faces the window. The bed head with light controls etc are behind you, meaning you have to reach behind and over your head to find & turn the lights off. There was a couch behind the bed; not particularly functional as a couch & a waste of space, but good as another place to spread your gear on. The TV is on what is now the side wall, so if you want to watch TV in bed, it is at a right angle to you and you have to turn on your side to watch it, which is a bit strange. Also, the air conditioning controls are supposedly tucked away in the wardrobe. I could not find it, so the A/C was not really comfortable.There is a small balcony if you want to check out the outside view.We didn't eat at the hotel, as we arrived late so I am unable to comment on the hotel's restaurants. There are plenty of shops and restaurants within a close walk of the hotel. Free WiFi is avalaible.In summary, there is little wrong with this hotel. It caters for all the needs travellers usually look for and it is comfortable enough. It just doesn't have much charm and is impersonal.

Liked this hotel - great size rooms and comfortable beds. We arrived before the official check in time and the front desk managed to get us a room as my daughter had been travel sick. Club floor a bonus as we were able to get drinks in the evening and a small but good breakfast selection. Close to the Shinkansen Station at Shinagawa. Bus transfer was £56 for 3 people (2 adults and a 5 year old). Took 2 hours - would recommend fast train into Shinagawa and then shuttle bus up the hill. 7eleven in basement handy.

We stayed there because my husband had a business trip and booked a king bedroom with his name, but added me when we checked in. They asked for 4000 yen/night!Addition to that, my husband's breakfast was included but my 4000 yen addition did not, so I had to pay another 3000 yen for breakfast buffet. Biggest mistake! Worst breakfast buffet I've ever had in Tokyo. The quality of foods and choices could not be compared with hotels like Hilton, Hyatt Regency, Marriot, Westin etc where they charge around the same price. You could have better and cheaper breakfast near Shinagawa station, so do not waste your money if it was not included. (Well, even if it is included, choose other restaurants in the Hotel!)The room was clean, renovated and comfortable, but the elevator doors close on you hard and might hurt you, so be aware.

About a 10 minute walk from Shinegawa train station, this hotel is part of larger complex of 3 hotels and expo center catering to events , weddings and larger groups. The rooms are decent sized for a hotel in Tokyo , and bathrooms are small but good water pressure in the showers and nice bidet toilets. The beds and pillows are very comfortable and the WiFi is free and fast. There are 5 Restaraunt’s at the hotel and several around Shinegawa station as well. It is About 90 mins by bus from Narita and about 70 mins by train (NEX). Tokyo tower is close by but not much else. So plan on taking a train everywhere

The rooms are very spacious by Japanese standards, well appointed and comfortable. They have open air balconies which we used continually. The onsite gardens are remarkably well maintained, complete with relaxing water features. The lobby is grand and gorgeous. The Main Bar serves a standout Cosmopolitan and the Caesar salad with a pizza margarita is very tasty. Make sure to ask for Belvedere Vodka. The breakfast and dinner buffets are the best choice in the hotel. This hotel is not well located to central Tokyo and is a 15-minute subway ride away.

We stayed 4 nights in this huge hotel. The room was nice and clean, we liked the cherry blossom that appeared through our balcony. There was a very big variety of food, to all kind of tests.In the bathroom you can find all the toiletries you need , all from good duality. We liked our stay in this hotel.

The hotel has lovely public spaces, nice rooms, a number of restaurants and is short walk to the train station (2 blocks uphill). The air conditioning is not turned on so the rooms are hot even with the slider wide open. The water tastes like fish?
