Ideally located close to transport and restaurants. The hotel itself is large and well set out with a wide variety of restaurants and conference facilities. Longest corridors in a hotel that I have stayed in, kept fit just walking to the lifts.Service was exceptional and undertaken with sincerity.

Booked a king room non smoking (3 nights) but was given smoking king room when checked in at 5.30pm today. FO officer rejected request to change room for the next few nights during the check in process. We requested for an air purifier to be set up in room to clear the smoke smell, the FO officer said that there is already one set up in the room which there after when we got to our room there is none. Called housekeeping to furnish us the air purifier but was given an air purifier with dirty filter. The air coming out from it stinks the room even more with cigarette smell, called the house keeping again to change to another set of air purifier machine but was turn down with a reason that’s the last air purifier machine they have in the whole hotel. Its going to be uncomfortable sleeping in this room for the whole next 3 nights for non smokers like us.

The location is great and it’s redeeming feature, only short distance to walk or use the provided shuttle bus to Shinagawa station and then Tokyo city in 5 min. The lobby and gardens are beautiful and a great way to unwind. However the service is poor (tried to ring and get room changed as we were put in single beds, while told there was none available they were still advertising availability on there own websites and this was what the travel agent had booked even though it was the only hotel that had this, no towel one day, no air conditioning and polite but no answers). The air conditioner is set on heat and the room was hot and the only suggestion was open the window/door to the balcony, we are on the 3 floor and had the entrances to a convention centre and coach parking area was directly below so noisy both late and early. Not a holiday or what is expected in this ‘class of hotel’. There is only instant coffee in the rooms and all the amenities, restaurants and coffee shops are overpriced to the extent of being a ripoff (~USD$11/AUD$15 for a coffee and more for a beer, meals are the same, AUD$40 for a club sandwich and the same price to have 7 underclothes and 1 shirt washed and folded). Shop around there are better value for money options in the area. I do not recommend this hotel.

My wife and I visited for three days as part business vacation trip throughout Japan. The hotel is nicely upscale and located close to the Shinagawa Jr rail station, as well as a 5 min walk to takawanadaie subway stop for the asakusa line. The location is perfect in providing access to one of the most robust, clean, and efficient transportation systems in the world. My suggestion is to purchase the $ 900 yen day pass that gives unlimited access to both subway systems ( not Jr access) that allow you to access all parts of the city. Hotel service is impeccable and rooms are large with all amenities. The hotel has numerous restaurants and bars and food and drink is very good. As it is in hotel, cost is high, but there are numerous good restaurants and bars in immediate areas that are much more cost effective. There is a 7-11 on basement level that offers tons of items including food and beverages at low cost. As this was my first trip to Japan, I quickly realized 7-11s are a key establishment for all around needs - make good use of them. Although we only ate one meal at the hotel - Shimizu Japanese restaurant- the food was very good and we'll served. Cost is not cheap for hotel, but it was clear that hotel was packed. Overall a bit expensive, but a great experience.

The lobby is very luxurious but it always busy due to all the conferences that are held. The airport shuttle stops at this hotel and the hotel's shuttle bus can take you to Shinagawa station too. The location is really good and close to the station, the rooms are spacious and the balconies are small but it's not a downfall as we spent most of our time exploring Tokyo.

Currently staying here for business. Great rate for a room at approx USD 200 inclusive of taxes for king size. Room very clean but dated and furniture knicked/ scatched as are the doors. Where they get you however is on the food! Extremely overpriced restaurants/food and drinks. 22 USD for a mimosa for example. Buffet breakfast in the lower dining room also way over priced and not good quality of food USD 35 for basically an omelette, greasy bacon, couple cups of coffee and juice. Poor pastry selection. Buffet not kept clean. My table was not even set. Had to ask for coffee to be replenished. Service when could get it was nice however. Mentioned to the manager he apologized but couldn't care less. Also mentioned to the hotel manager, she apologized but couldn't care less. So...if you want a reasonable room in a nice hotel but want to pay overpriced charges for food stay here. That's where they "get you"!

Make sure you have the name of your hotel written in Japanese on a piece of paper so your taxi driver takes you to the right one. This particular one is beautiful with great restaurants and gift shops and a convenience store. The rooms are lovely.

The hotel is very convenience, it is near the train station. there are the shuttle bus form the hotel to train station and to the air port. The break fast is very good, the garden is very nice. the room is very comfortable.

I have stayed in this hotel on 2/16-17 and 2/21-23 during our Chinese Year New holiday. I have visited Tokyo almost 10 times and my stays in your hotel was the most unhappy experiences I ever had.When I checked in on 2/21, the staff at the front desk asked for credit card for deposit. I asked “if I pay cash now, why do you need my credit card? I had just checked in on 2/16 previously, and the staff didn’t ask me to give credit card for deposit. Both bookings were made online, no difference.” The staff replied “this is our policy”. After some argument, although your staff didn’t insist the credit card, our family felt very uncomfortable about their attitude. I have stayed in many of the hotels in Tokyo, and every time I was willing to pay cash at the front desk, none of the hotels asked for credit card for deposit. This was the first situation I met, and I was very shocked and disappointed.Secondly, when my parents searched restaurant for breakfast, they passed もみじ restaurant and asked one of the staffs where is the restaurant, a lady replied “wait a moment” and walked away. Only until a few minutes later, another male staff came over and indicated the direction. And when the male staff gave direction to my parents, the pervious lady just took a look of my parents and didn’t say anything.Third, the staff forgot to put clean towels in my parents’ room after cleaning the room and I had to call room service for towels. Again, this was my first time experienced your staff forgot to put clean towels in the roomLastly, during the winter time, there is only heat no air conditioning in the room. So the temperature in bedroom was very hot. Although I have opened the windows to let cold air came in, the room was still hot and hardly fall asleep at night. The amenities in the bed room and shower were kind of old.Overall speaking, I felt although this hotel is very big and have many facilities than other middle size business type hotel, the training for their staffs seems not enough. And I rarely felt the staffs were willing to help and their attitude was not very friendly. I have stayed in another big hotel in Daiba last year, and their service and attitude was much better than this hotel. And I feel their rooms and other facilities were more clean and new. With so many unhappy experiences this time, I don’t think I will stay in this hotel anymore when I visit Tokyo in the future.

This hotel is conveniently located near the Shinagawa station which allows direct train access from the Hareda Airport. Please note the walk from the Shinagawa station is approximately 10 minutes uphill to the hotel. The hotel room was nicely appointed and has a sliding door to a small balcony. However, you do not have have access to set your own room temperature. The room temperature was set at 26c and it became necessary to open the sliding door to cool the room down! Not something one would expect from a hotel at this level. There is a 7-Eleven located in the basement level which is handy to purchase snacks. Reception staff were polite but with limited English.

Room Size Normal, 1 double bed.Fridge Yes, pre-stocked with drinks but space for a few extras.Bathroom Tub & Shower combo.WIFI Easy, access code on TV screen when entering roomPower US standard only, good plug locations.AirCon Only heat or cool so needed to leave the window open to cool the room.Curtains Good light blocking but also cuts down air flow if you are trying to cool room.Noise Very quiet, window open so some city noise but not bad (12th floor).Lighting IntuitiveTea/Coffee YesBreakfast: Unlimited buffet downstairs is almost the same price as the upstairs restaurant but has more choice.Toiletries Extras; Hairbrush, Razor, Toothbrush.TV Mostly Japanese channels, BBC and CNBC sometimes dubbed.Safe Low down so difficult to access, but since it wasn't bolted to the shelf easy to move to the bed for loading/unloading!Staff Very friendly and polite (Japanese).Other Although an easy walk I think this is the only Prince hotel in the area you cannot see from Shinagawa station so check your directions if walking (hotel also has shuttle).Other 7-11 in basement offers variety of extras, snacks etc.Better value than the minibar.

The only 4-5star hotel in Japan that doesn't allow you to adjust temperature in room.During summer the room feels like 26 degrees CelsiusDuring winter the room feels like 28 degrees CelsiusHad to leave balcony door ope to sleep, even during winter with -3 degrees outside as the room is extremely hot and unable to sleep.Popular hotel with tour group and airline crew as they have no choice/unaware of hotel temperature problem.

We only stayed here one night, but we got a wonderful night's sleep and started off the morning with a breakfast buffet to remember. There was even a vitamin bar and sushi at this breakfast buffet. The airport had lost our luggage, but it was found and delivered to this lovely hotel just about an hour after we checked in. The staff couldn't have been kinder to us. I would rate this hotel above five stars!

What a lovely hotel with spacious rooms. There is a 7 Eleven convenience store located at the basement level of the hotel and closes at 11pm which we found very useful to access. The staff were polite and very efficient.Only a 5 minute walk to Shinagawa station, one of the shinkasen stops on the Kyoto/Osaka line.

Stayed here at the end of a tour for 4 days and nights. This has to be one of the best hotels (standard) out there! great food, fresh kimono for free (and to keep at the end of the stay) great food in the resaurants, clean, fresh, piano bar, central, near the tube, great staff and surpisingly quiet!! loved it! we all emptied the (well stocked), mini bars from our room ( as I said, we were on tour), and the hotel waved a blind eye... :-)

My family stayed for one night (2 x twin rooms) on our way to Osaka. Very easy to get to from Narita and easy walk from Shinagawa station. Lovely staff and the rooms were very comfortable and surprisingly spacious, would highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay again.

Ideal accommodation. Only 5 minutes walk to Shinagawa Station; so convenient for travelling the JR lines. The rooms are spacious and beautifully furnished; we had a triple shared room which the beds were quite big and there was still enough room for 4 luggages. The toiletries are of high quality and the room is immaculately clean. The 7-Eleven Convenient Store on the basement level is a positive factor for purchasing food and water as well as other essentials. I was extremely pleased with everything about this hotel. The staff were polite and friendly. If you want LUXURY, CONVENIENCE and SPACE, then you must come to this hotel. I will definitely recommend Grand Prince Hotel to anyone travelling to Tokyo.

Nice luxury business hotel near Shinagawa station (about 20mins walk). Nice grand lobby and bar. Nice breakfast area. a favorite among southeast asian tourists. Hotel has free shuttle service to JR Shinagawa station.

Second stay here and always an enjoyable stay with good sized rooms and a very comfortable large bed in a large room. The gardens are lovely though not at their best in December (last time I was here was late April and everything was starting to bloom. The American breakfast (yoghurt with fruit, toast/croissant, omelette, 1xbacon rasher and 2xsausages) was good and sets you up nicely for the day.

This is my first time to Japan and staying at this hotel really brought joy and comfort to explore Tokyo as this hotel only 5 mins away from train stations and also has spacious room which really pampering in Tokyo.Good breakfast choices from buffet, japanese or american. I like the Japanese menu very much.

this was booked by my tour company. it's very far from downtown Tokyo and no night life nearby. it costs a lot to take a taxi from shinjuku to here especially when u have luggage with u . my room was a bit run down and the bathroom very cramped. would not recommend this to fellow travellers

It is located at the west side of Shinagawa Station about 5 min. uphill walk. Since shuttle bus is available from the west gate of the station, no fears for carrying large luggage.Aquarium, iMAX theater, bowling park and lots of restaurants are closely located with this hotel. I made a reservation via different travel portal site for the Club room with a very good price.Club room attendants' services are excellent. You can check in/out at Club floor desk without any queue.Variety of alcohols and beverages with good appetizers were served at Club floor at the Cocktail service time starting 5pm until 9pm. No need to go outside for dinner. Breakfast was also very good. It was much more than continental breakfast including Japanese food. Exercise / training room is located at the 1st floor and Spa is also available in the connected hotel. Room was large enough but bath tub is a little bit shallow and old style.

Large modern hotel, vast public areas, very friendly staff and a comfortable room of a decent size (not always a given in Japan). Good choice of restaurants spread around the large site, offering good breakfast choices, and western and Japanese choices for lunch and dinner. The location is close to Shinagawa station - walkable, but there is a shuttle. The area is not particularly central, and there is not much to explore within walking distance, but it is pleasant enough - and quiet at night. You can earn vouchers by declining routine housekeeping services, which gives you some money off your bar bill or the small supermarket within the hotel!In all unexciting, but hard to fault.

Stayed at this hotel with family for 2 nights. It is close enough to the train station to walk or use the shuttle provided by the hotel. The lobby is nice and the staff was extremely friendly and helpful. They always went out of their way to help. Rooms were clean and comfortable. The price was a little expensive, but, I suppose being in Tokyo that's how it goes.

Our first visit to Japan and this Hotel was a great start. The room was very comfortable after some temperature adjustments. The American breakfast was really good and the location was pleasant. Had the bar been more enticing then I probably would have given a rating of 5 stars. Each to their own as they say?

The executive room was quite spacious with a lovely comfy big bed and all the facilities we required. Even at the beginning of October the weather was fairly mild and we were able to admire the view from the small balcony. The hotel was in a business district outside the centre of the city of Tokyo so there was not a lot of sightseeing around the hotel and it was away from the hustle and bustle of the nightlife, but the advantage for us was that it was quiet and close to the excellent underground system so very easy to get around. We caught the Narita Express train from the Airport to Shinagawa Station which took around 1hr 10mins and the hotel provides a shuttle service from the station up the hill to the hotel. Without cases it only takes 10 minutes to walk from the station. We would definitely stay there were we to visit Tokyo again in the future.

There are 4 prince hotel close by and it was confusing for the first time to find the right prince oneHotel is nice and bit far away from Shinagawa station if someone is coming with luggage but it’s within 800 meter and convenient if there are no luggageRoom is well stocked except no complimentary drinking water, but 7/11 is located in the basement and can buy one big bottleOnly one lift connects to room and if someone has walking problem then request for room close to the liftLimited bus service is available from hotel to Haneda Airport, do check in advance regarding timing Breakfast is served at 3 places, I just tried American and it’s niceStaff are Super friendly

Stayed for two nights in executive room....room was on 16th floor...it’s 5 minutes drive from shinagawa station...they run shuttle service , one mini bus that comes I think every 15mins...pl don’t try to walk to hotel from station if you have heavy luggage. The road is uphill about half a km and very tiring of one walks with luggage. Pl wait for shuttle or hire a taxi.the executive room is divided in two sections ..one is sitting area with sofas and tv ...other section has twin beds and also tv....one could see Tokyo tower from the balcony....breakfast they have options in three restaurants...also they have bus service for narita airport which takes one hr and 20 min to reach airport...better option than taking narita express from train station along with luggage...bus fare is 3100yen....nice hotel

Very friendly and helpful staff. Good location and nice atmosphere. The convention centre nicely located aside. Convenient transport from both airports with limousine bus at reasonable rates. Varaity of restaurants and good breakfast options. 7/11 convenient store at B3.

I liked the Grand Prince Hotel New Takenawa, where I stayed 4 nights including a typhoon that passed through Tokyo on the 22-23 October, 2017. I had a view over the city from the 15th floor. The room was comfortable and the staff very friendly and helpful. There are three different places for breakfast: a Japanese restaurant, a typical international buffet and a rather more refined lounge, where you can either take an 'American' or a 'Continental' breakfast. One night, we dined in the Chinese restaurant of the hotel, and were very satisfied with our meal. The place is not far from a big railway station, Shinagawa (though you would never guess it from the hotel itself, so access to downtown Tokyo is very easy. I took the JR line to Ueno, for example. I don't know about value for money, as my hosts paid for my stay.

the hotel staff is really nice and they went their way to correct the mistake that was made with our reservation. The hotel itself is really nice and has a couple of nice places to eat, but in the neighbourhood there are multiple good restaurants so we tested those. There is e free shuttle between the Shinagawa train station and the 3 prince hotels, which is great, it goed every 20 minutes, but walking is also a good option.The room we had was nice and big enough for us, but there was a bit of shortage in closet space and you can hear your neighbours from time to time. Every morning we got a local newspaper in english.

The hotel lobby looks very nice and gives a warm welcome to any guest checking in. However there are things to take into consideration before choosing this hotel. First, the hotel is a little far out from shinagawa station, but there is a free shuttle between the hotel and shinagawa station which stops running after 10pm. Secondly the rooms have an old smell to them and I assume it's the old carpet probably only vacuumed and not cleaned. Other than that basic rooms with a limited mini-bar with only beer and water. Thirdly, the lounge on the reception floor is cloudy but quite overpriced for it's limited beer offering and bland food.But if you find these points not a problem you will have a great stay in Tokyo.

Some of the negative reviews below I can't believe it is the same hotel! We thoroughly enjoyed our stay, the room was a great size with table and chairs, bathroom was clean and not the smallest we have ever had. We were on the 8th floor and it was lovely to look out the window over the greenery below. Our breakfast was more than adequate with lots of choices both western and asian. It was a short walk from the station and in fact we walked to a lot of places. Would definitely stay here again without hesitation. We even had to get a document printed off and they were so accommodating and did it without hesitation and with a smile. Service from everyone was fantastic.

The best part of this hotel is the lobby and the fact that it had 7-eleven store in the basement. After that every part of experience is underwhelming. Rooms are cramped, old, cheap looking and not very well maintained, while bathroom is pittyful. Outside garden pool was very dirty and not maintained. Fitness center is literally two treadmills, two bikes and 4 mats. Bar is a huge room without any windows. Breakfast is $3400 yen with a very slow service. Tour operators must love this place as tourists come in busloads creating frequent service jams. And dont even think about asking for late checkout, they will charge you $5400 yen. There are much better options for all kind of trevelers in Tokyo, i would avoid at all costs.

Wasn't sure where to stay in Tokyo and was recommended this hotel, glad we booked it! Nice room on the 15th floor (16 is the top floor) overlooking the Tokyo Tower. Room is a King Superior and its spacious. It's a big hotel and seems to be popular for conferences. Staff were friendly and accommodating. About a 5 minute walk to Shinagawa train station. Some reviews have commented about walking up the 'hill' from the station to the hotel...it's not really that big. But if walking it isn't your thing, the hotel offers a free shuttle 3X/hour between the station and hotel (contact hotel for current pick up/drop off times...especially if you are arriving with luggage).

This hotel is my favourite among the few that I've tried around Shinagawa. It might be a bit more pricey but it's worth it. The lobby and overall hotel appearance is stylish and very generous, considering the cost of square foot in the area. There is a 7-11 convenience store in the hotel open to 1am which is very convenient. Internet access is included in the room price and works well, both wireless and wired (ethernet cable is provided in the room). The bathrooms are nice, with a relatively large bathtub and many amenities. There is a water cooker pot, iron, large HDMI capable LCD TV. Quite nice is the small garden next to the hotel.It's no more than 5 minutes walk to the Shinagawa train station.
user_name:
C0rnh0li0
Kuncice pod Ondrejnikem, Czech Republic

review_body: This hotel was booked by our travel agent. The check in could have been smoother. We found the common areas nice, but the room is Way too small. Bathroom is very small - and the rooms don't feel "new". they are better described as tired and not as clean as i like. The bed was NOT comfortable. The hotel is a short walk to the JR line so easy reach of trains. Breakfast was included - but they need to learn how to cook eggs and meat - the eggs were really runny - and the bacon did not look cooked. i could not eat it.

Great hotel, super close to Shinagawa station for the bullet train and Yamamoto line. Small but nice rooms, good breakfast and a nice onsite public bath. The gardens are very nice too and breakfast has both western and Japanese options. Staff were very helpful and accommodating and spoke good English.

Visited the Grand Prince Hotel Tanagawa grand banquet hall on a closing dinner of a conference during September. The banquet hall is a independent building which has a curve roof. The roof and the walls are filled with gold paints and artful details. The ceiling is 10~12 meters high enough for a grand feel. The servers are attentive, caring and professional. Food is normal you can expect of a large scale banquet function. We were transported by coaches and I noticed the Sinagawa underground is a 5 minutes walk away from the hotel.

I stayed in the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa for three nights and it was my third visit.The Hotel is what I’m expecting and the rooms are quite big for Tokyo. I can recommend this hotel for business trips especially because of the location:Close to Shinagawa station and many restaurants in this area.

My first time in Japan, first hotel in Japan and I am already in Love!Beautiful hotel, amazing attention, care and Love from all staff, amenities and and facilities AAA+.Will be back in spring.Thank you Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa.

The most frustrating thing about staying here was the lack of English spoken by staff- especially by the room service telephonist and the Concierge, who will claim to understand a request and then completely fail to act on it (even for a different pillow). Executive Lounge- a small place, with slow service that closes early (2100). The staff appear shy about approaching that appear to not be Japanese speakers. The food in the lounge is cold and small in range. The early closing forces guests to go to the main bar, which very expensive. Facilities- the Spa facilities are based next door at the sister-hotel, the Prince Sakura hotel and only the first visit is free. In fairness, the business meeting facilities are excellent!Location- a five up-hill walk from Shinagawa Train station, with lots of nice restaurants in the area. There is a pharmacy and a convenience store in the area, so no need to pay the minibar prices. Rooms- a nice size with great views on the higher floors. The decor was a little dated in places.Again, in fairness, once issues were pointed out, hotel staff tried to rectify them.

Best hotel in Shinagawa. Easy walk from the station. Plenty of dining options in and around the hotel. Staff is friendly and helpful. Lobby and rooms recently renovated. Quiet and comfortable. Hotel garden is beautiful. Also, take the time to walk to Happo-en garden about 20 minutes away.

This is located very near to a railway station. It has excellent rooms which have ALL the required amenities and facilities. It has meeting rooms et all. Food was excellent. a completely satisfying and enriching experience awaits you at this hotel. Wi fi facility is very fast and efficient.

Fantastic staff and a great visit to a good hotel.After being in Japan for a month on business I had a week here in Tokyo to have a look at the city.The hotel arranged boat tours and bus tours for me.I went up the tower and saw all of the sites such as world trade centre etc.Thoroughly enjoyed myself here.

Our motorcycle club, visiting Japan, was booked here same time two years ago. They were great to us then, and did it again for us this year. Good, easy-going service. Comfortably, good-sized rooms. Close to railway station and cafes and restaurants. I have no hesitation in recommending this hotel.

The location is great. Walking distance from a lot of restaurant, bars and train station. Rooms are very basic and small but that's the case with most average to above average Japanese hotels. Gym is very basic with no weights. Big lobby, first time getting to the room can be confusing. Great staff though.
user_name:
vprasad1468
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed here 6 nights. My room was one of the superior ones and was really spacious. Sometimes they'd even leave newspapers on the bed, that I obviously couldn't read. The toilets are fitted with that technologically advanced toilet seat which I'd never seen until I got there. The hotel is located very close to Shiganawa station (10 min walk or less, just literally down this small hill) which is very useful if you need to travel by Shinkansen. The superior rooms have balconies from which you'll get a beautiful view of the skyscrapers, especially at night. The hotel is surrounded by a nice Japanese garden and the rooms are usually quiet. I'd definitely stay here again.

The rooms are okayThe bathroom clogged once and they sent someone to clear it upThe key card stopped working every day and had to get a new oneThe staff was helpfulThe train station is only 6 - 8 minutes away - it is walking an uphill when going back to the hotel

We had booked a room with outside pool access via the hotel´s web page for myself, my wife and our 16 year old son. At checkin we were told they needed to change our room, as it was for 2 persons only. Appearently a child means no more than 6 years old at this hotel, but this was not marked so at the booking site. The upgrade would cost us another 15000 yen for 4 nights on top of an already expensive room price. The reception manager took no responsibility for the misunderstanding, he showed no ability to resolve the challenge suggesting a reasonable deal to us and we ended up cancelling. We felt misled and that we had waisted both time and money. We are very disappointed with the service and they way we were handled as new customers.

Service was not bad but there is room for improvement. Rooms were clean although slightly antiquated for my taste. Decent sized room considering this is Japan. Convenient location except for the walk up the hill from the station. Cost wise is a good value for families however for solo or couples, I recommend picking a hotel with a better location.

took 25 min for us 6 to check in; the groul was keen to visit places, what unnecessary delay; took 2 persons to help us check in, feels like the first time they are dling this. What adds to this it the main entrance taxi experience - basically refused to hail us taxi n asked us to go to the taxi stand. when asked if she can help tell the taxi driver where we want to get to, she gave us a discontempt look

The hotel has scheduled shuttle buses to take you to the nearest station, which is Shinagawa. But even if you miss it, it's only less than 10min walk away. Just a couple of steep slopes to handle, and from Shinagawa, it's only a few stops to the touristy places of Tokyo. All in all, a convenient location with a pretty lobby. Rooms are okay, pillows were a bit flat and uncomfortable. The water pressure from the shower was good. Staff were friendly as well.

Stayed in this hotel for 3 nights because of a busines trip and really enjoyed it. Rooms were clean, with all amenities (bathrobe, slippers, hair dryer, iron, coffee machine, etc) and bed and pillows super comfy!- Wifi is free and works really well. Breakfast was included in my package (you can pick different options, I went for the traditional one and did not regret it). Staff was nice and attentive. Really enjoy my stay.

I have stayed at 3 different hotels in the Minato, Shinagawa area multiple times: Prince Hotel, Grand Prince New Takanawa, and Grand Prince Takanawa. Location: All three are within walking distance to shops/restaurants and the Shinagawa Station for convenient access to metro lines and trains. Prince Hotel is the closest to the station (just across the street) and shops and restaurants (literally at the door). You have to walk uphill for 5 - 10 minutes to the other 2 hotels from the station and shopping/restaurant area. But the environments there are quieter, particularly the Grand Prince Takanawa, which also has a very nice Japanese garden right behind it. Rooms: Prince hotel has by far the smallest rooms. Grand Prince Takanawa has the most spacious and comfortable rooms. Services: Services at all three hotels are professional and efficient. Services at Grand Prince Takanawa are the most attentive of the 3. Overall, I would recommend the Grand Prince Takanawa if you do not mind good walking exercises up and down the hill, and the Prince Hotel if you do not want to walk that much.

I spent 3 nights at this hotel during my business trip in Tokyo. The most advantage for this hotel is only the location where it is only 5 mins away from Shinagawa stationWhile the room is OK but no WOW factor at all, however couple of downside:- Only Twin room is available even make booking in advance- No free bottle of water provided during the stay- Very loud noise from other Japanese guest when they completely get drunk and came back to the hotel very late night! I need to call to reception 3 times to complain! - If you are non-Japanese frequent traveller, this hotel doesn't belong to any chain so no point accumulation availableIf there is other option available, I would prefer another hotel which there is couple around this area.

I was surprised to read reviews here which criticised the location of this hotel and the room. I thought the hotel's location was excellent - a short walk down about one block to Shinagawa Station - certainly not an arduous climb up or down. This is a large hotel and my husband and I found all the employees helpful, friendly and very efficient in the way of most Japanese staff.There is a conference centre attached and conferences being conducted each day of our stay, but this did not interfere with our stay in any way. We enjoyed our breakfast buffet each morning and the experience of their Shimizu Japanese Restaurant. Being close to Shinagawa Station had several advantages, firstly there is a wonderful variety of restaurants within close proximity and secondly, this is one of the few stations in Tokyo where you can catch the Shinkanzen as well as other trains. Using the Japanese rail system is very user friendly especially if you do a little research online before you go. People will offer to help if they see you struggling to understand the ticket machines and there is a Ticket Office at this station for further assistance. The hotel room was comfortable and clean with all amenities required whilst travelling. This hotel suited us perfectly for our 3 night stay.

Nice as business hotel. Say 3-4 star. All facilities are available. The walk is but far and uphill from Shinagawa station so be prepared. Also there are 3 Prince hotel in the vicinity. No complaints but depends on what you need.

I travel to Tokyo almost every year for summer vacation and this is the first time I stay here. The stay is definitely below my expectations and disappointed compared to other hotels that I stayed before. Start from the check in, we arrived an hour earlier than the check in time, I was just told to go away until the check in time. I understand it's earlier, however staff was not even try to check if there's any room ready or go thru the check in paper work first to save time later. This is what other hotels did normally and I do appreciate those. The room is dated and doesn't feel clean. The bed is comfortable though. The best thing about this hotel is its location, short walk from Shinagawa station and surrounded with shops and restaurants. Anyway I don't think I will return.

Very good hotel. Modern clean and big. Reception staff very helpful and helped us with maps and directions. Breakfast very good with good selection of food. Walking distance to train station and shops. Nice gardens. Breakfast very good. Rooms comfortable with free if I. Highly recommend hotel.

We were part of a bus tour in Japan and were booked into this hotel. It was a pricey hotel by our standards at A$239 per night so we felt quite lucky having the opportunity to stay there. The hotel very spacious with a number of restaurants and bars within. The rooms were very comfortable and we enjoyed our stay there. The breakfast provided was excellent with a very good variety of western and Japanese food. It was close to many shops and a short walk to the railway station which proved an ideal way to get around the city.

Stayed in a club room so breakfast was included. Room spacious, air conditioner worked ok would have liked it a little cooler. The only thing we wanted was an extra towel as they only have 2 for 2 people. Asked for additional towel but each time they cleaned the extra towel disappeared. Nice soaps and shampoos. Breakfast was nice variety for Japaneese, Europeans, Americans. The scrambled eggs are on the runny side but had good flavor. Hotel was up a hill but very convenient to train station, shopping, and dinning. Behind the hotel is a lovely garden that is tranquil and relaxing.

I spend 2 nights in the old wing of the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa which is much more quiet the the new wing with much less people walking around. So the atmosphere is more relaxing.The service is very good, employees are very helpful and the rooms are big enough to feel comfortable. Everything you need is available on the room or reception. We had a chance to had breakfast in the lounge, which offers a nice buffet and is relaxing for the first morning coffee. Between the 2 wings you can find a Japanese garden with a nich small lake in the middle. For spring time it is a bountiful location.From the Hotel to the Shinagawa Station it is just 200m and you have many restaurants, bars, coffees and shops between.When you arrive by train, take care to identify the correct of the 5 Prince Hotels you can see

The rooms are very pleasant, the location is good, just a short walk from Shinagawa station. The staff smile and bow but true service is missing. We had an early arrival 6am and on being told this the receptionist said "when will you be back?". There was no suggestion for what to do while we were waiting (which ended up at 7 hours). We asked about breakfast but were told that the breakfast didn't open until 7am. Much later we discovered that the Japanese breakfast actually opened at 6.30. The café and restaurants don't have an alternative to milk not soy or almond. Strange in a country like Japan that consumes so much soy.A bowl of chips was impossible even though people were served chips as part of their meals. I ordered a meal that didn't have chips and asked for an extra bowl of chips which I was happy to pay for. But no a separate bowl of chips was not allowed. However they served us an extra bowl of tempura vegetables at no cost - go figure.

Good overnight stay near the station. Quiet hotel and we had an upper level club floor room. Don't bother with the "snacks" for club lounge members as there's pretty much nothing there! Breakfast was good in the club lounge though. Nice and quiet and plenty of food to choose from.Easy walk down the hill to the station and shops/restaurants. Literally out the front of the hotel and turn left!Room was nice with big bed and decently furnished. Was good value in Tokyo, the city of small rooms.

In our previous trips to Tokyo, we usually stay at the Prince chain of hotels at Shinagawa because the Narita Express stops there. This time we decided to stay at the Grand Prince Takanawa for two nights as we had stayed at the other three before.The lobby was huge and impressive. Service at front desk and concierge was good. The garden at the back was very nice with the sakura trees blossoming. There was also a free shuttle service to Shinagawa Station. But the room was a different story. It looked very dated and the furniture certainly needed to be replaced some time ago. The bathroom was equally disappointing - even the bath tub and toilet bowl looked very used. This would be acceptable if the room rate was cheaper . We would not be staying at the Prince hotels in Shinagawa in future.

This is a pleasing property, very neat and clean. The rooms are large and well kept with all conveniences. One can choose from rooms that cater for two, three or four persons.They have a Chinese and Japanese restaurant, as well as a cosy and relaxing lounge. There is a7/11 convenience store at the lower level, which is great! The staff are extremely helpful at all times.The only, somewhat problematic issue, I felt was the breakfast service for travel groups that could be vastly improved upon. The breakfast area below is limited and any given point one has to line up and wait , some times for pretty long, in a narrow passage waiting to be seated. The breakfast spread too could be better.The hotel is walking distance from the Shinagawa train station. The area around the station has a host of eateries and shops. The station itself has innumerable places to pick up a bite or just window shop.

Service was very nice. A lot of friendly staff to attend to you. Many spoke very good English. The rooms were clean and very nice. It is close to the Shinagawa train station so is very convenient. They have a shuttle from the station or it is a short walk. 7/11 is downstairs so was great for coffee in the morning.

After a long day of sightseeing, I was happy to see the room was spacious, clean, free wifi, and had excellent views of the city. It afforded a good rest and good breakfast in the morning, though I was happy to have chosen to have an early breakfast as there was a long line waiting when I finished.
user_name:
clairmontjeff
Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam

review_body: So the location was the primary reason for picking this hotel, convent and easy walk from train station. It is rather large and interconnected with about 3 or 4 other hotels, encompassing a convention center. Overall the hotel was clean, upscale, and nice. My issue was the room. It was nice enough and quite roomy but The point of a hotel is a comfortable room and good nights rest. First the temperature, while digital based control didn't seem to work right. After sweating to 77F temp the first night I found if I set the temp to like 63 it got to around 73. But really, how hard is it to calibrate these things. Second was the bed. It felt comfortable to begin with but it sank at the ends, had there been 2, it would have not been good. And after the second night I woke the next morning with a backache. So the two negatives bring a 4 star down to a 3

We really enojoy our 2nights stay at this hotel.Room is spacious and relaxing.Very clean and modern.Accessible to the train station withFree shuttle service.Buffet breakfast is excellent.love the foods.Staff are helpful and amazing.Highly recommended.

1. Just 2 night in Tokyo. This time staying at Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa.2. Hotel located about 90min bus ride from from Narita Airport & about 30min from Haneda Airport. Abandon of transport facilities nearby including train station (walking distance)3. Hotel room is decent in size with all the modern features & facilities. The room allocated to me facing the garden & wow so beautiful with Sakura Flowers still blossom.4. Room service menu is 24hr & reasonable in price. Restaurant nearby (walking distance) so abandon. Hotel have great restaurant but in did not dine any. Strolling around for local fish & food. Craving for street stall & vendor for good Unagi & Tampura. Enjoy every minute of it.5. Hotel staff, wow excellent & with all the Japanese traditional & Hospitality. Well done & kudos to all. 6. Lobby was crowded with guests during checkin, peak period, a lot of visitors all over the world.7. Hope to be here again.

Selected this hotel as I used to stay here as kid on family vacations. Booked two rooms and both were dirty (you could see dust on the carpet at the corners).I had specifically booked (3 weeks in advance) for non-smoking rooms but after check in found that I had been given the rooms on smoking floor. Hotel was fully booked so they were unable to give me non-smoking rooms. The linen was also stinking of smoke. Moreover the lift lobby is bang in the middle of the walkway to the convention hall so as soon as you come out of the lift you are in the middle of a very busy corridor and lobby.Whilst it was cold and the pool closed, the management couldn't be bothered to clean the pool (lots of leaves and dirt) or at least drain it.Had an uncomfortable stay to say the least.In room dining menu is very limited. Some upsides include big rooms, a nice Japanese garden and proximity to Shinagawa station and Haneda airport.

Stayed with my family (including our gorgeous shitzu dog) for one night, The experience was great~ The room had more than enough space for us to open our luggage and let our dog play, They prepared some training sheet with wet tissue, cage and some necessary equipment, surprisingly we even can order some room service meal for dogs! Not sting smell at all (they put air purifier but I believe without that still no smell) in the room. Also have exit only for customers with doggies, we can go for walk anytime as we like! Quite disappointed the International to channel was in Japanese and we couldn't change to English, But still in this location and we can stay with your fur-mily member in this price... Here will be absolutely one of the highest priority for you. (Don't forget to prepare certificate for their requirement!)

Nice bedrooms! Excellent location and very good food! The only down was the waiting time for breakfast as it seems they were understaffed because there were empty tables that needed cleaning... We waited half an hour before we could be seated...

Sakura time and you saw verdant foliage and think cherry blossoms as you walked around the hotel from within. It was a rainy three-day trip so the inside view and the balcony in the room were the best ways to enjoy it. That the hotel was right in the middle of a cherry blossom tour/ pathway was a big plus.Wide and spacious lobby and meeting spaces were just the thing for me. A convenience store at the ground floor, an efficient business center, cab and exchange machines, shops and the Shinagawa station a brisk walk away made it the perfect accommodation for a very hectic visit. Breakfast served at the restaurants were tasty and plentiful. Service, as in most of Japan, was unobtrusive. Room was well appointed and amenities were more than sufficient. Hotel was not cheap but you got what you paid for.Would love to check this hotel out again in the fall that's colorful and in winter that is snowy white.

For the price I was paying, I was really not impressed. AC only works during the summer despite it being rather hot in my room when I went during the spring (77 degrees F). When I ordered a pizza and called the reception desk to let them know, they told me that the delivery guy would not be allowed into the hotel and they were not allowed to let me know when he arrived, so I had to go stand outside the hotel and wait for him. How ridiculous is that?The hotel is in walking distance to a major train station, so that is a plus, but I imagine almost all hotels are. The other hotels I stayed at were much closer to train stations.

I have experienced some of the very best customer service anywhere at stays in Japan, but the team at the Grand Prince did not deliver and this made the stay a disappointment. This is an updated large hotel and is conveniently located near the station (although it can be a challenging 8 minute uphill hike with your luggage). The staff from the start was simply unfriendly and unhelpful. Poor start began when they tried to put me in a smoking room - I told them this was unacceptable and they stated that there were no non-smoking rooms available. Then explained that they have cleaned the room so that it likely won't smell that bad, again unacceptable. I had to do this dance 4-5 times before they finally assigned a non-smoking room. Later on in the stay I felt other staff members were dismissive and somewhat rude, rather than be helpful for questions on directions, buying postage, etc. This is not what I expect from a prominent Japanese hotel and I am hopeful that this was simply a poor experience for me and not others.

The hotel is nice however a little worn down (specially the bathroom), rooms are more spacious than elsewhere in Tokyo. Good location, close to Shinagawa station and free shuttle bus is provided. However its a group hotel, meaning they are not too much inclined to accommodate individual client's wishes. Example: our flight was pushed back and we asked for a 2 hours later checkout. Answer: possible but at ¥1.800 plus per hour. And the breakfast prices are steep at ¥3000 per person.

Stayed for work. The hotel is just too big, which is exactly what I dislike. The location is not great and the rooms are very basic. No iron, no complimentary drinking water, the bathroom is very old and tired. The shower is not at all inviting. The only positive note was the breakfast in the western restaurant on the ground floor opposite Reception. Sakura season is absolute madness in Tokyo. The hotel rooms are way over priced and availability very low. I didn't enjoy my stay here and will not stay here again.

Very clean and new hotel, staff are friendly and happy to assist with any issues. Located close to the Shingawa train station for easy access around Tokyo. Only issue was the waiting times to be seated for breakfast, otherwise a very pleasant stay.

A very large hotel with not much storage space . 2 small drawers for 2 people....we just kept clothes in our suitcases. Dining is expensive , but there are restaurants just down the hill . They charge for the bottled water in the room , but we found that the tap water was good..... so we never bought their water.

This hotel is supposed to have air conditioning but they only put it on when they think it is warm enough. They told me to open the one window since it is 60 degrees outside. I did but now I hear all the drums and talking in the courtyard. I want to move but all the hotels in this area are fully booked. Poor way to run a hotel. Never stay here again especially for almost 300 a day. Also, very strict with later check out even though I am a prince member. They charge $18 per hour past 11 am.Location is good but it's a 10 minute walk uphill from station. There is a shuttle bus but I didn't see it in 3 days. Front desk staff not overly pleasant. Better to stay at hotel goos if available.

Room is spaciousThe Japanese restuarent in the hotel is expensive for what youThe English translating system on the TVs is next to uselessIf you want English best learn japaneseThe buffet breakfast is good

Recently stayed here for 3 nights as part of a group. I found the room to be spacious, clean and comfortable. The location of the property is excellent with only a short walk to Shinagawa rail station, although the walk back up the hill at the end of the day or with luggage can be a challenge for some.The buffet breakfast was served in the basement level and was Ok without being great. There is also a la carte breakfast available opposite reception. The 7eleven (handy-mart) located within the hotel has an excellent selection of quick meals, drinks and essentials.The hotel is quite large and felt it lacked a bit of personal service, but in saying that I wouldn't hesitate in recommending this hotel and would stay here again.

Usually Tokyo's hotel rooms are very small, but here is quite big.Room condition was very good, balcony was great. we enjoy staing here.It's not far from shinagawa station, also they run shuttle bus. it ver easy to access.There are three Prince group's hotel there. Middle of three hotels, they have a Japanese graden. it was nice. also have little pond. If you walk the garden. It will be relaxing time.

Our room was quite large and clean and there was two easy chairs and comfortable beds. Every rooms has own balconies.The hotel location was good, just 5-10 minutes walk to Shinagawa station (Up/Down hill). Breakfast on the ground floor (B3) was good, lot of choices and both European and Japanese style. 7/Eleven convenient store was in the hotel (B1) and In the hotel you can also find nice Japanese garden. The staff were helpful.

The buffet breakfast room is yoo small and people need to wait in line. They have also 2 other restaurants but not buffet version. There wad not so many people in those restaurants.The price was very high compare to facilities. Even cooling cannot be on because it is winter time :)

Our room was very comfortable. King size bed with an excellent mattress. The hotel location is very convenient - being 5 minutes from Shinagawa railway station. We were there to see the cheery blossoms blooming in the beautiful extensive gardens with lots of water features and old relics tastefully displayed. We loved the food and the bar. The staff were excellent, very helpful with a lot of English speaking members of staff which helped a lot. The buffet breakfast was amazing, so many differently foods on offer!! When we go back to Japan we would definitely consider staying here again.

We stayed here in March 2017. The hotel is wonderful. The location is just up the street from the busy Shinagawa station, were in addition to trains, a lot of shops and great restaurants can be found. The breakfast buffet is great and was included with our hotel package. The room size is adequate and the bathroom is up to Japan tech standards. As indicated, the location is great with the train station serving as your launching pad to stops all over the city.

We stayed at this hotel for 2 nights very impressed, great location next to rail station, free Wi Fi , Large rooms with room for luggage (2 bags) great breakfast in the hotel restaurant, service was very good , you are able to open the sliding door to the balcony for fresh air , also close to restaurant out in the street

We stayed in this hotel for 10 days. It 10 minutes uphill walk but there is a shuttle van service every 20 minutes. The room is small but clean. Bath room lighting is a little dark. They provide 500 yen refund if you skip room cleaning.

Being my first time in Japan on business, I did not have much to go on in terms of hotel recommendations and instead relied on locations where my company had negotiated a preferred rate. I picked this hotel as it was the first to come up in the list and had a pretty decent nightly rate. It also seemed fairly close to Shinagawa train station which was good.Upon arrival after a long trip on the train from Narita airport I exited the station and proceeded to walk up the street to where the hotel entrance was. What seemed like a short distance walk on the map, was in fact over 500m up a hill. So while it was close to the station, it wasn't close enough to make it convenient to walk to with luggage in tow.The hotel itself appeared new and had lavish decor well suited for wedding banquets and corporate functions. It also offered plenty of onsite restaurant options, but most were quite expensive. There is an onsite convenience store however which was nice to see.Staff are very friendly and speak pretty fluent english. The one huge disappointment for me was that I had booked a non-smoking room and at checkin they offered me a smoking room. I immediately corrected them saying I needed NON smoking, but was told there were no non-smoking rooms left. Seriously??! Not even one? The hotel didn't appear that full... All I was given was a half-hearted apology and no option but to check into a room on a smoking floor. Needless to say the room stunk of stale smoke and felt dingy and dirty right from the start. I did not realize until the next morning that there was a balcony to the room and that the door to it could be opened to let in some fresh air. But it was cold that night and I'm not sure I would have wanted to sleep with the door open anyway.At check-in there was also no option given for an included breakfast so I don't even know if one is offered. But I had a very expensive american-style breakfast in the main floor lounge. A very small portion of plain omelet, 1 sausage link, a small piece of bacon, toast, very watery coffee, and a tiny glass of juice for the equivalent of $40. Not good value, and not even a Japanese breakfast option...Overall this hotel was just average for me. Nice enough in decor and service, but not being able to hold down a non-smoking room really turned me off and the expensive food options on site were also a minus. While the rooms are smaller, the Shinagawa Prince Hotel right across from the station is a much better value.

Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa TokyoI visited Japan in November 2016 and my stay was at Tokyo, Osaka and Hiroshima. In Tokyo, I stayed at Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa and it was a pleasant experience. Everything in hotel was as per ‘Japanese Standard’ right from light and room temperature controls to high tech toilets.The hotel rooms are spacious with nice interiors and great view of bustling Tokyo city (I got view of Tokyo Tower check below photo).The hotel is attached with various multi cuisine restaurants and many other facilities (which I could not enjoyed actually due to tight schedule of Tokyo sightseeing) The location of the hotel is 10-15 minutes walk from Shinagawa metro station, from where you can easily go to other famous districts of Tokyo like Shibuya, Ginza etc. and also connect to Shinkansen (bullet train) for travel to far places.Highly recommended hotel for a stay in Tokyo.

Room was excellent! Very clean and view of Tokyo was panorama! Service was A+. Probably the best hotel in the area! Close to Shinagawa Rail Station.Price was well worth it!I booked only 2 days, then stayed at Ginza. Should have booked all days at Grand Prince New New Takanawa.

My wife accompanied my on a recent business trip. Was told by local meeting group that I would have a king room. Given a room with 2 twin beds. I complained, meeting planner complained, and local contact person also complained on my behalf. We were all told that no king room was available. While eating dinner at the hotel, just 3 hours after check in, a King room was miraculously found. It was a bit nicer than the previous twin room, but overall rugs in room,and hallway are in need of heavy cleaning. My wife was not impressed at all. Coverlet on end of bed look like it needed to be washed, the cushion on the vanity chair was ripped, and the single armless chair in the room also looked rundown.The walls were pretty scuffed up too. The linens on the bed, and the towels and bathroom were clean. Room was extremely warm, despite turning off the heat. Had to open sliding glass door and sleep with door open just to get some relief. Did not sleep well because of the uncontrollable heat. I advise using the re useable slippers provided in the closet and not to put your feet on the carpet. Both pools were uncovered, dirty, and not available to use in February. Not much of a fitness room so did not bother. No spa. Located near a small mall and some local and chain restaurants. Large Train station at bottom of hill. Cab ride to heart of city for shopping and dining was approx. $25 US/one way. Staff was efficient and extremely polite.Charged an extra $75/day for my wife to accompany me. Not informed of this until check in! Also given a hard time about late check out (meeting not finished until after lunch). Hotel wanted to charge for another full day to check out at 2 pm instead of of 11am. Of note, check out at 11 am was a mad house, so go early!!! Breakfast was included ( but not $75 worth!) and was ok, with no lines or waiting in lobby or at buffet in basement. Two restaurants were closed for revamping so options in hotel were very limited. Would not stay there again and will let local meeting planner know not to book it for future meetings.

Not far from the main station of Shinagawa where most of the trains connection are. The hotel is modern yet also have some Japanese design into it. Specious room for Tokyo standard. The hotel promote sustainability where you could choose 1day to skip the Housekeeping service in exchange for cash to redeem in restaurant of convenience store.

I stayed in this hotel for six nights on business trip. Room was spacious and clean. Convenient location to other parts of Tokyo. Its about five minutes uphill walk from Shinagawa station. There is hotel shuttle service but not sure the pick up points as it is not shown on their web site. There is a convenient store at the hotel, could buy food and drinks and daily needs. Breakfast was good. Many restaurants nearby the hotel. There is also a supermarket at Shinagawa station. I was satisfy with the service.

Very confortable hotel with huge space. Good location nearby Takanawa Station. Good choice for business trips or vacation. Rooms are clean and lights. Breakfast is unclude traditional and european meals.

The first room allotted was 2350, which had live cockroaches in the room. Called up the reception and my room was changed to 3315 which was kind of ok. Personally I prefer wooden and / or tiled flooring to carpets as it looks and feels much cleaner. Not sure how frequently are the floor carpets cleaned in the hotel. The breakfast at the Momoji near the lobby was quite measured in quantity. Just enough for one person. Overall a pretty average experience.

Third stay at this hotel, last time was over two years ago. Checked in to find the hotel had been recently been refurbished, a added bonus! Great room, efficient, polite and helpful staff.Nice gardens to walk around, chill out in and relax.Shinagwa Station is just a few minutes walk away.All in all excellent hotel in a good location of Tokyo.

Great location. Just walk for 15mins to Shinagawa MRT (walking to hotel is a bit tiring tho because the road is inclined.) B1 has 7-11 and should buy 2L water there because it is cheaper there than at NewsDay @ station.Great stay because the room is spacious enough and so does the shower and toilet. The beds were comfy. Different range of toiletries provided. Clean and quiet with a cute balcony. Tip: ask for a high-floor room facing Tokyo Tower. For breakfast, there are 3 options. Better choose for Japanese breakfast option because the other two were disappointing and not worth ¥3000.Overall, a great stay there despite a bit overpriced room and breakfast rates. Keep up the good work!

The first day I stayed a room behind the elevator and the noise kept all night. I could not stand it the 2nd day thus called the front desk to change the room. The service was quick to change a room even at the midnight. The breakfast was poor with egg and breads only. In general the service and the environment were awesome.

I had a great time there. Perfect Service and Great Quality. The breakfast offering is very good. Very good Restaurants for Dinner close to the Hotel. I had excellent three days there. Very close to downtown via shinagawa station.

We stayed for 4 nights in a "quad room" at this hotel. We thought it was a lovely hotel and could not fault the staff, cleanliness or rooms. I know others have commented that the rooms are a bit small for 4 people, however while it was cozy, there was room for all our luggage and we did not find it too cramped (and we are two adults and 2 teens). I have stayed in much smaller "quad rooms' in Europe. The bathrooms, while not as recently updated at the rest of the hotel were perfectly fine. The only reason we would not stay here again is because of the location. It is very close to Shinagawa station, which is one of the busiest stations in Tokyo which was a plus, but we found very few affordable restaurants nearby. We had to travel to other areas of Tokyo to find reasonably priced food and on those evenings when we exhausted after a days sightseeing often resorted to convenience store food for dinner in our room. 5* for the hotel, but only 3* for location (for tourists).

We book as a family of 4 and we got a room that looks like a room for two with added 2 fold out beds. The room was very small with no room for 4 luggage. Some other hotel gave us a room with 2 bathrooms in conparison to one in Grand Prince. The shower curtain sticks and does not work well.

I stayed here one week for business and there's not a single thing I can complain of. Clean, quiet, great service, charming. Try the Japanese breakfast in the room.There is also a Japanese garden where you can go for a walk, a convenience store and a small gym.

The room are niceMomiji resturant has a nice location but service is bad - morning 20 min to get a coffea with people undertsranding nothing - only customer , a lady start to pay piano, you ask if possible to stop they tell you not possible => We had to leave because of jetlag I wanted to be in peace

The hotel was great overall; the room was fairly large for Japanese standards. It was also fairly clean though it did feel somewhat dated and soon in need of renovations across its amenities and styling. Having said that, it is the hotel's location that makes it an absolute winner. Only 5 minutes walk from Shinagawa station, navigating to the city as well as the airport was extremely convenient and straight forward.

I selected this hotel for a few reasons: the Airport Friendly Limousine has a direct stop here from Narita Airport, they actually have a King Size bed for the 4 of us (2 adults+2 toddlers), and it's close proximity (a 5 minute walk or there is a free shuttle) to Shinagawa Train Station. There are shops and restaurants in the neighboring Prince Hotel complex and a 7-11 in the basement of our hotel. The tea garden was very scenic and nice to walk through each day on our way to the station. Would definitely recommend this hotel for families.

Wonderful view from balcony, helpful staff, a 7/11 convenience store within the hotel, AND an airport shuttle service + free bus to Shinagawa Station even though it is only a five minute walk away. Our family of four were amazed by the quality of service and welcoming nature of the staff. All of our queries were promptly answered by the hotel concierge and they would even go the extra mile of providing us with timetables for buses and staff members who spoke our native language. The interior of the hotel itself exceeded our expectations and we were blown away by the staff's enthusiasm and willingness to assist us with our luggage (we had many heavy suitcases) and even deny any tipping! There were even hotel staff assisting us at the front of the hotel before we even set foot in the place! The free and speedy WiFi, easy-to-use room key card as well as the hotel's general closeness to all the areas which we planned on visiting pleased us greatly. We'll definitely recommend this hotel to all of our friends and anyone hoping for a lovely stay in Tokyo.

Not recommended to visitors who bring heavy bags by walking.시나가와역에서 걸어가기에 좀 애매합니다. 거리는 뭐 나쁘지 않은데 짐 들고 간다면 꽤 힘들어요. 역에서부터 오르막길이라. 일과시간엔 셔틀이 오가니 그거 시간 참고해서 타고 다니시면 좋습니다. (15분 간격, 역에서의 막차는 9시반쯤이었던듯) 굉장히 큰 호텔이고 숙소 시설도 나쁘진 않습니다. 연식이 좀 되어보이지만 관리가 잘 된 느낌. 일본 호텔 치곤 방이 넓은 편인데, 제가 묵은 방은 샤워부스가 없어서 - 개인취향 - 조금 아쉬웠음. 조식은 좋다는데 먹어보지 않아 모르겠네요. 벨걸들은 친절했으나 프런트 직원이 불친절했어서 아쉬움. 늦은 시각 체크인이긴 했으나. Staffs don't speak English very well.

Very good medium/ high priced hotel.Rooms are decent sized ( not often the case in Tokyo, even in top class hotels)Small balconies over a Japanese garden : delightful Breakfast buffet is opulentConveniently close to two majors train and underground stations: takanawa and shinagawa

I loved the room and hotel's asthenic. It's only a block away from the Shinagawa station. There are closer hotels but for the price and quality (my assessment based on reading other's reviews and pictures) this appeared to be the best deal. I also liked the fact that they have an ATM machine in their lobby and a 7-11 on the bottom floor. Everything was very convenient.

Tokyo Grand Prince Hotel is so big, the front office directly give me the hotel map when we checked in. There were 2 restaurant choice for breakfast. I forgot the other one, but we choose marmolada restaurant because they serve international buffet menus. Unfortunately we have to queu before to be seated at the place they choose for us, so we can't choose our own seat.There's also convinient store opposite marmolada resto called family mart, if you need anything like snack etcThe nearest subway station is shinagawa station, its 10 min walking distance

Stayed there for 3days. The hotel staff were friendly & accomodating, the rooms were clean, the bed & pillows were so soft & comfy, restrooms were clean complete with toiletries. There were 3 choices of the restaurants where we had breakfast. The buffet area was big, the food were delicious & had many choices. The location was nearby a train stationmaking it very accessible

I stayed in the hotel for three nights. Quite location, a clean comfortable room, 7-8 minutes walk to a train station and to a metro station, too. It is a good place for staying in Tokyo. One tip for breakfast. There are several cafes and restaurants in the hotel that offer breakfast. Please try the self-service restaurant on the ground floor. It has a rich choice of various meals: Amrican/European and Japanese as well. At the same time the cafe near the reception on the first floor features a continental breakfast only.

I was attending a conference at the conference center, PAMIR, on the hotel grounds. I was booked at this hotel for 7 days by my hosts and I chose to stay extra days while attending to other business. The location is great if you have to travel in the Shinagawa ward of Tokyo, and it is down the hill to the JP Shinagawa station with very convienent access to the rest of Tokyo and Japan. Plenty of places to eat, especially on the other side of the station in the Konan neighborhood. Old meat packing area of town so there are some great barbeque places!I arrived two hours early, and my room was not ready. Check in is at 2 pm, and there were many of us waiting in the lobby, and this scene was repeated daily. So don't expect an early check in. Lobby is comfortable and free Wifi is decent.Rooms are nice size and amentities are at the level you would expect for the money you pay per day. It is important to request a non smoking room if you do not wish to absorb the smoking smell. The problem for me was that my room was hot and there was no way to turn on the air conditioner. I called the guest services line and some one came up right away to check on the situation. I speak some Japanese and I was told that once the hotel switches to the winter mode, only the heater was functional and there was no way to turn on the air conditioner. So I kept my balcony door open for the stay. Forutnately my room was on the opposite of the street. It was okay until they started construction and the banging started before the sun rose.The breakfast option is a nice perk. You get three choices. The buffet has all you can eat and it can get a little crazy. I liked the Japanese option and the hotel lounge option. Definitely quieter and much more relaxing. Food was good, but just not all you can eat. I always ate outside the hotel for my other meals in other areas of Tokyo. That's the fun part of the city. However, if you need a midnight snack, there is a 7-11 convenience store on the level below the lobby. Exercise facilities are very basic. Two treadmills, two bikes. No TV so take your smartphone. Good wifi connection for streaming. The front desk staff were definitely hit or miss on their Englsih and hospitality. I would not stay at this hotel again, if I had a choice. Service and room did not match the room cost.

I've stayed at the Grand Prince Takanawa for business several times, this was my first stay at the Grand Prince New Takanawa which is located next door. Both hotels are located in the same area and are very similar from all aspects. The good: - The location near Shinagawa station is very convenient.- There is a shuttle to and from the hotel every 20 minutes most of the day. - Quick and professional service by staff- Access to a good gym (at additional cost of 2100 JPY per visit, but at least you have the option). Located in the Sakura Tower accessible through the garden.The less good:- Some noise from neighbouring rooms- If you get a room close to the elevator the vibrations can be extremely annoying- A bit difficult to find your way around- The breakfast options aren't great. The lounge restaurant by the lobby is just plain bad, and the buffet style restaurant downstairs has a long waiting line at peak times in the morning and is horribly planned. Want a bowl of yoghurt? Get the bowl in one end of the room, get the yoghurt in the other and then realize that the spoons are yet somewhere else. Unacceptable. Somebody really needs to re-plan this layout.

My wife and I stayed at this fine hotel for 5 days. Great location just 5 minutes to the Shinagawa Train Station and situated in a calm residential area this hotel has everything to offer. Attentive service, nice rooms, great selection at breakfast, nice new lobby, full tourist services by the concierge, and walking distance to temples, shrines, churches and a synagogue. This is my hotel in Tokyo.

I stayed here yesterday for business. Upon check-in at 3.15pm (hotel's standard check-in time is 3pm), the Front Desk agent said that a smoking room was reserved for me which I later clarified with our corporate travel agent that it was not true. Anyway, I was told that hotel was fully booked and that no non-smoking room was available. For a non-smoker, it wasn't comfortable for me. I find it strange that at 3.15pm, such a large hotel has already managed to check in all of its guests (usually there should be people who check in later in the day). Even its 2 other sister hotels nearby were also fully booked so all could do was to do "air cleaning" which essentially was just sending a staff to quickly spray the room but it didn't help much. Other than being a smoking room, room is average and dated. There was no ladies' amenities such as cotton pads which I had to call Operator and they delivered quickly. The good things about the hotel are that it is quite near and there's a shuttle us to Takanawa station and that hotel staff (Front Desk agent + Houseskeeping staff) responded quickly but I wouldn't stay at this hotel again.

This amazing property welcomes you the minute the vast sliding doors open into a colossal lobby that overlooks a beautiful park in the middle of Tokyo's stainless steel buildings. Staff are ready to help you and serve with a smile.Rooms have balconies that overlook incredible city views.Many restaurants are located in the hotel if you prefer to catch s bite to eat after a long day of meetings and/or site seeing.Also great Shopping in the area.

Comparatively to typical Japanese business hotels the room we had was much larger and far more comfortable, there is a nice-sized desk and chair jutting out from the corner of the room and a vanity with chair for the ladies, as well a comfy chair for lounging facing the TV. The bathroom was also nice and spacious, it had plenty of counter space and a nice shower/tub that had simple water temperature controls and even an adjustable pressure shower head. The balcony is also accessible which is a nice feature but I felt a bit lonely out there as it doesn't seem like anyone really uses them since you can see all of the other vacant balconies.The hotel itself is about a ten+ minute walk from the station (the hotel website claims it's a five minute walk but realistically from the station entrance to the hotel's side entrance it is certainly not unless you speedwalk), and mind you it is all uphill so if you are in a rush it feels more like a hike. If you decide to jump in a taxi it's approximately ¥750 from the west side of the station and will get you to the hotel in about two minutes. The hotel also has a convenience store on basement floor 1 that I think is open until 1 a.m.This hotel has a great location just for proximity to Shinagawa Station, as you get extremely convenient access to Shinkansen lines as well as the Narita Express. One stop away on the Yamanote Line at Osaki Station gives you a convenient transfer point to the Rinkai Line for access to Odaiba and even the Disney Resorts (with one more transfer to the Keio Line at the terminus in Shin-Kiba). Overall a great hotel if you want convenience and comfort.

Overall, the service and friendliness of staff is excellent. Room is very dusty - the cleaning crew doesn't seem to do any dusting at all. Don't expect too much from club lounge - you get what you pay for. The white and red wine was less than average, the champagne was good. Nibbles is some nuts, smoked salmon, etc. Breakfast is buffet style - not too bad. 4/5 star because of the dustiness.

well deserved from both airports from Haneda 20 minutes by taxi 5000 yensfrom narita airport limousine bus directly to hotel 3600 yenswell situated near tube and rail stationlarge rooms well furnishedig you want a large bed you will have to ask in advance

There are four Prince Hotels in the JR Shinagawa Railway Station area; the ever popular, but simple Shinagawa Prince Hotel, Sakura Tower and Grand Prince Takanawa with beautiful Japanese garden and this Grand Prince New Takanawa. I've stayed all of them in the past and I have to say that Grand Prince New Takanawa is the least interesting of all.The location is okay. Though the farthest among the four to the train station.The hotel's lobby is spacious and rooms are said to be also spacious and ours was fine. (I have stayed here only once.)However, this is a boring hotel. The room decor is spartan and has no character of any kind.If you have budget to stay here, choose Grand Prince Takanawa or Sakura Tower. They come with much better atmosphere.

I had a twin room which had large beds, a work table, small chez lounge which was large in my experience of Tokyo. Very clean and well maintained. Each room seems to have a small balcony but there was no view from mine and a tree had overgrown into it. Powerful shower. Room safe and mini bar fridge. Take your own adapters as this hotel didn't have multi region sockets which some have. Reception will loan you adapters though. Very limited room service menu. Breakfast had a few choices. I opted for the Marmalado and fairly traditional American style food but there was a very large selection covering almost any preference. Freshly cooked eggs and omelettes were available. It's about a ten minute walk from the very busy Shinagawa station. I would definitely stay there again
user_name:
Dtucker1962
Sutton in Ashfield, United Kingdom

review_body: We traveled to this hotel from a business meeting in the Ginza core; about a 10 minute drive. This hotel is located in a quiet District with many facilities inside and surrounding the hotel. The reception area is very large and the service staff at check-in and concierge very willing to accommodate with great efficiency. After check-in , brief meeting at the lobby level bar was very enjoyable as this bar is suitably decorated and furnished for relaxation. Great atmosphere. Use of the hotel rooftop pool was an unexpected pleasure. The rooms themselves are substantially larger then my prior 3 hotels in Tokyo this week and well equipped with coffee, stocked mini bar and plentiful bathroom amenities. An added convenient feature of this hotel is an ongoing shuttle bus from the hotel Property to the transportation hub (Shinagawa station). From this station about a 10-minute walk downhill from the hotel if you prefer walking, you can travel to any point in Japan.
