I use the station for subway trips back into downtown Tokyo as well as the express train to Narita Airport (NEX) which stops only once briefly in Tokyo Station on the way. This is the most convenient way to get to the airport as it removes the element of unexpected traffic delays and gets you into your terminal in about 1 hour (vs minimum 90 minutes on the limousine bus at similar cost). I would recommend this hotel to anyone vacationing or here on business as it is a budget-friendly Hotel with comfortable accommodation and a wide variety of features. Don't miss the Japanese Gardens on the property.

The hotel was our first port of call after a long journey from the UK. It was great that the room awaiting us was Modern and impeccable. The reception staff and bell boys were very attentive and helped our every needs. We needed luggage forwarded on to Kyoto and this achieved with a minimum of fuss. There were various restaurants in the complex, but we didn't use these. Did use the TGI Fridays just down the road and made a number of visits to the 7Eleven which was handily placed in the basement.The Shinagawa railway station was within walking distance when we departed Tokyo. This was 5 minutes walk away.

I stayed here for 6 nights while on business in Tokyo.The hotel is a 10 minute uphill walk from Shinagawa train station (Takanawa exit). The bars and restaurants at the hotel are typically high priced so consider your budget (or business allowance) for food before staying or eating. There are plenty of eating options in the area though if you are happy to take a walk about.Service is very good and the hotel is kept to a very high standard.The fitness room comprises of two running machines and two exercise bikes - choice and availability can be limited.Early check-in (if available) is charged by the hour.

This hotel had a gorgeous interior. They were still renovating certain areas when I was there, but whatever was done was beautiful. The rooms are modern and spacious. For how new the rooms were though, I expected a more modern bathroom, but the bathrooms were not that appealing. They weren't dirty or anything, just not as new as I would expect from seeing the hotel and the rest of the rooms. The staff were polite. The hotel conveniently has a 7-11 downstairs. Location-wise, it's near enough to a train station, but coming back from the station, there's a somewhat steep uphill.

Overall, I am having a good stay here. First off, it is a five to ten minute walk from the JR station with a sloping uphill so not super close. They strictly adhere to the check in time but are happy to store your bags. The limo bus stops here which is convenient. My room was very nice and spacious, but I opted for the club floor. At the time of reservation, it was a. Small increment in price ($20) but get many benefits. My room on the 15th floor with a balcony had a great view and with the widow open, felt wonderful. You also get snacks, beer and alcohol included along with breakfast items, so seems a bargain. It also includes access to the spa at the adjacent property which normally would be a extra cost(20 dollars or so). If you have not done a Japanese public bath experience, I would recommend doing so as it is so Japanese. My room that they gave was very spacious. I paid about $200 per night, so please put that in perspective. So, overall, some pluses and minuses, but I would stay at this hotel again.

In comparison to hotels in other countries, this hotel really should be with 4 stars ... or "Very Good" rating. However, in Japan, standards are so much higher so its unfair to rate it high compared to other really fantastic Japan hotels.Still, it is great value for $$ and *relatively* inexpensive compared to surrounding hotels in the area (Prince Sakura Tower, SHinagawa-strings Intercontinental, etc.)Hotel is a bit of a walk from Shinagawa station. Up a gentle-ish incline for about a 10 minute walk from Shinagawa East Entrance. Hotel itself: Rooms are as every neat and well appointed. Bathroom/shower area unfortunately extremely small, even for Tokyo standards. Shower Curtain in a bathtub is the main showering area.Internet: Pretty good speeds but does not allow Bit Torrent downloading. YouTube is fine ... average speeds of about 6Mbps. Wired connection in the room, as well as Wireless in the hotel. Not great:Gym facilities are a paid extra charge ... around 18USD per day, opens 6AM-10PM, and not in the main hotel.NOT to be missed:If you have the time ... the hotel shares a common garden area with the other few hotels. Walking into it is like walking back to Edo society ... Koi pond, with Edo-style structures. Truly an oasis of tranquility. The Koi are pretty large and beautifully kept ... seats/benches provided around the pond which becomes a cacophony of living colour after a few minutes of starring. The garden is pretty quiet and isolated ... probably the best kept secret feature of this (and Prince Sakura Tower) hotel.

Pro's: big rooms for a Japanese hotel, modern decor, free and fast wifi, 7-11 on premise. Close to Shinagawa train station(5-10 min walk). Just about all employees spoke survivable English. Airport shuttle(Narita) to the entrance of hotel. Cons: none really, lobby had construction, but unnoticeable.Great hotel will definitely be a returning guest.

This a big hotel set on an enormous site for Tokyo, renovations were being carried out in the middle of the night whilst we were staying so you can look fireRd to an upgraded lobby.First time I had a shower over bath on my 9 day Asian trip accomodation was clean and tidy but nothing special to write home about. I think rooms are ready for an upgrade, very good location, close to a number of things.

Our coach parked under cover outside the hotel so we didn't get wet. Huge, stunning lobby, spacious room and well equipped bathroom. Breakfast excellent, with a great choice of food and drink. Staff obliging and efficient. Perfect hotel! No hesitation to recommend.

Very good room size and clean and beautiful washrooms. Was there for 4-5 days and had a comfortable and pleasant stay in a room overlooking the pool. It's a business district and the Shinugawa station is a pleasant 5 mins walk. The restaurants in the hotel are amazing and many eating options/sake bars in the Shinugawa area. The staff at the travel desk in the Hotel were very helpful, knew perfect English and helped me with my entire Tokyo itinerary.

Located 10min walk from Shinagawa station the surroundings are well populated with restaurants. The lobby is grand with excellent service. The rooms are quite large and nice. They have two sets of breakfasts: Western and Japanese. The Western one was abrogate. You can take the limousine bus from Narita to get tot the hotel.

It's a very good hotel and the service is also very prompt.They have a good swimming pool.Generally the beds are small in Japan but here it's big enough.Since I m tall so was very happy .the ambience is also very good.food is fantastic one should not miss there silken tofu.

We had a great stay and a great room!!! Our room was a double room the bed was HUGE and comfy and the overall room was also big! We had an amazing view of the tokyo tower and the room service was also nice!!! The reason i didn't give 5 stars was that the laundry service was extremely pricy!!! For one t-shirt almost 600yen! We had our clothes washed elsewhere! We deliberately got less clothes so we could use the washing facility but we couldnt imagine that cost! Apart from that issue our stay was unique!!

Well deserved 4 star hotel. We had a triple room with 3 bed. Unlike other Japanese hotels with tiny rooms, our room was spacious, as well as the bathroom. Comfortable beds and very good breakfast buffet (3000yen each). Very good location, close to JR Line and subway. Highly recommended!
user_name:
read-travel
New York City, New York

review_body: I had never stayed in the Shinagawa area before, and I'm glad I picked Grand Prince New Takanawa on this occasion.On arrival at JR Shinagawa Station, go through the Takanawa Exit and you'll see an pedestrian crossover bridge to connect to the right hand side of the street.The hotel is a straight walk ahead. 5 mins on the website, about 10 mins with luggage walking uphill:)There are great facilities on site - atms, great convenience store and helpful, friendly staff.The rooms are a great size, we had two adults in each room, plus copious amounts of luggage and still had plenty of space. The beds were comfy, and the balconies were a bonus.There isn't a great deal of shopping or dining options in the area - there's an Outback Jack's if you feel like a streak a few mins walk back towards the station from the hotel on the right hand side, and plenty of cheap places to eat within the station complex.The real drawcard is the quietness of the area, and the close proximity to JR Shinagawa Station, which has direct connections on the NE'X Express to and from Narita Airport, limousine bus connections and also serves as a major bullet train hub, making side journeys seamless. This hotel is a perfect stay for families, singles and couples alike, looking for a quieter alternative to the hustle and bustle of Shinjuku and Shibuya.I would recommend this area if you were looking at travelling on the bullet train the day after arrival, or to wind down the end of your trip back in Tokyo for a couple nights before you fly home from Narita.

We a group of 12 had been to Japan visiting Tokyo,Kyoto & Hiroshima organised by Chariot World Tours Ltd from !st august to 8th august 2016.In Tokyo we stayed at Grand prince hotel.It was a good business hotel.The rooms were spacious & well appointed.complimentary breakfast made available was quite good catering to varied tastes but a bit limited for vegetarians,One of the features in the rest rooms was electrically/electronically operated toilet seats known as Bidetswhere temperature can be controlled for the personal convenience & the temperature of the jet wash can also be controlled.A very good use of technology.All in all the stay was comfortable

Well appointed for the business person, with desk, desk lamp, swivel chair & lots of power points. Free wi-fi for up to nine (9) devices. Free shuttle bus to/from Shinagawa railway station. Great restaurants nearby which are more economical than hotel restaurants. (Expensive). Railway at Shinagawa is a major rail hub for JR lines, Shinkansen and local trains. Paid shuttle buses to Narita & Haneda airports to the hotel door. I think you have to pay to go to the two pools, but when I tried to ring reception to check, they did not answer the phone (?). Overall a comfortable bed, and a roomy experience. Location in Shinagwa is great. We will return.

Many hotels in Tokyo offer girls night plans for a lower price than regular, most of this information is in Japanese websites so you must know some Japanese to make the reservations. This time we made reservations for 3 girls and it was 9600 yen each which included the room and one pool ticket but prices vary depending on the plan.Because a typhoon hit when we stayed here we couldn't use the pool so instead we could exchange it for a meal (2160yen worth) in any of hotel's restaurants which was nice.If you want to use the pool though beware of the times they open at 10am and close at 9pm which is quite early to close it i think.The room was spacious and it had a small balcony to look at the view. From my room I could see Tokyo tower (small but there)the beds were comfy and it was quiet. The room had 3 beds so we didnt have to share either.They had ATM, seven eleven, currency exchange machines and even machines to charge your Suica cards.Its about an 8minute walk from Shinagawa station but they also have a free shuttle bus in Takanawa exit which runs every 20 minutes.

The lGrand Prince Hotel New Takanawa Hotel is surrounded by lovely Japanese gardens, a tea house and a pond which offer a cool respite from the August hot weather. This hotel is currently in the middle of lobby renovations but it still manages to impart cool sereneness and beauty. IT also has the advantage of being just a short walk to the Shinagawa Railway Station from which you can take trains to the airport and JR railways connections to all parts of Tokyo as well as being one of the stops of the Shinkanen (Bullet) Train. There are four restaurants in the hotel as well as many other in the Minato entertainment area. The rooms are large and airy with very comfortable beds and large bathrooms.

We stayed in this behemoth for two nights. 1. Rooms a lot larger than usual in Japan and relatively luxurious for Japanese standards.2. Breakfast ridiculously expensive, have breakfast at the Royal Park restaurant which is a 5 minutes walk towards the station3. Neighborhood quite boring4. Only hotel that out of nowhere charged us 100Y per person5. Has two pools but charges a whopping 3000Y per person for use of them. And if you would wish to relax on a lounger, they have the guts to ask 10000Y (!!!) per lounger. This is absolutely insane, paying for use of the hotel pool even if you are a guest. Sky pool is a unoleasant place anyway, don't use this, it is a complete ripoff. We didn't even want to look at the other pool.6. This hotel is so enormously big, it is a very bland and has no personality whatsoever.7. Beds are good, pillows too.8. Hotel bar: huge, only a glass of red wine costs 1500Y at least, about 13€!!All in all there are way better places to stay in Tokyo.

We stayed for one night as our first-stop hotel after landing in Tokyo. From Narita International Airport we took the JR line to Shinagawa station. There are several Prince Hotels in the vicinity of the station, with another Prince Hotel being much closer to the station than this one.Should we had known that Prince Hotel group runs a complimentary inter-hotel shuttle we would have opted to walk over to Prince Hotel to ride this shuttle instead of walking about 15 mins (some uphill) to Grand Prince Hotel. (We only learned about the shuttle after checkout, when we asked about getting a taxi to the JR station down the hill because it was raining so we did not want to walk to the JR station. Receptionist told us about the shuttle, for which we were glad. The shuttle ride was only about 5 minutes.)Other than being a bit farther away from the JR Station than its sister property, Prince Hotel, our stay was fine. The hotel and the room's decor and furnishing looked dated, but good that room and bathroom were clean and the floor was quiet. A convenience store at the lower level in the hotel offers hot and cold food choices (staff uses microwave in the store to heat purchased food up for customers.). If one does not want to walk back down to the busier commercial area near the JR station or does not want to dine in the hotel restaurants, this on-site retail outlet offers some convenience.

Although this hotel is undergoing renovation currently, it is a great place to stay for a few nights in Tokyo. You have access to several amenities in and around the hotel. If you don't want to spend the money on food I the hotel there are other restaurants surrounding it. The staff is helpful and friendly. Centrally located too.
user_name:
Tasha S
Salt Lake City, Utah

review_body: This is our second visit to the Grand Prince. We love this hotel for its clean rooms, friendly staff and it's close proximity (2 blocks)to Shinagawa Station. The staff is very helpful for even non-Japanese speaking customers. The area near Shinagawa Station offers you lots of shopping, eating and drinking. The hotel itself offers some nice restaurant including a very nice French Bakery. Shinagawa is your gateway to Tokyo and Japan with access to all rail including the Shinkansen(Bullet Train). I would definitely recommend a ride anywhere on the Shinkansen! If I find myself back in Tokyo this will be my hotel.

Good location. Super easy bus from Narita, so if you time it right go for it. Stop 13 for the limo-bus. Nice size room. All rooms have balcony so fresh air after long flight is good. Club level is standard basic "avg USA self service Marriott style". Nothing to complain about, just solid. Under a bit of reconstruction, but still very workable. Internet speed is good.

Stayed there last week on business, really nice hotel, bit reminiscent of a Las Vegas Casino, big spacious reception lots of marble, they are connected to a conference centre so that adds to the feeling, it was busy but not packed. The Room and room service were excellent a comfy bed with plenty of pillows. AC was good and I even had an extra dehumidifier! Bathroom was modern and the shower was good. Wifi coverage was excellent as was the speed. Proximity to the Shinagawa station is really useful as people have said it is the terminal station for the express from Narita, it is a steepish climb up to the hotel though so if you have heavy luggage beware! The only bad thing really was the cost of the food, ended up eating breakfast out most days down the road at the many cheaper restaurants on the way to the station.

When I stayed here, they were going through a remodeling of their lobby, so the whole thing was chaotic. Nevertheless, to the staff's credit, they were managing the best they could with the situation. So, I am not going to talk about anything else other than the quality of the rooms, the restaurants and the location. The rooms were very clean, though dated and old. They are typical Japanese upper business hotel rooms. Small and cramped but not as bad as some other hotels. I was very comfortable staying there for four days. The Japanese restaurants in the hotel are very good. But the hotel is near many restaurants and bars. One has many choices a very short walk away. It is also very close to a subway station but I didn't use it because I couldn't make sense of the map and the lines. In all, it is a good hotel. I am told it has a great pool and Japanese gardens, but I didn't have time to explore those. Hopefully next time.

The hotel is set in beautiful gardens uphill from Shinagawa station. The international breakfast buffet can get very busy, with waiting times to be expected. The Japanese breakfast is less popular, but worth a try.The bar is very relaxing. Cool ice cubes served with the japanese whiskies.Wifi is very fast.

In comparison, this is a value for money hotel that has big room. It has direct bus from the airport & easy access to train station, but not too many shops in the area. 相對而言，這是一家物超所值的飯店，特別是房間夠大，而且大廳的設計很日本的同時也很大氣，到品川車站也很方便，但是車站附近購物商業較為簡單且不多元。。

Hotel location is within walking distance to hundreds of restaurants, bars and fast food. Main interchange station Shinagawa (which is also end stop for fast train from Narita Airport) is just 300m down the street. The most surprising thing about the hotel is the room size for a Japanese hotel. Rooms are comfortable with quality amenities. Unfortunately no gym and English stations on the TV are also minimal. Eating in the hotel restaurant is expensive. My recommendation is go out the many restaurants outside. The hotel room rate is very good for such a location nearby a main rail station.

I am a seasoned traveller and every now and again I get a new experience that I wasn't expecting. This hotel seems to be good at charging but completely lacking at service. I don't mean to complain but has any reader ever been charged as a Hotel guest for using the Hotel's swimming pool? Well this place does. 3,000 JPY which at the time of writing is $29.78 USD. $30 for swim. Are you kidding me? I know Japan is running a huge current account deficit but they're not going to get the money by being rude to their customers and cheating them. A customer stays at a hotel because they are away from home and want to feel at home. Cheating a customer is unpleasant. The Gym is also next to useless with 2 bikes, 2 walkers and 2 yoga mats. The gym is free and it would need to be because it is useless.Next is the shuttle bus to the airport. in a 24 hour period this hotel runs 3. If you need to get to the airport early, which I do then you should add another $50 US to the cost of staying here for a Taxi. The Wifi has convoluted password system which is annoying for logging in.

This is a large, nice hotel in Tokyo, within a couple of blocks of the Shinagawa station (where you can get trains to anywhere). The public areas are nice, comfortable and spacious (though part of the lobby was under renovation construction at the time we were there). Two different breakfast choices - a Western style buffet, and a traditional Japanese meal, served in traditional fashion. We tried both, and enjoyed both. The room was very good, and the wifi was excellent - the best wifi we had on our twelve day trip. Like in other places in Japan, the TV didn't have much in English language, but I did not go to Japan to stay in my room and watch English language TV. I would recommend this hotel.

Was quite surprised as how big this hotel actually is. Looks brand new as well! Seriously amazing, English friendly staff, warm rooms, and a nice surprise to see a 7-11 in the B1 level of the property! Watch out for those expensive restaurants In the hotel. It's a 10 minute walk away (slightly uphill) from JR Shinagawa Station.

This is a very nice hotel. It is large and part of a the prince chain that has several other hotels in the local area. I was warned that hotel rooms in Tokyo are notoriously small, but that was not the case at the New Takanawa. Apart from the Japanese TV and bum-washing toilet I could have been in any business hotel room.The room as nicely decorated, the temperature was good, the bed was comfortable and there was even a balcony. Breakfast in the main restaurant was Japanese only, so if you want a western style buffet breakfast go down Marmolada or for a continental try the Edelweiss Cafe, both on B1.A couple of small things, it is a fair trek up the hill from Shinagawa station, and there is nowhere to just just sit and relax in an open area. The seating in the lobby is actually a restaurant.

Visited Tokyo for a business trip and stayed in this hotel. Rooms are large as per Tokyo standards and comfortable. Walking distance from Shinagawa station which is one of main stations and train takes you straight to the Airport. Several restaurants and bars in the vicinity. Language is a problem with most of the staff members but somehow manageable. Recommended for stay ..

The stay in Grand prince hotel comfortable but it seems a bit expensive. But you dont get this size of rooms anywhere else. :-)All in All a good experience. The staff is very co-opearative. The only problem was that many in staff do not know English, which can be frustating.

Just arrived and stopped by the lobby area cafe for a quick cappuccino.Received a bland, watery cap in small cup$13 U.S. I said it must be a mistake ..no where in the world is a cappuccino $13He said sorry sir but that is the priceOutrageous !

There's not much to complain about this hotel. The location is great, very near Shinagawa train station which is one of the major train terminals in Tokyo. Many western restaurants nearby (Outback Steakhouse??), and Japanese restaurants on the other side of the station. There is even a convenience store on the premises. The rooms are large, and of course clean and well maintained with the usual essentials. They serve both Western and Japanese breakfasts. I only ate the Western breakfast, and it had a pretty good spread.The 2 reasons the hotel did not make 5 stars (IMHO) is: (1) it's currently under renovation, so can be a bit noisy, and the reception is hard to find; (2) its just too big. It's quite a trek to get from the restaurant (where breakfast is served) or the reception, back to the rooms. And given the number of guests, breakfast time can be a real challenge with crowds and long queues. Finding the gym proved next to impossible.

The Grand Prince Hotel is super convenient, especially if you're on a business trip: very close to Shinagawa and Gotan-yama and bit further away from Osaki. A bit removed from the hustle and bustle of Shinagawa yet very close to everything. The inner garden is lovely and peaceful. And - being in Shinagawa - there is plenty of connection to wherever you want to go in Tokyo.The rooms are large and the staff and service is always top notch.

Stayed 3 nights excellent room with buffet breakfast and one buffet dinner. Very large hotel complex so a 5minute plus walk to the restaurant. If taking a taxi downtown make sure you return to correct hotel as there is the Prince Hotel, the Grand Prince Hotel and the New Grand Prince Hotel all close together but it's not easy to negotiate a route from one to another. The hotel has an eco cleaning policy so guests are offered 500 Yen if they do not require the room to be serviced one day in three

I stayed there 2 nights and I enjoyed very much. It's a 4* stars Hotel, but it could be a 5* too, for all, what the offer.I had a large room, but I reserved a double, for having more space, no breakfat option: but you are very close to the Shinagawa train station, with a lot of possibility to get everything.Also a very good Enoteca, close to the Hotel.You can also carry your luggage, if you want, but the way to the Hotel is a litle up, maybe not for old people.Any way a good stay, a litle expensive, but my Hotel in Shinagawa, where I already was last year.

The hotel feels like a conveyor belt, designed to churn guests in and out. It is very large, with great distances between rooms and reception. It is pretty much faceless, with the arrival outside, reception inside and rooms themselves having no character. The view from a lower floor room was limited, adding up to one of the most dull hotel experiences I've had in a foreign city. The area around the hotel was also not appropriate for walking.

The hotel is under renovation and you my see some construction going on around the hotel but that should not disturb you, at least it did. It happen to me during my visit. The room is reasonable in size and cleanliness. However, generally I felt the service is a bit lacking for Japan standard. Also, there is no complimentary water in the room and you are expected to buy if u need it. One thing that impressed me is the little consideration that they place the child size slipper and bath accessories when you have told them you have young kid with you! Well done to the management as this little consideration make me feel your appreciation of your customers. The hotel locations is slightly up the hill from the train station, a fair bit of walking distance about 200-300m uphill, so perhaps grabbing a taxi is an option for ¥730 only if you hv kids/old parents/disabled. You will find restaurants, coffee shop conveniently around the hotel and train station areas. Good varieties too!!

I selected this hotel for its proximity to the Shinagawa station, the second stop on the Narita Express (N'EX) train roughly a 70 minute trip from Narita Terminal 1. It is a 5-10 minute walk up a moderate incline to get to the lobby. The building is undergoing some renovations in the lobby area so the registration counter and concierge are not much to look at but still fully functional.I have heard many rooms in Japan are cozy to put it nicely, however I found my room on the 12 floor to be as spacious as any other in the USA. Nicely sized bath and sleeping area. The electronic bidet on the toilet is silent which would have been a delight to my toddler who hated the noise from the automatic flush and auto-open/close toilet lid feature he experienced at another Japanese hotel. I did not partake of the in hotel dining options, instead I was an frequent visitor to the 7/11 downstairs which was fairly well stocked. I was amazed that a 500ml bottle of Evian runs just 120 yen there. There are also many touristy dining options and Pachinko parlors as you head back to the train station. If you are looking for something local an inexpensive just walk to the other side of the Shinagawa station. I had a bowl of chicken somen noodles plus sides for ~900 yen, an inexpensive yet filling dinner after a long haul flight.The concierge desk was very helpful and patient while helping me look for a spa with "doctor fish" to treat my feet.The rooms are quiet, never heard my neighbors. The beds and linens are very comfortable. I wish the flat screen was a bit bigger and with more TV channels available both local and international. Using Ookla from the room, the WiFi speeds are impressive >10Mbps download easy. I forgot my international plug adapter at home so I just showed my three prong US plug to the front desk and they had an adapter waiting for me that evening.If the train is not an option, taxis are readily available. I was able to catch one within 10 minutes even at the busy rush hour. I recommend the location being in the mid point with Tokyo Station / Ginza District on one direction of the Yamanote Line and the Shinjuku, Shibuya and Harajuku stations on the other.

The hotel is just a 5-10 minute walk from the Shinagawa station so the location is fantastic. There are quite a few dining options around the station so you are sure to find something agreeable.The hotel is large and given the renovation currently underway around the lobby and the large crowds while I was there, it's a bit chaotic.The feel is a convention or package tour hotel capable of swallowing large groups in an extended lobby. The rooms are a bit of a walk from the check-in desk.There are two breakfast venues, Japanese and western. The Japanese is a set menu tray with a quieter format and the western is a buffet is a more boisterous setting.The room was clean with a TV, safe and water boiler. No iron although I'm sure the desk could deliver one. Unusually, it offered a small balcony and a green view of the central park between the hotels. I woke to bird song which was a nice change from rail or road traffic.Once you are past the renovation and crowds, it is a fine hotel. I'd be happy to stay again given the proximity to the rail station.

We recently stayed at the Grand Prince New Takanawa at the start of a 2 week land tour of Japan. The hotel is located a short walk from the Shinagawa Train station and its surrounding shops, restaurants and department stores. The hotel is very large and was quite busy but the room was quiet at night and was very spacious by any standards. The only down side, like most hotels we have stayed at, was a lot of the food at the breakfast buffet was only just warm. I don't understand why hotel guests continue to pay US$30 (plus) for a barely warm breakfast and I expected better than this in Japan where the rest of the service was very good.

I had a workshop here and it was ok. Breakfast and main meals are just above the average. Long distance to walk between the reception area and the elevators bringing you to the rooms. Internet was not very fast, but no problems for email and a little surfing.

This hotel has a bus service to the airport. The staff is very helpful and very professional. The rooms are nice and clean and the buffet located in the basement offers a big choice on different types of food.Perfect for business.

We were part of a tour that travelled direct from SFO to Haneda. By the time we arrived Tokyo, it was past 10pm and we went straight to our hotel. It was about a 30-40min ride from the airport to the hotel. As soon as we arrived at the hotel, our tour guide hpretty much elped coordinate the check-in. However, the hotel staff who was helping us had to keep coming back as i think she kept getting the wrong tour packets. After 30min, we finally got our keys to our room along with our vouchers for the buffet breakfast. We were so tired and wanted to go straight to our rooms. Our room was a decent size and since there were 3 of us, they brought in an extra bed for the 3rd person. The other beds were pretty decent size so i think we could've done without the extra bed so that we could have had more room. Regardless, there was enough room for all of us to move around. The walls in the room were thin as we could hear conversations going on from the other rooms. Our first night, we hard a woman moaning, lol. The bathroom was a pretty decent size. They don't have an iron and ironing board in the room, luckily i didn't need it until we moved to a different hotel. The only issue we had was the a/c was not working properly and it was pretty warm in the room. We stayed for 3 nights and every night we had to sleep with the balcony door open because it got too hot. They cleaned our room everyday and provided new toiletries each time. IThe complimentary breakfast we had was pretty good. We got seated pretty quick each time and we were in and out. It was very convenient having a 7-11 located at the basement of the hotel. The hotel was about a 5-10min walk from Shinagawa Station. All in all, we were pretty happy with our stay.

+As a member of the Prince hotels family I always try to stay in one of their hotels at Shinagawa because of the amazing garden.At this particular stay we loved the most the large room we had.We also like the Green Room option - we hate the wasteful replacement of towels and sheets. And the extra cashback from the hotel comes as a nice bonus.The hotel is going through renovation and one can already see some signs of the new fresh face, which was overdue. Looking forward to the next visit to see it complete. -Must be typical for Japan, but in all my stays in the Prince hotels I find it strange that gyms, pools, sauna etc. come at quite steep price for the guests. Forget about coming for free.The view of the dark Prince Takanawa closed completely for renovation was kind of spooky in the night across the garden, but we understand it is for the best. Glad to see they are both being refreshed!Better yukatas would also be a nice touch.

Hotel has nice location, just 5 min walk from JR, that makes easy to catch train to Narita airport. Lobby was big and always very busy, but staff was extremely friendly. Room was exactly what we needed complete with a Japanese garden view and Nescafe machine.The amenities were fantastic. So many restaurants within the hotel as well as nearby.

I stayed at this hotel while visiting for a few days for business meetings. I probably would have given a 5 star rating but there is remodelling work currently going on and this meant the hotel was not quite as impressive as I had hoped. Furthermore I was very disappointed that neither of the swimming pools were open. I was lucky enough the stay on the 15th Floor (room 3563) which is on the Club level. This room has excellent view of Tokyo, and the Tokyo Tower in particular. Being on the club level also gives you access to the club lounge on the 16th floor where drinks and food are served. I had breakfast here on two of the morning I stayed and enjoyed it very much. I also checked out here on my final day which avoided any queues at the main reception (which is currently a temporary set up).The Wi-Fi in the hotel is very good.One of the unusual aspects of the hotel is that there is a long walk from the reception area to the elevators. This might be due to the remodelling work but it seemed very strange to me.I'd certainly stay here again and will be interested to see how the hotel looks once the remodelling work is completed.

Just 5 minutes walk from JR, the hotel is surrounded with the shopping mall.I can also see "Tokyo Tower" from my room's terrace. Room is clean and fully equipped.24 hours convenience store located just at the basement floor of the hotel.Staff is not that friendly, but helpful.

The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is one of severeal hotels with similar names on the same hotel grounds. The lobby area is quite grandiose, high under the ceiling, yet a nice atmosphere. The staff were very friendly and helpful.In the middle of the lobby, in celebration of the Sakura cherry tree blossom season, was a beautiful floral arrangement that must have been 2-3 meters tall. An excellent photo- or selfie-op for many.Adjoining was the hotel bar, with its' comfy couches, low tables and the occasional piano player. The menu there was nice, perhaps on the expensive side, so go for one of the combos (coffe and ...). Very nice atmos.The rooms were spacious and modern, well kept and clean. Beds were also good. The door to the bathroom could have been a regular door, instead of a sliding type, to offer better sound proofing.The hotel naturally has free wifi, that worked seamlessly all over the hotel.Due to the sakura, the hotel was packed with tourists, especially from Korea, which resulted in the breakfast buffet restaurants being overcrowded, with lengthy lines, unless you were an early bird. The buffet itself was very nice, with a wide selection of both Japanese and western breakfast dishes.The hotel also has some very nice gardens with narrow pathways, that are lit by rice lanterns at nights. At the end of the garden lies the excellent steak house Katsura (go for the teppanyaki!).The hotel is close to the Shinagawa train station, only a 5 minute walk down the road. Though you probably want to go to other parts of Tokyo for your shopping.

The room we got was a corner room and the size was really good (compare to other hotel rooms size we face in Japan). The hotel location is very convenient as it close to the metro and JR lines, less then 5 min walk. Breakfast was fine with variety of western choices. only one comment is that the hotel is old and it looks in the bathroom and the decoration. All in all, good stay.

Here on business for only three nights. Breakfast restaurant way too expensive and packed. Staff on the desk couldn't speak English well so not too helpful. No coffee in my room. Pretty soulless and unfriendly though efficient and well located.

The absolutely massive lobby of this hotel sets the tone for a good, comfortable, but soulless hotel. Our room had two large single beds and every convenience except adequate hanging space. The queue for breakfast in the Marmalada coffee shop was unacceptable so we ordered breakfast in our room, which was a much better option and served in some style.

It is very near to Shinagawa station, close to shopping and very nice to stay. The hotel has good shopping downstairs. Buffet is very exhaustive. Very big, atmosphere around is very serene. Lovely place to stay.
user_name:
Abdul M S
New Delhi, India

review_body: from pictures and reviews it looked better. In reality it is quite old and not renovated.Especially the lobby is quite anoymous. It has a nice garden and services are ok, good options for breakfast. Location is very convenient, close to Shinagawa station. Shuttle bus to airport.

Rooms were nice and clean, front desk was very cooperative. We stayed for 3 days and overall experience was great. Good place for business trip, very few things to do as tourist. Had high speed connectivity. Breakfast was also very good.

This hotel is large but works well. Bit worn and needs to be updated. Front desk and concierge very helpful. Clean and comfortable rooms. Large and busy hotel. Close to station. Not the best area for tourists not much to do in this area. Good breakfast.

Location: it's a bit far (5mins slope) form Shinnagawa JR, but actually is still ok.The hotel is quite big no matter lobby, restaurant, or the room, the room is really nice, the size is about normal Japan's hotel 150%, and it also has balcony.The price is reasonable, and they've got convenience store inside!

Cons: The heat was turned off (read 75F) and I opened my balcony window each night (It was 40F outside) but it was still very hot in the room. There was no option to get sheets - they only have down comforters. For me this made sleeping hard - but I noticed in my week here that the Japanese like very warm rooms (be it meeting rooms, restaurants, etc)Average - breakfast buffet. There are plenty of options but the food was not very inspiring when you consider the options you get in other hotels in AsiaPros - Very close to corporate office and also Shinagawa station for business meetings and customer calls. Friendly staff - but that probably goes without saying in all of Japan. I also liked the bathroom rolling shelf for storing toothpaste, etc so that you had easy access to things but also open space on the sink.

It's a good hotel for a couple of days business. I had booked at club floor which included the lounge. That's was actually a nice experience. As mostly with the Japanese hotels rooms are small but due to small Balcony you can at least open the door. There is a Japanese restaurant on the ground floor that serves good Japanese good. The gym is small and not free and in the neighbor hotel. A 3 min walk through the back garden. Overall good but not for long.

Stayed here for 4 nights for a medical conference. This hotel is one of three on the campus, together with the convention center itself. Very convenient. Concierge staff very helpful. No gym though - we had to go to the Sakura Hotel, one of the others on the property, for a workout, and this cost about $25. They did not have a jogging map although nearby streets are narrow and may not lend themselves to doing this safely. Buffet breakfast was included in my rate and offered am omelet bar. Some of the dishes though were not very good - very runny "scrambled eggs"

A good sized room, clean, comfortable and convenient to the Shinagawa station - this place ticks the right buttons as a place to stay in Tokyo. It is very handy for Shinkansen access, as well as for getting to and from Haneda and Narita airports and for the JR Yamanote line, which takes you to pretty well every major destination in Tokyo.Consider joining the Prince Club International (free), which at this hotel gives you top floor rooms (and if your lucky, views of Mount Fuji from your Juliet balcony) and the use of the club room for a light breakfast, snacks and evening drinks. The icing on the cake!When we last stayed in 2014 there was a free shuttle bus to the station, which wasn't running when we stayed this time. Even though the hotel is close to the station, it could be an issue if you have a lot of luggage.Tip: make sure your know which Prince Hotel you are staying at in Shinagawa - it can be confusing, with the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa; Grand Prince Hotel Takanawa; the Prince Sakura Tower; and the Shinagawa Prince Hotel all in close proximity!

This hotel is not at all lacking in any basic comforts and is great place for families to stay and explore Tokyo within easy reach of a well connected train station. Although it has a cookie cutter room and basic service, everything was clean and stylish and perfect order. The area is a little 'western' in style and its hard to find any authentic Japanese experience nearby however it is easy to travel anywhere and there are a huge amount of options for shopping and for eating at the nearby station. An easy and very practical choice. The views from our room were lovely.

My wife and I stayed for three nights this past January and we greatly enjoyed this hotel. I choose it for its location and amenities. The hotel is located an easy 8 minute stroll east of Shinagawa Train Station and our 15th floor kingsize room offered wonderful views to the north overlooking down town Tokyo with Tokyo Tower illuminated at night. Room was large, comfortable, and clean. The king-size bed was very comfortable and our floor was very quiet. Checking in was easy and quick, as the staff were excellent, patient, and courteous. The room wifi was very good, but connectivity suffered in the lobby. Overall condition of the hotel felt clean and fresh, although the decore and fixtures are beginning to show their age. We made use of the excellent concierge when we needed help contacting a local airline. When you question the expense of a hotel of this type, services such as a concierge to help smooth your travel arrangements are well worth the cost. There are certainly cheaper options for accommodation, but the services offered by a full on hotel such as this quickly justify the cost. I cannot fully express how friendly, helpful, professional, patient, and courteous the staff were. We felt welcome, tended to, and at ease our entire stay. I highly recommend this hotel and I look forward to staying again when we return to Tokyo. Thank you so much to the staff and management of the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa.

1. Room and bathroom were great - very large for Tokyo standards. At par with international chain hotels.2. Excellent location - about 600 meters from the Shinagawa station. Lots of restaurants close (TGIF, Outback steakhouse, McDonalds etc.)3. They have a shuttle service (3100 JPY) to Narita4. Very stingy hotel, charges for everything: i) Have to pay 2100 JPY for accessing the gym which is actually in the Prince Autograph about 100 metres away!!; ii) Every hour you stay after checkout time is charged at 1800 JPY5. Weird in-room dining rules - there is no in room dining service after 11:30 PM, which is extremely strange for a business hotel. Also there is literally nothing here for vegetarians6. The in-room massage service is terrible - not worth the price.

I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights during a work trip, check in was fast but the hotel couldn’t accommodate any of my room requests. I was given a smoking room with a single bed, they were not willing to find an alternative and as it was 11pm at night I had no option but to accept the room. When you step into the hotel you get the feeling you have travelled back to the 80’s, all the furniture and décor is 70’s/80’s era. The room was no different with all old furnishings and air conditioning that didn’t work. Breakfast was an absolute joke, the line to get into the restaurant was a 20 minute wait and the food selections were very poor. Don’t waste your time……….My experience at this hotel was very poor and I wouldn’t stay here again.

The Grand Prince Hotel is a large Hotel with a huge lobby. The staff was very service minded and helpful. The wi-fi worked ok in the rooms and you have everything you need at this Hotel. They also offered me to borrow a charger to my phone & computer without extra charge, which helped me out a great deal! They also have a "green alternative" which means that for a voucher (500 JPY) you don't get new towels etc. For one day. Loved that! It is located close to Shinagawa station so basically everything is close by.

The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is a well-known hotel in a complex of three...with beautiful grounds and convention space in the bottom floor. Taxi drivers are sure to know of it, and you are in walking distance of a major train station (and all the shops and restaurants that includes in the city). Rooms were clean and modern; beds and bath were perfect. That said, I was a little disappointed that the indoor pool was closed, and you had to walk a mile to find the breakfast room. Kids thought the player piano was cool (live person only in the evening), and the buffet breakfast had both western and Japanese treats. But the weather was exceptionally warm, and the kids stood on the balcony more than once looking longingly at the huge outdoor pool that was closed for the season. As an adult, the whiskey bar was exceptional if not hidden, smokey and dark, nestled in the main lobby. I found myself more than once in the basement 7-Eleven across from the breakfast room. We splurged for a dinner at one of the hotel restaurants - very expensive. I would suggest this hotel as a fine place for business trip or a quick stop, but not for family. Staff were hit and miss in English proficiency. My youngest daughter's biggest take away was the milk bath packets in the bathroom. The Grand Prince had neither the appeal of a fully westernized hotel or the charm of a fully Japanese one. But it was cheap for November and cheerful with access to all you need.

I stayed in this hotel a few times for business purposes. It is huge and not so personal, but rooms are newly decorated and quite spacious for Tokyo standards. It is walking distance from Shinagawa Station and plenty of restaurants in the area. Service is very friendly and effective. It also has a pool, gym, etc. Breakfast room is not that big, so can be crowded.

Rooms are big, my kids like the terraces in each room. Although the hotel is not that fancy but the location of the hotel is quite perfect for us, its close to Shinagawa Station,a few blocks to local shopping mall and restaurants, wherein we found some so familiar to us. Just across the hotel there is catholic church, just in time during our stay on Christmas.Hotel staff speaks English well.

We went to this hotel for a business event and I just can say it was perfect. The room was big and nice the bed like sleeping in a cloud, and the shower really good too. Staff is really nice and helpful and the location, next to Shinagawa station can't be better. Highly recommended!!

The Grand Prince New Takanawa is a quick walk from Shingawa Station, one of the bigger transportation hubs in Tokyo. Although the rooms have been recently renovated, this hotel has been around for quite a few years, for better or for worse. The age shows in some hardware, which can actually be surprisingly lovely (original balcony railings from the 70s) or just kind of drab (bathrooms, for example). The place has history, and you can see it also in the very proper training the staff apparently receive. Check in and check out were very efficiently managed. When we complained of slamming doors and hallway chit chat, we were immediately moved to a quieter location. If your budget allows, I'd suggest saving yourself (and the night porter) the hassle by upgrading to the Modern or Club tier and requesting a corner room. All in all, great value for the money in a very expensive city. I found the rooms much more comfortable and aesthetically pleasing than the ones at the Shinagawa Prince Hotel.

This my goto hotel in Tokyo. A limo bus from the airport (Narita or Haneda) will drop you off right at the door. The staff speak excellent English. The rooms are big, the beds are comfortable, each room has a small balcony with glass windows that open all the way, plenty of hot water and lots of amenities. The hotel could use an upgrade - paint and furnishing are looking a bit worn. But really, who goes to Japan to sit in the hotel and worry about the furniture. The hotel is just up the hill form Shinagawa Station, a major hub in Tokyo. A person can get all over Tokyo and beyond from this perfect locale. Love it, recommend it, will stay again.
Friendly staffHangar sized receptionOK breakfast-bufée, but there might be a lineComfortable roomsInternational news channels on tv dubbed in JapaneseAirport limousine bus directly to/from Narita

Chose this property for its convenience as it is close to the Shinagawa JR/Keikyu station, merely a few stops away from Haneda. Lots of food and beverage options nearby (and in the station). But the walk up the slope to get to the hotel may be pretty tiring, especially after a long day and your feet is screaming for a rest. Be also aware that the shuttle does not stop at the front of the JR station but at the sister hotel (Shinagawa Prince Hotel) across from the station. As such, you will still need to cut through the hotel to get to the JR station. One thing that may be confusing for travelers is the fact that there are 3 Prince hotels in the vicinity with similar names.

This hotel is a blast from the past ..... very much a 70's style hotel badly in need of modernisation of the public areas. The rooms have been done but not completely ..... they had applied some new finishes but the fixtures are all the original ones in the bath rooms ...... disappointing.There is no service in this hotel at all .... take you own bags to your room, no complementary water in room ...... bring your own bags down ..... etc.For a 4 star hotel only to have Room Service until 11.30pm seem strange to me or to what I am used to ......Rooms were large for Tokyo and bed was comfortable so my basics were met .....Not sure I would stay here again.

I checked in to this hotel late one night last week. All was fine until I looked for bottled water so that I could take some meds, only to find out that they don't provide any on a complimentary basis. Now, every hotel I've ever used in Asia has provided complimentary bottled water, even the lowest-star ones. But these guys don't - unless you want to pay 380 Yen (approximately $4.00). Since I had no choice, I did so.Then I found out the following day that one had to pay to use the gym (approx. $22).The last straw however came when I asked the bellman if a taxi could be arranged for me at 5:00am on my departure date. I was told that they could do that, but only if I agreed to pay 840 Yen for the privilege. Stunned, I looked at and empty set in the lobby and asked if there was a charge to sit there while I composed myself. In then end I took a chance, walked out to the curb the following morning at 5:00am and had only to find three taxis waiting to take me to the airport.Other than this nickel-and-dime stuff, the hotel was decent and clean, although their breakfast buffet could use some variety.

Very spacious rooms for tokyo, and staff was good. But the facilities need abit of TLC especially for a 4* hotel, mainly in the bathroom have seen better days. Otherwise it was a good stay with good location for the airport.
user_name:
William L
London, England, United Kingdom

review_body: Room was comfortable, updated and very clean. Rooms have tiny balconies (no space to sit but you can open the sliding glass door and stand outside). Main areas of hotel are "classic" (kind of old fashioned, 1960s-ish). - fair number of decent-to-good restaurants nearby (esp in and around Shinagawa station) - Shinagawa is a stop on the JR Circle line and for the bullet trains, so good location for transportation ease - small shop in hotel is open late hours and has plenty of drinks, snacks and supplies - lobby area (bar etc) Ok but while I was there, was overrun by a big conference they were having so wasn't able to use it myself Would stay again.

Stayed at this hotel for a week and was thoroughly impressed by the hotel, the facilities and the overall experience.The checkin was smooth and cordial. The room was large, clean and airy. It even had a balcony and you could get fresh air in the room. The air-conditioning was not working all that well and when I complained about it it was promptly fixed. I needed a power adapter and they had one to my room in about 3 minutes.The hotel has about six restaurants, all of which were good. The buffet was large but not impressive. The food was often mislabeled (I failed to take a picture of it) such as with a chicken dish that had a label of a pig next to it ;)The chinese and japanese restaurants were very good.The location is awesome, about 7 minutes from Shinagawa station.If you stay here, I'd recommend you consider breakfast across the street at the Royal Host. After the overpriced buffet on the first day, I went to the Royal Host ...Or you can walk to the station and eat at the McDonalds.On the whole a great experience.

The hotel is located a short walk from both Shinagawa and Takanawadai stations which makes it extremely easy to travel. They have good spacious rooms, clean bathrooms and expansive gardens. The airport limo has a pick up and drop off from Narita at this hotel which makes it very convenient especially when you have luggage. The staff are super friendly and very efficient. A definite value for money!

Got to stay 3 nights in this hotel for business. Actually requested for a single room or a king sized bed but instead got a twin set up. Location wise, this hotel is near the Shinagawa station , which is a leisurely 5-10 minute walk, a reminder is that going back is a little uphill approach. Along the way to the station you will encounter several western and Asian restaurants like Mango Tree, Outback and McDonalds. Below the station is a nice upscale supermarket and many stores selling different kinds of merchandise. Going back to the hotel, the lobby is very huge, the lounge near the lobby is also spacious , but the decor was very minimalist so nothing very luxurious is noted even though they have a high ceiling. Being on a tight schedule I never got to see the swimming pool (it opens at 9am) and the fitness club ( we arrived at the hotel quite late. Rooms are on the small side (but well appointed) by Asian standard , including the toilet, but said to be average compared with European and Japanese standards. Tv channel selection showed only 2 English speaking channels, which means it is not geared for international tourists. Airconditioning is also not up to standard, not cool enough for me. Additional features of the hotel include the Japanese garden which somehow links the other 2 hotels of the Prince brand, and the convenience of having a 7-11 store just near the elevator.Wi-fi is free and is quite fast, which is a must for a business traveler like me. Breakfast served buffet style can be partaken at their different restaurants but I always have mine at Marmolada which is nearer the lobby and have a little more spacious set up. Selection was adequate, with various cuisines available, but I kind of like the inclusion of different types of juices and soda in the buffet . Staff service was worth commending, almost all of them are very polite and approachable , and this was consistent throughout my stay. For the magnitude and scale of its property and surroundings, the buffet breakfast experience, and the good staff attitude particularly the lady bell staff, front desk, porters and restaurant personnel , this deserves a very good marking.

This hotel is located close to Shinagawa station, about 6-7 minutes on foot.The same time is requested for Takanawadai subway stop.I had a nice room (equipped with all the amenities by this category of hotels) with fantastic view (it was on 14th floor looking directly towards Tokyo Tower) and free wifi in room.Good and abundant breakfast.

This was my second stay in Tokyo, with the first being at the Westin in Meguro-ku, which helped set my expectations for the area. While my husband and I had to share a room with 2 beds, they were plenty wide and long enough for us to share one. There was no shortage of hot water, and it was nice to get a smoking room when we requested it. I also really liked the bath products. Note that the modern twin rooms are really only big enough for 2 people at most.

This hotel is really huge. About 5 restaurants and a really great gym and sauna. The rooms are quite big for Tokyo style and really nice. I always stay here when I'm in Tokyo and can recommend it if you need to be in this area.
user_name:
Tim Miguel S
Da Lat, Vietnam

review_body: This hotel is very nice and can accommodate a very large number of people. The staff is very friendly and helpful. Could stand to be updated a little bit and smells of cigarette smoke from time to time. Otherwise it's very quiet and comfortable. The views are great and the garden area is beautiful and tranquil. Don't miss the koi pond!!

Very disappointed in my room.. Room Spartan in nature and comforts. Very limited English speaking news and sports channels, A/C doesn't cool and few employees speak English. I know I am in Japan but I have been here several times before at other locations... For a major technical conference host the lack of English speaking staff is a surprise. Hosting a conference the quality of OS I would have expected a higher quality of service. A working A/C would be nice.. Multiple times in Japan but this has been the most disappointing place I have stayed.

Grand Price... once upon a time .. fading now but glimpses of former glory .. well appointed homage to the nineties.. Great views from higher floors..Overall a pleasant and economical hotel well placed in Tokyo..

Stayed there for 3 nights during a group tour in Japan.Although it is a big and busy hotel it was not overcrowded and everything went smooth.The room I got was large and well equipped, had a nice desk and sofa, even a balcony with a chair. There were plenty of room amenities as customary in high Japanese standard, like toothbrush, toothpaste, razor, slippers, bathrobe (beside the obvious soaps and towels). There is also a fridge and kettle with green tea kit, and a safe. The hotel has free wifi in room (an access code is provided).The breakfast was good with large variety of western and Japanese dishes. Tip: there are several restaurants for breakfast, I preferred Marmolada dining room at B1 (access through Edelweiss cafe).There is a nice garden with fish pond next to the hotel, I'm going to upload a photo of it.

As I used to do with my notations, I report into average the "good" that does not exist. Definitively not enough for this hotel to deserve more and very good. But it is perfectly located, very close to Shinegawa train station that is a important one in Tokyo and deserve all the city's area and also has the direct Maria Exprès line to the international airport. Also therefore close to an commercial activity zone, that are always around train stations, giving many options for shops, restaurants and bars, and entertainment opportunities. Finally a nice garden is sitting in between the various hotels if the chain that are concentrated in this zone. Inside, hotel is too neutral, very big and a bit old. Nothing special to say for reception, they just do the job but are not too much happy to give more information. Rooms are oldish, but quite spacious and very clean. Internet works well and was included. TV channels are limited with basically no international channels. Not good for such place. Minibar was however empty and no complimentary water was offered (quite common in Asia). Breakfast was included but for both mornings I was there - day one at 7:45 and day two at 7:30, I could not take it as it was full (30-45 mn waiting time...!). And when leaving "early" day 3 at 5:45, impossible to even have a coffee. I was also not able to use fitness. Opening hours from 7 am to 9 pm makes it difficult if you work. It is any how not in that hotel... So you have to walk to go there in another hotel (Prince Sakurai Tower, closeby) and if you go be aware it is very small and very crowded. So possibly no chance anyhow to exercise.

The New Takanawa hotel in Tokyo is a good choice for an economical priced hotel close to Shinagawa station (walking distance). The staff are very friendly and helpful, the rooms are clean and the hotel grounds include a Japanese style garden. For a seasoned traveler or a first timer to Japan and good hotel choice.

This hotel was very good, we stayed for a couple nights while visiting Tokyo. It's very close to Shinagawa Station so its easy to explore from there. There are some great restaurants in the area so no problems finding a place to eat.The rooms are nice and large. They have free wifi which worked well. The bathrooms are large as well. The rooms and design of the hotel are pretty dated, and definitely have a 60s/70s feel, but the décor and amenities are modern and up to date. The lobby is very large and the grounds are nice. The staff at the hotel is friendly and helpful, although the English is somewhat limited. I would be happy to stay here again.

I've stayed here for 4times. beautiful garden, i can enjoy a walk. nice staffs, always giving me good responses for my requests. I tried Sauna and Bath at Sakura tower befor check in. 2000yen for staying customers. quiet and peace. Just what i wanted. hope they have coffee in the rooms and water but u can get it with reasonable price at convinience store on ground floor.Lobby lounge, i prefer Takanawa(the hotel next door) but Shintakanawa's room r much better. walking distance for OUTBACK, ROYAL HOST, Shingaporian restaurant.

Rooms are spacious and well appointed. A small gift shop and 7-11 off the huge spacious lobby. Great shopping just steps away plus so many restaurants. A grocery with all kinds of prepared foods and great sushi at a reasonable price. Also offer 500 yen if you participate in their green program where you do not have the maids come clean your room. This can be spent in their shops. Train station just a short walk from the hotel. Also has a lovely garden connecting another of their hotes nearby.

It is a huge hotel, lobby always busy for guests check in and out, neat interiors, nice room with more than enough space for triple sharing, great buffet breakfast, helpful & accommodating staff, and good location - near Shinagawa Station.

Stayed here in December and it was amazing! Room was spacious and had a balcony. Staff was helpful. Walking distance to shinagawa station. A shuttle bus takes you to Disneyland. I loved the little pet shop on the way down to the station. Will stay again!

Couldn't fault the hotel, great location, friendly staff. Neat and tidy. The rooms were always cleaned, even offered an incentive to not have the room cleaned everyday, a 500 yen coupon. All enquiries were answered promptly. A short walk down to Shinagawa St made commuting a breeze, with plenty of restaurants in the surrounding area and only a short walk over the train line.

My first time to Japan and stayed at Grand Prince New Takanawa for 4 nights. Great location in reasonably quiet area, yet just a short walk down to train station, restaurants and shops - perfect!Hotel is large and rooms are fantastic with balconies. You can also use facilities at the two other Prince hotels in the complex, there is a Japanese Bath House in one and good restaurants in the other, although there is plenty of choice for dining at Grand Prince New Takanawa.Really good value and prince location.

The hotel is conveniently located, 7 minutes from Shinagawa station. I stayed at this hotel during the week days (not weekend) and the rate was comparable to most of the small Japanese hotels in the area. I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the room, making this hotel stay the most value for money for the area. There are plenty of restaurants around and many convenience stores. I chose not to have breakfast at the hotel as there are many options near Shinagawa station, some with great coffee. Room came with free wifi and quite a few English TV channels. Staff were very friendly, particularly the guest relations desk staff. I will definitely stay at this hotel again.

Stayed here for 8 nights. 5 minute walk from Shinagawa station. The walk is up hill so if you'd rather take a taxi they are available right at the station exit. Most taxis start at 730 yen. So it shouldn't cost much at all and worth it if you have heavy luggages.We stayed on the 12th floor-amazing view of the city! Some rooms will allow a view of the tokyo tower as well.Every morning you can hear crows and crickets(only if you open your balcony window)otherwise windows are soundproof if you don't want to hear it.The room was a pretty good size. Beds are comfortable and the bathroom was very nice. We ordered room service for breakfast which took about 40mins each time but worth the wait.Also, there is a seven eleven convenience store available in the hotel and they provide a variety of food plates. The area itself has a lot of restaurants including T.G.I.F and Outback.We utilized the pool on the last day, but you have to pay to go in. Not worth the price.The hotel also has a beautiful garden I would recommend going there around 6pm.Hotel provides airport transfer however it's not free. It costs about 3,100 yen per person. Overall, a great experience will definitely stay here again!

Very good hotel. Good fornitures.Big and clean rooms with large lavatories.Free in-room wifi.Very good breakfast, lunch and dinner (lots of restaurants).Inner and big smoking area with AC.Super gentle and experienced staff.Only flaw: far from city center, near Shinagawa station, where you have to take JR circle line and then change for subways. No hotel's shuttle to station, 7/8 minutes walking uphill.

Was trying to pick a hotel near a Shinkansen station so I wouldn't need to change trains with the kids before taking the Shinkansen. Not many hotels offered triple rooms near Shinagawa. Picked this one after reading the reviews and it proved to be a good choice. Stayed for 3 nights. The room (we were in a triple room) was spacious and there's a convenience store in the hotel. There's a shuttle bus to and from the station which was great for us as we didn't have our strollers and walking uphill back to the hotel with 2 kids after a long day out would have been uneasy. The shuttle needs to be booked if you are heading to the station but not if you are heading to the hotel from the station. Will stay again.

This is a nice but very dated property, it is part of a large complex of several Prince hotels with the New Takanawa located at the top of the hill from the Shinagawa Train station. There are several pools and restaurants and the rooms are large by Tokyo standards. The price was very good for such a large property, however the location is rather unusual, it is in a residential neighborhood, so there is really nothing interesting to do within walking distance.If you need to be in Takanawa or need quick access to the Shinkansen then the location is perfect, except the hike up the hill, otherwise I would not suggest staying here.

Service good but rooms seemed to lack coffee machine, mini bar and water. The bar downstairs had a good atmosphere but the whole place kind of felt empty.Probably would not stay again.Staff were helpful and friendly.Breakfast started at 6:30 and I skipped as I was leaving at 6:15.

Stayed for 4 nights on a business trip, was very good with easy access in and out of the hotel, train station being down the road . Hotel was clean and tidy, I stayed here before the date i have put here as only got round to writing this now. Service was good but we did have a few language problems ( expected as i dont speak Japanese ) easy to get around though. Enjoyed my stay there and would have no problem returning.

On a trip to Tokyo we had lunch at this hotel. It is a modern building situated in lovely gardens.The meal, which was cooked before us, was delicious and the service first class. Although it wasn't Kobe beef it was still very tender.

Just returned from a 10 day trip to Japan which involved a quick trip to Kyoto from Tokyo. We chose to stay at the Grand Prince because of the proximity to the Shinagawa Station where we could easily catch the bullet train to Kyoto. The hotel was great, staff were very friendly and accommodating. I was particularly impressed with the incredible hospitality extended to their guests which allowed luggage storage for up to 10 days. I was travelling with my 11 year old granddaughter and was able to leave 2 extra suitcases there while in Kyoto. On our return we were given a private room to repack before our trip back to Canada. Very much appreciated

foreword:stayed 1 night at the hotel for convenience as it's one of the pick-up location for our 2 days 1 night mt fuji and hakone tourit's a value for money hotel. not bad but not WOW either.the good:- hotel lobby is the pick up location of tour- walking distance to shinagawa station- quite a good view of the tokyo tower from the balcony- value for money (this hotel was the only hotel during our travel date that's within our budget)the bad:- UPHILL walk from shinagawa station to the hotel! facilities/amenities:- didn't try any as we only stayed for 1 night- the lobby is quite big? LOL- the hotel looks outdated but kept clean and somehow well maintained- no international power outlets but they went to lend us 3-pin plugs (we forgot to bring our own)staff/service:staff speaks quite good english and they are very friendlytoilets: clean but SMALL. they provided a lot of bathroom amenities (i super like japanese hotels providing a mini hair brush) and of course, we love the warm toilet seats! cleanliness: as expected from a japanese hotel, very cleansleep quality:8/10. comfy bed not too soft, not too hard.. just nice! (like baby bear's bed)

We were allocated the hotel as part of a package holiday but were pleasantly surprised. There is more than one hotel, interconnected by a beautiful Japanese garden, which you are free to use the facilities including some 6 or 7 restaurants, although we only used 2, the restaurant in the Grand Prince is buffet style eat all you can with a good selection of both International & Japanese food, there are discounts if you are staying at the hotel & also if you're a senior citizen. Really well located with a short walk to Shinagawa station which is very well connected. Staff were really helpful & helped us find our way round Tokyo using the different rail lines, even helping us get to central Tokyo so we could use the open top bus tours that are available.
user_name:
Dave O
Milton Keynes, United Kingdom

review_body: I stayed here for alomost 9 days for business purpose. The hotel is located very strategically which is near the Shinagawa staiton. It is only a 5 to 7 min walk from the hotel. From the airport you can easily take a Limo bus which charges around 2100 yen and drops you right in front of the hotel. The reception is huge and looks are grand. The hotel rooms are spacious no doubt given the scenario where most of the rooms in Japan are very small. But the rooms are not very well maintained, and i did encounter some kind of flies everytime in the room. If you are hungry and think to eat something from the mini bar then please know that except tea there is nothing. Along with water which is chargeable. Anyways tap water in Japan are credited that can be easily consumed. The In room dining menu also needs to have a little more variety. There is a timing for getting some kind of stuff through the day. Though you may just go down and there is a seven eleven in case you want to munch on anything. The hotel has different restaurants like, Chinese, Japanese etc. The spread of the breakfast at Mermolad is just okay, not much to choose on. You would also find quiet a few restaurants outside the hotel at a walking distance. Overall though a good hotel i think they need to do more on the in room furnishing.

This time, I would like to share my recent experience in staying at Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa. Both of me and my friend arrived at Shinagawa (Shinkansen) station and proceeded directly to Takanawa (West) exit. Once we exit the station until we reach the main intersection, it is a 5-6 minutes walk. It is quite a challenging walk if someone carries heavy luggage with him/her as the street is going slightly uphill.Once we reached the hotel, we went up 1 floor to the lobby and once we exit from the elevator, turn right and we could see a huge size hotel lobby quite a bit of walk from where the elevator was. Check-in was done within ten minutes of our arrival at the front desk. They assigned our room in 12th floor almost in the end of the hallway which was quite a walk as well. One unusual thing I found when I looked at the room number : Our room was in 12th floor but the room number started with 32xx where the last two digits reflected the room number.Our room was acceptable in size, nothing to complain about; after all, we stayed in Japan and small hotel rooms was something we had to deal with and accept when we stayed at many hotels. However, the bathroom was slightly bigger than normal hotels which was quite nice as we had extra space to move around but still could not be compared to bathroom in Grand Pacific Le Daiba which was larger than this one.Our room was clean : Although this hotel obviously showed its age but it was very well maintained. The nicest thing was the fact that they had tiny balcony just outside each room. Since our room was located in 12th floor, we could still get a nice view overlooking Shinagawa's area both during the day and night. One thing I liked about this hotel was their lounge : It was nicely designed overlooking their famous garden.It was a peaceful experience sitting down in their lounge and enjoyed the garden from where we were sitting. Their design reminded me with the ones in Shangri-La Hotels where they designed many of their lounges with similar design (glass from floor to ceilings overlooking gardens). I didn't have any chance to try out the breakfast as we had other things to do during the the next morning and both of us checked out very early from the hotel, after two nights stay, as we had to take Narita Express to Narita International Airport early in the morning that day. However, I will not be so surprised that the food quality in this hotel is better than average by looking at the way they run such massive hotel in this location. FYI, this hotel is located in a huge parcel of land which shared by 3~4 other hotels owned by the same company (if I am not mistaken). Overall, I would recommend this hotel to every one who is looking classy yet elegant hotel accommodation nearby Shinagawa station. This hotel property is not a new one but it is very well maintained and someone could experience a bit of Japanese culture in this hotel.

This hotel was born in 70's as one of the most popular hotel in Tokyo with spacious rooms, large bed, great location, as the leading hotel of the Prince Hotel Group in Tokyo. It has become old, and it's no more the best hotel in Tokyo, but has undergone renovation several years ago and now it's a good value for money !!

5 minute walk from Shinagawa train station. Big hotel. We had a large room on the 12th floor. We were given 2 twin beds which were very comfortable. The room was quiet and dark. Compact bathroom. Each floor had an ice machine. ATM on the ground floor. Also a convenience store which had items at a reasonable price. In the evenings there is a piano player in the lounge. Efficient check in (and out). Also we were allowed to check in a couple of hours early.

It is walking distance from shinagawa train station, has few indian restaurants nearby like Devi and salmatikka. The Staff is very coooperative. Room size is adequate with tea coffee maker in the room. You can open balcony door for fresh air. Breakfast time is 6;30 - 10 at marmolada restaurant in B1, you can book Airport limousine from reception. Has a 7 eleven withinthe elevator area within the hotel. Has a very good garden....

I stayed for one night in this hotel for a business trip. The hotel seems aged, very clinical with a huge lobby but a bit lifeless, the reception is fitted with rows of chairs, making it look like the waiting line to renew your driving license. The staff is friendly but the check in process seems complicated, with vouchers and papers being handed over to you (e.g. for breakfast). Could be handled differently in the land of technology?The rooms are quite a walk away, same goes for breakfast (which offers a good variety though). The location is great, just a couple of minutes away from a train hub so loads of options to eat out and get around.

1. Walking distance from Shinagawa station with a slope. So with walking issue for pple (elderly or children) dont consider this hotel but after meal with couples or friend this hotel suit you. Walking about 5 mins to the Shinagawa station and another station call Takanawa. If you buy alot of thing from the mall, you may need to carry alot of thg down.2. Facilities, they not using the Japan hse brand shower gel and shampoo, pls bring your own or can purchase from the shop above MacDonald. It rather cheap there.3.
