I met an earthquake and I stay at level 16. Mag 8.5 from 600KM away, you are safe. 4. Balcony got good view of sky tree (if i not wrong) but when u stay more than 2 days, that view is normal.5. Service, i could said, english and chinese should not be any major issue for them.6. room with bath tub and basic bath stuff is ready for u.. 7. Good wifi, seldom lag.

Spacious Room, Large Bed, friendly staff and most importantly it is at a great location. There is also a convenience store at the ground floor. Good value for money. I won't mind staying again if I am traveling on business to Tokyo.

Very Negatively impressed by this hotelBreakfast: A) long lines (first time in my life I experienced lines for bfast longer than 2 min)B) food: poor in selection, quality and tasteC) service: practically not existent- they don't serve you even a tea nor a coffee (actually the first day they even run out of hot water and had to beg for it in the kitchen) ServiceA) I had to extend one day my stay and they moved me to a downgraded room (no complementary water nor bath rob....very weird way to differentiate) but at the same rate...B) Very long in every process: check in - check out - request of infoNo wonder there are also lines in the lobbyRoomsOld and not really niceProsClose to station

This is a great hotel. Lovely rooms in a good size. Breakfast was enjoyable but the line could be a little long at times later in the morning. Convenient shuttle bus to the station area was so helpful. Staff very attentive. I would happily stay again.

Big hotel and at 8 am the lobby looks like a subway station...people streaming all round. Rooms are big, comfortable and purposefully designed. Train station is nearby. For Breakfast do go to marmaloda restaurant as it has a bigger spread than the Chinese tohri restaurant. And for breakfast the queues are big and do add that time when planning the day.

We stayed at this hotel after a cruise. It is really three hotels in one and is well organised with public areas wider than some roads. Our room was on the sixth floor and we were taken there by a "fast" lift. The room had two double beds in it and was spacious. The bathroom had a bath and shower as well as an "electric" toilet. You could adjust the water pressure and temperature and also use the toilet as a bidet. Food at the hotel was fine with self service for breakfast at different places. A separate evening meal was more "Japan style" which had to be paid for. Try the "Patio" restaurant for the evening meal. There is a standard meal for 3000 Yen (£15-00). To explore Tokyo it is best to book a trip within the hotel, make sure that the trip will bring you back to the hotel as some drop you at a railway station and leave you to find your own way back.

Fantastic location - a few minute walk to Shinagawa station -- easy to grab a local JR train,subway or even the Shinkansen. room was HUGE and LOVELY! Modern sleek and clean. More than comfortable. I really loved this hotel and I would absolutely stay here again. Breakfast buffet included in the price we paid and there were very many choices Western and Japanese. Lots of restaurants near the hotel - even an Outback Steakhouse and a TGI Fridays if you decide you want a burger.

This hotel exceeded our expectations. We stayed in a large double room on floor 12 with a small balcony overlooking the swimming pool. The hotel is surrounded by lovely gardens and only a short walk down to the tube station of Shinagawa which made travelling to different parts of the city very easy. Breakfast was very good and ample choice. All of the staff spoke very good English and a special tour desk was available for booking trips. Would certainly stay at this hotel again and would recommend to our friends. A very quiet hotel but easily accessible to all parts of Tokyo.

The hotel is within walking distance of Shinagawa station where you can get the Narita express, the Shinkansen, the rail to Haneda and all JR metro trains. This was our second visit to the hotel, the last time some four years ago, and it maintains a high standard.The facility is clean, well kept and excellently maintained.The efficient reception with staff that actually both speaks and understands English gives you a friendly welcome, and you are shown to a big (very big for Japan) room with all amenities.Next to the lobby you find a small 7 eleven if you are "self catering".In the surrounding area you find a number of restaurants, but when it comes to price and quality the food centre at and across from the station is unbeatable.All in all, in Tokyo you can hardly get a better total deal, price, quality, location and surroundings. Whatever you want to visit you need to travel a bit wherever you stay in this huge city.

Stayed 3 nights as part of a cruise package. This hotel is enormous with acres of open wasted space, little comfort, no lounge or seating areas. Very expensive, dark, depressing bar area. Coffee shop in lobby had the only comfortable seating in the place but very limited opening times. Limited opening of restaurants. No breakfast after 10 am and no dinner after 9 pm. Could not check in the group before 2 pm and had to check out at 11pm. Many people not leaving until the evening but apart from luggage storage absolutely no facilities provided for comfort. A day room could easily have been laid on. Staff however very efficient but totally inflexible. This hotel is probably fine for conferences, large weddings and one night stopovers but totally unsuitable for holiday makers and tourists.Rooms reasonably sized and well appointed

It's a huge hotel in a business district, so there's not much (nothing) to do there. Close to a major JR hub, Shinagawa, the location is really good for transit travelers. The hotel is pretty close to Takanawadai subway station (5 mins walk). The room was quite spacious by Japanese standards. With a good balcony view. The hotel has an affordable convenience store and some cafes and restaurants on the premises. Edelweiss Cafe is a great choice for breakfast and coffee. All but some of the reception staff were very polite, considerate and helpful. Direct shuttle limousine direct buses to Haneda and Narita airports. Free shuttle to Shinagawa station.

I arrived at the hotel and was greeted quickly by reception. My room was read early and I was grateful! At the time of check in I asked about the airport limousine to the airport and requested a reservation for 1:15 pm the next day. I also asked which terminal my airline was in because the schedule shows arrival time based on the terminal. I was provided accurate information and proceeded to my room. The room was spacious, clean, and all rooms seem to have a balcony, at least on the side I was on. I toured the 5 acres of gardens which were peaceful. The stores and restaurants on site leave a lot to be desired for quality and price. Research local restaurants and eat elsewhere. I ate at the Chinese restaurant and everything is priced for two! Yes, I could have gone elsewhere, but Chinese was the only choice in the hotel I was interested in. After a serving of braised chili shrimp that was lukewarm, I was disappointed. The crab fried rice was excellent! The steam vegetables for one were tasteless, unseasoned eggplant, carrots, mushrooms, sweet potato, bok choy, and okra..........don't order it. I love veggies but this was a very poor presentation at $8 US just for the vegetables.A problem with communication was experienced in two instances. I changed my airport limo bus reservation from 1:15 to 12:15 p.m. after receiving notice from the airline that the flight time had been moved up 20 minutes. I asked for the reception desk and for someone that spoke English. The lady changing the reservation sounded like the same on that checked me in 3 hours earlier. The next morning at 10:30 I arranged for my luggage to be picked up from my room at noon. I was assured that the bell staff would be there at noon. I was headed out to eat and I paid for the limo bus to the airport and was asked to sign a document to pick up my tickets at the bell desk. I signed the document without reading it and picked up my ticket. I returned to my room at 11: 30 am and waited for the bellman. At noon I called for the bell man and talked to reception. Long story short, they arrived at 12:05 asking which airport I was going to (I gave this information and the airline at check in the day before, that's how I knew which terminal I needed to go to). They tagged my bags, took them to the bell stand and I waited outside for the bus it is now 12:10 p.m... I saw the bus arrive. I waited for my luggage and then the bus took off without me or my luggage. I immediately asked the bell desk what happened. They said my reservation is for 1:15!!!! UGH!!! I explained the change in reservation the previous day and asked what could they do since my flight was at 5 pm and the airport is an hour away and I had an international flight. Then I looked at the paper I signed which stated that my reservation was 2:15!!! If I signed a form for 2:15 why was my luggage tagged for 1:15? Get all critical communications IN WRITING!All communication issues aside, the hotel had great little gift shops on sight an their sister properties for last minute gifts. The shopping at the hotel is on the lobby level and B1 has larger stores.A good cheap breakfast, and possibly other meals can be found down the hill and across the street at Royal Host. The service is excellent and so is the coffee and the food. There are several restaurants in the area by foot and car.

Lot's of tourist buses and business functions. Lobby huge, impersonal. Room was good size and clean. Rugs very tired. Food options are limited. Staff appeared a bit worn out from the constant large group business functions and tourist buses. Not a bad experience, just not that memorable. Other Prince properties in the area looked better.

Pro's: Big rooms, wifi is good, friendly staff and they try hard, location close to station, grounds are nice, lots of dining options close by.Con's: Dated rooms, convention style hotel, communication in English to desk staff can be a problem.Can't beat convenience, but there are better hotels in the area for this price point.

I have stayed 3 nights in this hotel, not really my kind of hotel, it is huge and impersonal. Please take note that if you are late in the morning, don't even think about going for breakfast, there is always a huge queue and it can take up to 30 minutes before you are seated. The rooms are big for a Japanese standard and clean, bathroom was renovated in mine. It is walking distance to the train station which is a +.Don't forget to visit the garden, which is simply beautiful.

We stayed here for 3 nights at the end of March 2015. The hotel is about 7 minutes walk up a hill from Shibuya station. The station has loads of clothes shops and food supermarkets for your convenience, which is nice. There is also a few nice restaurants in walking distance.The hotel is a bit dated but very clean, with a newsagents next to the lobby. A regular shuttle can transfer you to Shibuya station to save you the walk but you need to pre book your place on the shuttle to avoid disappointment,Room was a good size and the the Shisheido toiletries were a nice bonus.Sadly the staff do not speak much english at all, which did cause a few problems with luggage transfer but apart from that I cant complain.There is a pool outside which looked lovely but only for use in the summer months.

There is a problem on privacy in this hotel. If you make some noise in your room , the hotel staff can come inside your room without even knocking without even asking permission to come in. They just rush inside the room then and scold you. They even demanding not requesting but demanding to keep quiet....... Will never stay in this hotel again. Very rude staff i think he is also the manager

Intentionally booked this hotel for my Tokyo trip, knowing that it is not near to the touristy areas like Shinjuku, Shibuya, etc but mainly for the spacious size of the room. Was definitely not disappointed upon check in! The room not only offered me with very big space, comfortable bed to rest my tired body and legs after much walking and shopping, it even has a balcony overlooking the premise's garden lined with Cherry Blossom trees! Unfortunately, they were not in blooming season during my time there otherwise the view would have been tremendously beautiful!Loved their Shiseido toiletries which provided a nice scent and gave enough moisture which made my hair looked silky and hydrated throughout my entire stay.Thumbs up for the shuttle bus service provided between Shinagawa station and the hotel. This will be useful for the elderly or people with children/luggages. However, even when the service has ended by 2130 hours, I've enjoyed the upslope stroll back to hotel within 10mins on late nights. It was a good choice staying here as getting to Haneda Airport was fast and cheap using the Keikyu plus airport line. And getting around all other parts of Tokyo from here was relatively quick and easy for one who has a relaxing itinerary as well.Only negative feedback was that the hotel does not provide complimentary bottled drinking water, where I have never experienced before in all other hotels.

There's nothing really special about the hotel itself. It is an old hotel. (Updates have been made to the rooms. Some of them at least.) there's a 7-11on the lobby floor which is nice to get late night snacks and beverages. The service is great but that is typical of japan. There are a couple things I do really like about this hotel. One, unlike the other prince hotels in the area, this hotel has a balcony. The rooms in japan run small so I usually like to place my suitcase on the balcony. Also good because the rooms can get humid if someone takes a hot shower. The rooms don't smell like mold or an ashtray. Shinagawa prince and takanawa prince both had those issues. I read somewhere that the location wasn't good. I think the walk to the station is pretty short. Just don't go from the the lobby exit. There is a side exit. Just ask where the bakery is (1 flight of stairs down on the side of hotel). Go out, make a left and walk straight down to the station. Shinagawa is a major station and has food counters, shopping, and restaurants in the station. Easy to get in and out of. Just buy a 140 yen ticket from the ticket machine. There's also restaurants on top of Queen's Isetan (instead of going past the ticketing counter on the right, go straight and you'll see the entrance on the left of the Queen's sign.Back to the hotel. The lounge is always empty and the bar is dull. There's other restaurants in the hotel but they're not great. I always go down and choose from the many restaurants around the station.

Stayed in the hotel close to the Shinagawa station in Oct 2014. Travelled as tourists with my Mom and stayed for 4 nights. The hotel is strategically located close to the Shinagawa station, so was very convinient to reach after our trips on the Shinkansen(Bullet train) to Kyoto and Mt. Fuji. The breakfast spread was elaborate, but a bit crowded on weekends with long queues for the breakfast.The decor of the rooms were a bit dated and could do with some overhaul. Best part of the hotel and true for most of Japan I say was the hi-tech toilet seats, which I have not seen in any other part of the world! Is located as an annexe to the older Grand Prince Takanawa with a Japanese garden separating the two! Only Con: The climb from the Shinagawa train station to the hotel could be slightly uphill :(Overall a good hotel, but a bit more expensive than the older Grand Prince Takanawa.

As mentioned in my other review, I stayed one week in Tokyo; two days in Grand Prince and the rest in Prince Sakura.The grand Prince is good, rooms are clean and spacious but in everything you can see it is a convention center hotel.There's a seven eleven convenience store in the hotel which is...convenient... But for a breakfast you have to go around.Due to the location I believe it is an excellent place and has helpful staff.I recommend this hotel for the convenience and proper business standards.

The rooms though are quite big compared to the other hotels I stayed in Japan. We had the Superior twin room. Bathroom amenities were complete except for the body lotion. It is not located in a convenient location. The train station is about 10 min away. Not too bad except that we had to pull our luggage all the way there. Shinjuku and Shibuya are not very close by.

Our travel agent booked this hotel after being briefed that we needed wheelchair access. When we arrived my husband's chair could not fit through the door and we were told every single room in the huge hotel had the same size bathroom door. This seems amazing as the hotel is new and has thousands of rooms! There is also not a single wheelchair accessible toilet in the whole hotel despite it being a popular convention centre. Luckily my husband came up with a work around and we used the desk chair which was on wheels to locate in the bathroom and he had to transfer on to this for every bathroom visit - not ideal! The staff were helpful but the whole complex was rather impersonal and lacked warmth. It is conveniently located 5 minutes from Shinagawa Station which is on the Yamanote line. Our deluxe rooms were quite spacious and clean.

Excellent hotel & facilities. Good location for business, taxi ride to industrial areas.I tried the steakhouse on site, it was the best I have had.Train station is very close to use the circular 'green' Tokyo line

Stayed here for the first time from 20-22 Feb 2015. We have booked a twin room on my friend's corporate rates which was about $160 SGD per night without breakfast. We were given a room at the 2nd floor facing the inner garden of another hotel. It was quiet and has lots of privacy from the balcony. Though not much sun. The hotel is situated on a slope about 10mins walk from Shinagawa JR station. If you are carrying large luggages, my advice is to utilize their free shuttle bus that leaves every 20-30mins. Room's thermostat doesn't seems to be working during our stay. We have to open the balcony door to cool down the room during that period of time which was still cold in Feb. Bed mattress was kinda soft for japanese standards. Pillows were too flat even with 2. Room size was consider big for japanese standards. The usual japanese hotels' amenities were available. Nothing extra ordinary. Although the rooms were recently renovated but the bath room seems dated. Lobby was huge as it is part of the conventional centre. Not too much of late night cheap eateries around the hotel. Overall, for the price we paid, it's worth staying for a short period. It was comfortable and quiet. But not the best location if you want to shop.

My wife and I stayed in this hotel in Feb 24-25, 2015. We were thinking that it was not so bad about the location of the hotel, because it can be reach in 7 min. from and to Shinagawa station by the shuttle bus of the hotel which a lot of frequencies. We can say that hotel services and other things are not so difference compare with another hotels.

Arrived here with 2 companions, and we stayed for 2 nights in a western-style double room with an additional bed on level 4 in week 2 of Feb 2015.Our room was very nice and it came furnished with exceptionally comfortable beds, cable tv, mini safe, mini fridge, and a complete set of large-sized toiletries (i.e. Shisedo bath gel, shampoo, and hair-conditioner). There was a balcony from which we can enjoy views of the quiet surroundings and the pretty Japanese garden down below. And this was here where I saw a security staff doing his round patrolling the garden compound which was very reassuring.WiFi connection here is very good, and we were also provided with complimentary English-languaged newspapers daily (i.e. The Japan News). There is a small convenience store that's open from 0700 ~ 2300 daily, and it is helpfully located on the ground floor of the mini in-house shopping strip (just next to the central lift lobby). The hotel offers security safes behind the reception lobby of which guests can use to help temporarily store valuables upon check-out. For smokers, there is a spacious smoking room after you make your way past the doors on the right side of the hotel's main entrance.Location is pretty good - just about a 200m stroll from JR Shinagawa station, but the hotel also provides complimentary minibus rides to and from there. Just fyi, this minibus makes its round to pick up guests from the other two sister Grand Prince hotels just down the street before arriving at the bustling train station. To get directly to and from Narita / Haneda airport, you can also opt to catch the hotel's airport shuttle bus which is available at a fee and at designated timings.

Have visited first time Tokyo & stayed at this place, found that the hotel is quite & calm, there is no hustle bustle of crowded roads as it is located on a hill far from main road, nice & friendly staff.. best part is that its got a Japanese garden behind the hotel.. which is beautiful & calm.I was on a business trip & most of the lunch & dinners were organised out & far by the office team, hence I haven't tried food at this hotel, so no comments. Over all it can be termed as Very good in terms of rooms & amenities provided inside the room... sleep quality is good !!!

Much better options are nearby. I stayed one night and was very happy to leave the next day.Pros: Free lounge with a fairly standard room with some beer and low end breakfast options. Many eating options on the Prince campus.8 min walk to Shinagawa station if you know which Prince hotel on the campus to go to. don't be tricked in that there are two GP hotel Takanawa with the difference of this one being 'new'Cons: Room was clearly older and not as nice as I've experienced in the area. the AC did not work leaving me to have the window open all night. Instead of windows, there are doors that open onto a balcony that is a metal thing screwed into the building. I didn't trust it based on the rest of the room, and would not bring my kids to the room for that specific reason. Overall, hot room, restless night, older furniture with wear, long lines trying to check out...no reason to return.

We stayed here for 1 night on arrival in. Japan due to the proximity of Shinagowa station. rooms were very clean and quite spacious although slightly dated. The staff were brilliant so helpful and polite. the Japanese garden is lovely

It is my third visit to this hotel having previously stayed here on 2 occasions.This time i was very late to arrive and my travelling party were not in the hotel leaving me without a key to the room. The concierge was very nice to offer me a telephone for me to call them. The lobby is very comfortably warmed even on a chilly night.The garden is a draw for those who have no time to go to the nearby parks. It is very well manicured and quiet. Even a short stroll is enough to get away from the busy nearby Shinagawa area.Room was as usual very clean and neat. Bed is comfortable as far as business hotels go.I'll still choose it when i next stay in this area.

While we only stayed overnight in this hotel it was greatly appreciated. We had just spent 9 hours on trains coming from Nagasaki to Shinagawa and the Hotel's reception staff were extremely helpful and understanding, the Bell boy was extremely talkative and knowledgeable on the history of the Hotel. The room was great, beautiful view from the balcony and the fact the they have an on-site 7-11 was extremely convenient.We would definitely recommend this hotel

This hotel has big rooms with sane standard as in South East Asia 4-5 star hotels. For European and American travellers, this is the best hotel. Each room has a balcony! I stayed at 15th floor and was great! A little quiet in the evening and a lot of space within the hotel. Unfortunately there is no proper lounge bar to relax. There was one bar on the ground floor but was booked for event and hotel residents cannot use. Short walk from Shinagawa station. Bonus.

Stayed for 2 nights.I love its:1. Clean rooms, bedding, toilet & its accompany amenities2. Its greenery. Nice garden with small touches of greenery located throughout3. 10mins walk to Shinagawa JR station, which is actually on the main Yamanote Line (10mins to Shibuya, 20mins to Shinjuku). Hotel provides shuttle service every 20mins till 10pm. But its ok to walk.4, Breakfast was quite impressive. Loved it mini croissants.5. 7-Eleven at lobby that opens till 1am. Easy to get your snacks and drinks anytime. I sort of dislike its:1. Only 1 Eng channel (Movie Plus). Despite all other Jap channels in HD. 2. Aircon/heater does not seem to be working. I'm assuming its cos of winter, thus the system is not operational. Had to sleep with balcony door slightly open to let the fresh cold night air in. I guess this hotel caters more to the business group as there is tons of them in the hotel.

Great location and connected to narita express from Shinagawa station, only afew stops from shibuya and shinjuku!! Clean and spacious room.... There's also a 7-11 within the hotel which is convenient and great!! There's also a Singapore seafood restaurant at opposite Shinagawa station.

My husband and I were assigned a room with 2 beds because there were no other rooms available. I couldn't complain because I got this at a great deal from Japanican. Our roundtrip shinkansen tickets from Osaka to Tokyo came with accommodations at a very cheap price. The hotel was a long uphill walk from the Shinagawa station and is especially tough if you have huge luggage like ours. We didn't mind since it's winter season during our travel and they also offer shuttle services to and from the nearest station so we took advantage of that during our stay. The room was so big and it had a tub!!! I was so surprised because I expected really small rooms in Tokyo. It even had a balcony!!! The garden was awesome too so we took a lot of pictures there. The staff were very courteous as well. I would gladly return to this hotel with the same deal from Japanican in the future. I am very satisfied with our stay and have recommended it to friends and family.

It's clean and near from shinagawa station.It's clean and near from shinagawa station.It's clean and near from shinagawa station.It's clean and near from shinagawa station.It's clean and near from shinagawa station.It's clean and near from shinagawa station.

Stayed here a few days ago and satisfied with the property. The hotel is located (quite) near to Shinagawa station that has a few train lines and is a Shinkansen station beside the crowded Tokyo Station. There's a shuttle bus that arrives every few mins (the schedule is at the wall across Kinokuniya éntree). There are 3 hotels in a huge complex so you should know which hotel you go to. In the hotel, there's a beautiful garden that has quite good lighting at night. The hotel itself is looks a bit old but still in a great condition. The room itself is spacious. It also has a balcony on every room. It has a big Sony TV but only have channels in Japanese (there are VODs,tho). The bathroom we're in was great also. If I'm not mistaken, the floor was made of wood (I kinda forgot this part). And they have Shiseido shampoo, conditioner and body wash in a huge dispenser. So you don't need to bring your own amenities :p. We had breakfast in mamalama or mamalobo I forgot. The restaurant is located a bit far for the room. We had to walk across the lobby and go down 1 level. But the selections in the restaurants is great! The only cons I experienced was the hotel is quite far from any convenience store so it's a good thing to grab your food or snacks from Shinagawa station

My travel agent booked this hotel. It was the first hotel at which I stayed in Japan, and initially I was satisfied with it, assuming that this is what Japanese hotels were like. However, after having travelled for two weeks in Japan, and then staying at this hotel again at the end of the trip, I came to the conclusion that this hotel is overpriced for what you are getting, the maintenance of the hotel is substandard by Japanese standards (which are very high, in general) and there are likely better options in Tokyo.Pros:- Beautiful garden setting- Reasonable room size- Outstanding breakfast buffet (extra cost)- Clean (the staff did the best they could given the condition of the rooms).Cons:- Furniture in both my rooms needed either replacement or cleaning. (The upholstery was stained).- The bathroom, quite simply, smelled, in both rooms (as the previous reviewer also noted). I kept the door closed for that reason.- The hotel is a long way from the Shinagawa station. This becomes a bit of an issue if you are carrying luggage with you.- There are no nearby restaurants or shops. For that, you need to make the trek down to the Shinagawa station area about two or three blocks away.Shinagawa station itself is an excellent base from which to explore Tokyo, and it also has very good access to the Tokyo airports. There are quite a few restaurants and shops in the immediate area of the station. I would stay in this area again, but would probably select a different hotel. For example, the Keikyu Ex hotel is directly across from the Shinagawa station (much more convenient) and costs appear to be similar, so I might try that instead next time.

The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is located in a vast complex which encompasses a few other Prince Group hotels. It has a large garden within its property. And its about 10 minutes walk to the well-connected Shinagawa Train Station. The uphill walk from the train station to the hotel maybe a little strenuous for some people.I had a bad check-in experience with a rude staff. When asked for a second room key card, the answer was a very stern "NO", no apology or any kind reply. Confused, I repeated my question and was given the same stern "NO" answer.The room is pretty small and the ceiling is low, maybe it's a standard Japanese specification. I feel a little claustrophobic in the room. The carpet in both my rooms and along the corridor need a bad shampoo and thorough vacuuming. Fortunately there're sandals provided for the room, otherwise I'll be very worried about stepping on the carpet. To compliment the small size of the room, the bathroom can only accommodate only one person at a time. And the bathtub should have a new coat or be replaced. I would not allow my family to soak in that bathtub. Maybe due to the use of the flooring material in the bathroom, there's a persistent urine smell that refuses to go away, even after extended ventilation. And this happened in both our rooms.Room service is bad. Not kids friendly at all. No kids menu, food items selection is limited, no lunch hour room service, uncompromising service attitude (cannot make changes to food item to accommodate kids' taste), "Prince One" service button on the telephone is useless, behaved like a phone operator function.Somehow, I just feel that this hotel is not very friendly towards foreigners in terms of its facility and its service attitude.I wouldn't recommend this hotel for family travellers, especially foreigners travelling with young family.

We stayed two nights in this hotel en route to skiing in Hakuba. We have 3 children and needed a two and a three bedroom apartment. Not many Japanese hotels can provide a three bedroom apartment, so this suited us well. It is conveniently located about ten minutes from the Shinagawa Railway station, which is on the JR route from Narita airport and provides easy access to lots of the areas of Tokyo one wishes to visit. The staff were helpful and polite. The rooms were of a good size. I would stay there again.

It was so nice to have a room that was big enough to accommodate party of 3. Usually when extra bed is added, there is no room to place luggage and walk around. There was plenty of room to relax. Would definitely recommend.

Just back from a two week holiday in Japan during which we stayed at The Grand Prince hotel for five nights. We were given a very spacious room on the 12th floor with excellent views of the Shinagawa area from our balcony.We didn't get to try the hotel restaurants as there are plenty of good restaurants only a five minute walk away, however we did have breakfast at Edelweiss cafe a few times and were impressed with their buffet breakfast of salad and pastries for a very reasonable 1100 yen (approx. $11) The room we had was large by Japanese standards and well appointed in all regards. What really impressed us though was the outstanding service provided by all members of their staff, in particular the very helpful members who attended reception. Many thanks to all for making our stay so enjoyable,we will be back next year and will be happy to stay with you again.

The hotel (different than the Prince Hotel located nearby) is very comfortable with large bedrooms (for Japanese standards) and balconies. Room 2681 (sixth floor) faces the gardens below and at night the city skyline is nice to view.The hotel is located very close to the Shinagawa train station where you can get both the JR (Japan Rail) and the Tokyo Subway lines. I do not recommend the restaurants located in the hotel. Just go to the Shinagawa station where you can find many good Japanese and Western restaurants. For excellent seafood check the EN restaurant. Avoid the Edelweiss cafe in the hotel.I didn't find the specific person assisting hotel guests to be as helpful as most staff in Japanese hotels (very unusual event in Japan I must say).

Stayed 2 nights for a business trip. Huge and busy business hotel but very well organized. Rooms are well-sized and comfortable. Excellent service by the concierge, who helped us organize airport transfer. The hotel even brought out boxes of umbrellas for guest one rainy day. The hotel restaurants are busy for breakfast. The queues can be quite long but there are several to choose from. Short 7 minute walk to Shinagawa station which brings you anywhere in Tokyo. There are several restaurants either side of the station so dining is not an issue. There is even a Singaporean restaurant nearby. The lounge opens till midnight. Enjoyed the single malt specials (Bruichladdich) for the month, which can be purchased by the bottle.While the stay was enjoyable, travelers who are after some peace and quiet will probably find the ground floor area too harassing

Ive stay with my family here for 4 nights and 5 days. The service is quite impressive and the staffs are very helpful and polite. Although they dont speak the best english but they are trying their best to communicate with you.

Very comfortable room with balcony and view on Tokyo tower. Prince hotel has huge facility and includes several hotels at one place. Lovely japanese garden and pond with fish. Business floor has nice lounge with great breakfast and snacks/drinks happy hour. Spa is tranquil and price included for business travelers. Gym is not free. Several great restaurants, tea room, kobe beef, french cafe etc. Hotel price-value is great. Free 2 way shuttle from/to Shinagawa station to hotel. Easy to book airport shuttle to both Tokyo airports Haneda and Narita. Excellent staff. The Takanawa area in Minato-ku is a great place for a walk to see old style buildings and temples and has a rich history. Sengakuji Temple is 10 minutes walk. Many shops and restaurants at Shinagawa station.
user_name:
AnastasiaP
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Well located, about 10 minute walk to Shinagawa Railway Station so lots of food choices around the station and at Shinagawa Food court across the road behind the lovely French patisserie Aux Brauxelles.The hotel is huge and popular with tourist groups and conferences. The staff are very friendly and helpful and many can speak English. We stayed there on 3 different occasions with a JTB rail tour group. It is an older style hotel but the rooms  are quite spacious and very clean and we liked the fact that we could open the sliding door for fresh air and step onto the small balcony. Bathroom well equipped with amenities, toothbrushes, shavers, hairbrush etc. Room safe available. A very good selection of Western and Asian dishes for breakfast.Good free wifi access. We used the Eco option of not having our room serviced on our second day of stay and received a 500 yen voucher to use in the hotel. There are a few dress shops and a 7-11 style shop where you can easily spend your voucher.

Very good location, just down the road from the station, big (by Japanese standards) rooms, all mod cons!! The staff were very helpful and, as with everything else in Japan, very efficient! We started and finished our trip in this hotel and couldn't wait to get back to it!

Japanese hotel not Welcome for foreigners(Gajing).Staff speaks poor English...1 hour waiting for an american club sandwich in room service (with soft and greasy french fries)Almost 40.000Yen/ night and you will be chargeif you want to go to the gym... Gym that is not even in your 4 star hotel !!! (No Gym!)Location is just not very good but not far from a big train station.Air conditioning not working and after someone came to see if you know how to press a button to switch it on, you are told to open the window and to sleep with the window open if it is too hot in the room (promiss it is true !!!)I am so happy to leave tomorrow and to go to the Intercontinental... Hopefully they will at least welcome foreigners... But Grand Prince will never be a king.By the way rooms are old and dirty but that is just a detail...I am not even sure to have breakfast here tomorrow.Can't believe it has such a good rating sometimes I really wonder if tripadvisor have some real customer.Well do what you think but for me it is never again.

Very friendly staff. Huge halls and nice garden. Breakfast with European and traditional Japanese dishes. Spirit of Japanese hospitality with 30-years old history of building. Quality maintenance. Railway, high-speed lines over Japan, subway and bus integrated terminal is very close, only 3-5 min by walk. Busy, but not noisy district with huge range of shops, restaurants, clubs etc. There is large attractive aquarium with dolphins In the next building of this hotel's chain, 2 min by walk.

I went there with my family in october. i was worried about the room size as Japan is known for tiny hotel rooms. but this hotel has really great rooms that could fit two big beds plus a normal size room for my daughter and still had some space for table, office... very clean - no surprise, in Japan! location was excellent! 5 minutes foot distance to the shinagawa train station, from where you can go any place! the hotel offers a free bus shuttle to/from the station from early morning to 9:30 pm, every 20 minutes. great!for breakfast, two solutions: buffet or bakery shop. we picked the second one on the first day and it was perfect for us. fixed price you get free flow juice, coffe/tea and yogurt with cereals and a choice of 3 pastries/breads. we could only eat one each so the waiters offered us a take away for the two others which became our lunch.all the staff was very helpful and kind. thumb up!

I stayed just the one night here, arriving early evening and leaving early the next morning, so I did not get to experience much the hotel had to offer. Rooms were well appointed and clean, with an interesting little ‘Romeo & Juliet’ balcony – great for a fresh air city view, but might not be for you if you are not comfortable with heights. Careful which hotel you book as ‘Grand Prince’ hotels in Tokyo seem to be like Marriotts in the US – one on every block. Right next to this hotel (‘Grand Prince NEW Takanawa’) there is a ‘Grand Prince Takanawa’ and a Shinagawa Prince as well, (Nighmare for non-Japanese speaking tourists and their taxi drivers!). Located near Shinakawa station makes it very accessible to any part of Tokyo if you are comfortable riding the trains (which I highly recommend – once you get the hang of it it is super-efficient and a fast way to get around). You may need to avail yourself of the trains if flying out of Haneda, as the hotel only offers two shuttles a day.

I stay at this hotel every year when I come to Tokyo on business. The rooms are spacious, the neighborhood is nice and the hotel is just an 8 minute walk to the Shinagawa station with easy access to the Yamanote line. It has never been great, but it has been comfortable, convenient and I could count on a reasonable level of service. This time my room was not cleaned very well, the business center wasn't open during it's posted hours and overall, my 5 day stay was a bit disappointing. I have been here many times, but they have no record of previous stays and give no acknowledgement to my frequent visits. Other hotels of similar class welcome me by name and are very welcoming. The recently renamed "Grand" Takanawa Prince Hotel needs to make some changes to live our to its name.

If you want a clean, comfortable, quiet and good-sized room with a lovely little Juliette balcony close to the Shinagawa railway station this may be the place for you. Our room was starting to show signs of needing refurbishment, but everything in the room worked and the bathroom had a good sized bath and plenty of hot water. A free shuttle bus to the railway station and airport limousine (coach) service at the door makes it a handy place to get to and from with luggage. The hotel (together with two others in the Prince Hotels chain) is set in a delightful garden, which is lovely to walk through on the way to the station - about 10 minutes away. Room and front of house service is efficient and friendly and gave a big hotel a more personal feeling.

仕事で数日滞在致しました。駅からは遠いもののその分都内とは思えない緑の中を歩くことができます。お部屋は清潔感があって適度な広さでした。朝食はとてもおいしく、毎日しっかりとればよかったと後悔しております。また機会があれば利用させていただきます。Stayed for a business trip. Bit far from the station but the way to the hotel was awesome. You can take a walk through a Japanese garden. The room was spacious and cozy. Also the breakfast was so good especially in the Chinese restaurant.

I used to stay at this wonderful hotel when working with an international airlines. My re-visit to the hotel in last April still gave me a very warm and fuzzy feeling. The hotel manager was very kind to upgrade me to a higher floor and bigger deluxe room upon hearing that I used to stay there. My balcony overlooked the renowned Japanese garden.Nestled in a lush green area with a beautiful Japanese garden, the hotel has been refurbished, the rooms are now contemporary and very comfortable. The hotel offers shuttle services to the Shinagawa train station. It's very convenient for those who travel by Shinkansen as it is one of the stops in Tokyo.I highly recommend people to stay at this hotel, for it a leisure or business trip. Happy staying… ^.^

Had to travel to Tokyo for a quick business meeting and this is the Hotel my collegues recomended. This was my first time in Tokyo so to be honest i was glad to have somekind of referance on were to go , I had look at other of my more familiar chains to see if I could stay near were we were going and was not able to make sence of logistics. What I liked more about the hotel is the way to get there, coming out of baggage claim in Nariat airport , it was very easy to get to the bus desk were i purchase the one way ticket to were the Hotel is located, this cost $27usd and was the way to go since the bus takes you to the fornt of the lobby of the hotel. this was perfect for me ! hotel is clean and has the necesry facilitys and restaurants , its close to a small shopping area and its recently priced. no complaints from me... cheers.

My wife and I stayed 10 nights and found the hotel very comfortable with pleasant and helpful staff. They did all they could to accommodate us except for one gentleman at the cashier desk who made me feel we were a nuisance. The room was very suitable with no noise problems and the restaurant menus were first class. The Japanese gardens were a relaxing way to go to Shinagawa station or to sit and enjoy the tranquility. The regular shuttle service negated any complaint about the hill up from the station. We would certainly stay there again.

This hotel is a typical western style Japaneese hotel with all main facilities. It is about a five minute walk from Sinagawa Station (although it is slightly up-hill if you are carrying luggage. It is one of a group of hotels in the area but tends to be particularly good value as it is slightly older than the others. All the facilities of the Sinagawa area are within easy reach and central Tokyo is less than 15min by train.

There are 3 prince hotels at Shinagawa area.New Takanawa the lobby area is big but old. Front desk staff English level is not so good.It about 10 mins walk from Shinagawa station, but there is a slope. If you just arrive and carrying bulky luggage, better take the shuttle bus from Shinagawa station or airport limousine bus.There is a small park near the hotel.

A few minutes walk from Shinagawa station, up a gentle incline, through the gardens, rather than the road, I recommend, although there is a free shuttle, if you have luggage or it is raining. Hotel staff were attentive, pleasant and helpful. The hotel room we had on the 8th floor was clean, tidy, with an enormous, comfortable double bed and English CNN, plus free wi-fi. The hotel operates an eco option where you receive a 500 yen voucher per day( for use in hotel shops) if you opt not to have your room serviced.There were a number of eateries close by, plus really decent coffee to be had at the station- walk to opposite end from hotel side and there are 2 places to choose from. We had a very decent breakfast at the bakery.Location is great as it was an easy train ride to wherever we wanted to go.Price-wise, for Tokyo, this was good value.

Located very closed to Shinagawa station where you can find a lot of shops and department stores. The hotel is on top of the hills if you can't wait for the free shuttle bus you have to take your luggage uphill and it takes about 10 minutes to find the hotel as it located amounge the other Prince hotels, very confusing!. However the hotel itself is nice and clean and comfortable. Breakfast was good too.

Just arrived. The Prince hotel has a couple of hotel chain. Btw, make sure you get the correct Grand Prince as there are 2 - the Grand Prince Takanawa and the Grand Prince New Takanawa (both located about 10 mins walk apart)Upon arrival at Shinagawa station, find the East Takanawa exit. Don't ever attempt to walk to the hotel with your huge luggage. I read some of the reviews here which said that it was a 5 mins walk and easy even with luggage, that is not true. The Grand Prince New Takanawa is literally about 15 mins walk (with luggage) as you have to cross the busy Main Street (you can see Wings Shopping Mall), turn right and the 1st junction turn left.Don't walk with your luggage. There is a shuttle bus. Unfortunately no signs. The trick was, as you walk down the staircase or escalator after locating the The Takanawa East exit, just walk straight ( when I said walk straight you go straight after the escalator. Don't turn left or right) to the end of the station. Don't cross the road, just wait there. Every 10 mins the Prince Hotel small Mini Bus will come by. Check in was smooth but room was not ready despite 2.30 pm. I had to remind them and push for it. Check in area located on 1st floor. Room (Double bed non smoking) - very nice. There is a balcony (children beware - dangerous). Spacious. Amenities full. No complaints. Locating the room was confusing. My room had the number 32xx (xx number) but not on 32 floor. That was the 12th floor. Downside - no one helped with luggage. I had to drag mine to the room. Never mind. I saved giving tips here. If you need to go back to Shinagawa Station go to the reception and book the time. No booking no bus.

poor service which is rare in japanese hotel: no one to help with your luggage at checkin,no smile at the reception,,location is no good for somebody who arrived by JR :you have to walk 15 mins upslope,,weird room number arrangement:e.g. room 3100 is not 31floor it is 11 floor ,but nobody told you at the checkin,so we have took a long time to look for non-existent elevator reaching 31 floor,, good points are:reasonable price for reasonable size room

There are 4 of this Price hotel chains in this same area and i tried all of them and I think this is the best one. It even has triple bed rooms. The most rooms have small but nice balcony to enjoy and beautiful japanese garden to walk around.

We stayed in this hotel for three nights and here are some impression about it:Location – Can’t complain about the location as, in my opinion, there is not a perfect location in Tokyo. As this hotel has a nearby subway/railway station (Shinagawa Station) the location is good. Around the station there are plenty of restaurants and stores. There is a hotel shuttle bus hotel - station - hotel but the distance is easily walkable (no more than ten minutes).The Japanese garden in front of the hotel gives it a special environment.Hotel- Lobby and public areas: The lobby is huge but it lack soul. At first impression it seems I was arriving at a train station. Clean and huge but with no decor or soul.Restaurants – We only went to the Marmolada Restaurant for breakfast. Good as expected with enough choices for westerns.Rooms – With a good size , the rooms we stayed were modern and clean with all expected amenities and a small veranda with a great view, specially at night.Staff – Some of the staff have low English skills but that never was never a problem. They were courteous, helpful and attentive. Did not use the swimming pool but the acess for it is not free. In Japan, in the hotels we stayed, there was always a tax for the use of the swimmingpoolIt was a good hotel choice.

I love staying in Shinagawa every time I visit Tokyo. It is not as crazy busy like Shinjuku or Shibuya where you can easily get lost. If you are travelling to Tokyo, I would recommend staying in Shinagawa as it is only a 10min train ride to all the major cities. Convenient if you are traveling via Haneda airport as well as bullet trains. There are three "prince hotels" all close by but I like this one the best. The newly renovated rooms are very nice and clean. My room had a balcony facing beautiful bamboo forest. Service is also very good. Once I locked myself out and as soon as I report this at the reception, I was told to simply wait outside my room. Within 3 min, one of the staff came "running" to help me out. This is only a small example of the level of their customer service. They "care."I used the Eco option and received $5 coupon. Just enough to buy some postcards in one of their small boutiques that sells souvenirs. There is even a mailbox right next to the reception, which was very convenient.The three connecting Prince hotels share a beautiful Japanese garden in the middle. You must take a walk though this garden. It is well maintained and there are many small paths that lead you to a tea house, a little shrine, etc. One of the highlight of this garden is its massive pond with hundreds of beautiful Koi fish. Highly recommend for a walk before or after your breakfast.It is less than 10min walk from this hotel to JR Shinagawa station. I am staying at this hotel on my next trip to Japan as we'll.

The hotel is located close to Shinagawa Station and from there you can easily get a train to other parts of Tokyo. The hotel is on the top of a hill from the station, a steep walk up the hill. The hotel is very big. Avoid the old style rooms as these are worn and not that nice. Rooms are clean. Breakfast is good, but the area is crowded. Not a lot to do near the hotel, so plan on using the train to get to attractions etc.

Very good. I've been there with the PMF Orchestra. It's quite difficult to find the breakfast room, but once you get there it's good. :) The wi-fi reception in the room is excellent compared to other hotels I visited in Japan. I recommend it.

This hotel is very, very conveniently located just a five minute walk from Shinagawa Station. The location of this hotel was perfect because we rode the trains everywhere. We had a double twin room, which was completely adequate. The bathroom was delightfully and unexpectedly fun with the "robo-toilet". We took advantage of an "eco" option regarding cleaning the room. If you choose to have your room cleaned every third day you get a $5 voucher good for every restaurant/shop in the hotel. The concierge and bell service was top notch. We asked our concierge about several excursions and they were very knowledgeable and even had printed train numbers/times printed for us. Everyone we came in contact with in this hotel spoke enough English for us to not have to struggle.We had two complaints about this room: (1) The air conditioning never cooled the room off enough. Tokyo in the summertime is HOT. We cranked the AC down to the lowest setting and it never really cooled it down enough. (2) The beds were very comfortable, but there were heavy duvets on the beds with no top sheet (I know, very European, but I still don't enjoy it!). With a warm room, and no top sheet, sleep was a bit warm and uncomfortable.

I came to hotel 1 1/2 hours before official check in time and receptionist did not even want to talk to me about early check in.Hotel is well located at Shinagawa JP station.Room I got was small, bathroom was not very well maintained. Room was quite dark and it was clearly worn out.Breakfast is quite good but you need to come very early because it very crowded and you would need to wait 10-20 minutes.

Location & environment: Conveniently located near Shinagawa JR station. You can reach it from Narita airport by rapid N'EX train in 70 minutes without transit. The 5 -10 minutes walk from that station to hotel is a pleasure in mild weather but quite hard if you carry big suitcases or in summer. Shuttle between that station and hotel is available and booking can be made (only for coach from hotel to JR station, not in reverse direction). Several hotels which belong to the same group are found in the same quiet and green area. Lots of eating places and shops near to the hotel, thus very convenient. Both Japanese and western cuisines are available. From hotel you can reach Tokyo and Shinjuku stations by JR in 15 minutes (Yamanote Line has train every 2 to 3 minutes). Can reach Disneyland in 35 minutes (By JR Yamanote Line > Keio Line) with only one change in Tokyo station. The hotel is equally close to metro station Takanawa. You can reach almost the whole city by metro. Shinagawa district, however, does not have many tourist attractions. You should choose other districts if you like shopping. But it is in the southern part of Tokyo, so convenient for those having day trips to Yokohama and Kamakura. Room & service: The rooms are a bit dated and renovation will be very helpful. Room size is reasonable in Tokyo standard. The double room is really enough for two people. Good air condition, free and strong wifi in room. Half of the rooms above 8th floor can have view of Tokyo Tower. The room and bed sheets are clean. Reception staff speak English. There is safe box, kettle, tea bag and coffee are not provided. You have to buy in the 7-11(not around the clock) inside the hotel.

A very comfortable hotel close to Haneda airport. The hotel run a shuttle bus to the airport as well as to Shingawa station ( the latter is free). If you have a JR pass it can be very useful here as there is a direct JR train to Tokyo station. The room was fairly large and there was a balcony with lovely views.

Considering the size of Tokyo, this hotel is very convenient for getting around the city as the train station is within five minutes walk, as is the Metro. We stayed for four nights on B&B basis and as the breakfast buffet was so good we never needed lunch. Staff were very helpful and there is a small mini-market in the hotel. There are many restaurants nearby and on a couple of evenings we ate street food from near the station, which was great value and very tasty. Probably the only drawback was the sheer size of the place. This gave a muted atmosphere which is not surprising considering it is mainly a conference hotel.

This is nice hotel. Big lobby, big hotel, nice room, but the furniture a bit old. Unfortunately, this hotel far away from Tokyo Metro. If you want to take a shinkansen, shinagawa station was close enough within walk distance. But to take tokyo metro, you need to go at the back side of hotel to catch into.

My family and I stayed for 2 nights in July, in standard double and standard twin rooms. We were very impressed with the size of the rooms, which were no smaller than Western hotel rooms, and huge for Japan. The rooms were impeccably clean, the bed was comfortable (though note that mattresses in Japan tend to be on the hard side), and we were very pleasantly surprised that the "double" bed was in fact a full king. We had a small patio from the Double room with a nice view if the city and of the hotel's koi pond and gardens, facing the Grand Prince Takanawa. We chose the hotel for its value, and proximity to Shinagawa Station (it is a 5-minute walk up a small hill from the station). This gave us excellent proximity to Haneda airport (15 minutes direct by JR), Kamakura (50 minutes direct by JR), and Kyoto (2 1/2 hrs direct by JR). The area around the hotel is not a destination unto itself.I was happy with the choice of hotels, and would recommend it for anyone looking for good value and a decent hotel near Shinagawa. The only disappointment was that we did not get to try the 2 outdoor pools, as the hours were not very convenient for busy travellers. The pools did not open until 10am and were closed by 8pm.

This is a mid level hotel that is good for a business traveler. Close to Shinagawa station, the bullet train is accessible, as is the local train. Rooms could use a refresh, but it is clean and service is attentive. Free wifi in rooms and lobby is convenient. There are many local restaurants nearby where you can eat on the cheap. Royal Host down the block has cheap breakfasts and the ramen alley in the station has delicious ramen.
user_name:
Bryan F
Lincolnwood, Illinois, United States

review_body: The Hotel was very accommodating. The rate included free WiFi and an awesome breakfast buffet. I recommend getting a room as high up as you can, ie, 15th floor on the side with the view of the Tokyo Tower and the Tokyo skyline. The rooms have balconies and the night view of the illuminated Tokyo Tower is breathtaking. And, how can you possibly go wrong when your toilet seat is heated. There is a free shuttle service to and from the Shin station. There are many Grand Prince hotels in Tokyo, so make sure you choose the New Takanawa. I don't think you will be disappointed.

Part of the big maze in Shinagawa. Very very huge lobby and they have their own small 7-11. Save me from spending 15 minute walking down to the 7-11 at Shinagawa Prince hotel or Shinagawa station. Hotel do sell stamps, should you need to post letters of post card

This hotel is part of a big hotel complex in Shinagawa and seems designed to cater for big conferences. Nevertheless, it is a good choice close to Shinagawa station. Rooms are spacious and have all the basic stuff you need, including free WiFi. Breakfast was good and there is a convenience store within the hotel.

Stayed at Grand Prince New Takanawa Hotel for 2 nights. This hotel had a huge lobby! And free wifi at your room, which was of course awesome. What I like about this hotel is that its quite near the Shinagawa Station, approximately 15minutes depending on how fast you walk. Some restaurants are also near the vicinity such as TGIFridays, a Singapore restaurant, and a Steakhouse. Inside the hotel, there's a small 7-11 convenience store where you can buy bottled water (safer), a nail salon, souvenir shop etc. There were also restaurants below the hotel where we ate our breakfast. The rooms were clean and neat. They provided pillows and fluffy comforters. Haha I was able to sleep well for 2 nights. The downside of the hotel: there's a small balcony from my room overlooking the hotel's pool.. And oh my!! it was a very dirty pool!!! Nobody dares to swim there coz nobody cleans it. Overall experience is good. Visit my blog: http://www.itravelwithmyheart.wordpress.com

We have spent here seven nights. The Staff is absolutely wonderful, the rooms are big, we have a double bed room (non-smoking) with a balcony. When I opened the closet the first day I found PJ's and sleepers for our use, which is rare in the US. Also, all kind of toiletries. Good Wi-Fi signal. This hotel is well located, within walking distance to the subway (Shinagawa Station) and the Rail Station.convenient to Shinagawa JR station although the hill to the hotel with luggage can be a challenge. My only complaint is that I had a hard time booking a tour, first I couldn't communicate in English with the lady at the desk. Also, it appears that they deal with only one travel agency who most of the time has not availability. In addition the swimming pool is not open until July 1 and to go to the gym you have to go to one of the other Prince Hotel and pay.

I am a business traveler and this hotel is basically not what I was expecting.It seems to mostly cater to large tourist groups and this was detrimental to my experience. For instance there was a HUGE line (>30 min) waiting for having breakfast in the morning at both the restaurant offering breakfast. Had to go to the local Lawson and get a bottle of orange juice and some plastic wrapped food for breakfast. Concierge was overwhelmed and clearly not up to the kind of tasks a business traveler would ask. Getting a taxi was also a pretty difficult task. In a nutshell, not recommended for business travel.

I stayed there for a night, the room is more spacious than I expected.... Nice hotel room with clean sheets... Stayed on the lower floor so nothing much to see... However the hotel is rather big, it took a good 5 minutes to walk from room to the place we had our breakfast.Breakfast spread of nice... not too much variety though.

Stayed here in 2011 and very pleased that we decided to return. Very helpful member of staff at reception who politely and quickly processed our booking. Luggage taken to our room by staff member who reminded us how to operate the air conditioning etc. Room large, clean and very comfortable. Good Wi-Fi signal. Location is convenient to Shinagawa JR station although the hill to the hotel with luggage can be a challenge. However the hotel does provide a free shuttle service (must be booked) to the station. Small shop in the hotel for the purchase of food and or wine etc and the room had a fridge. There is a good range of restaurants in the station area and on the road to the hotel. Definitely would use this hotel again when back in Tokyo.

This hotel is a part of three properties within the same area, it is a a 3.5 star hotel. The rooms are large, clean and comfortable, however, unless you're on the club level, the rooms do not have a coffee/tea machine and no minibar. You have to go to a small mart within the hotel building to buy anything. There is no restaurant or bar in the hotel either, but there are a few restaurants/bars within a walking distance. The lobby is huge with a large seating area that was closed off the whole four days that I was there, I could not figure out what purpose that area served. In general, staff are friendly and helpful and the hotel is very clean and very conveniently located to two train stations and a busy restaurant/bar area. I would stay there again if there were no other hotels available, but it would not be the first place to go back to.

The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is one of a cluster of hotels near Shinagawa Station. Some of the hotels have very similar names, so make sure you are heading for the right one!The hotel is conveniently located a 500 metre trudge up the hill from Shinagawa Station. It reminds me of an older style hotel with its large expanses of timber and open lobby areas, but the place is spotless and features all the modern facilities you'd expect. My room was spacious and very clean, with a comfortable bed and air conditioning that worked well. High speed Internet did the job well too.Although there isn't much of great tourist interest in the immediate vicinity, this hotel is ideal for travellers who have just arrived in Tokyo and want to take the Shinkansen from Shinagawa Station to another city the next morning (like me!), or who are doing business in the area. The price was pretty reasonable too.
user_name:
Brett G
Sydney, New South Wales, Australia

review_body: Great view of mt Fuji from our room when it was clear. Breakfast was great and varied. We had 2 stays here and we're happy to come back before leaving japan. Close to jr train line. Rooms were large and comfortable

I decided to go for a mid-priced hotel during my short layover. I had never been to Japan, and this was a very nice place. Excellent staff. Nice room with every convenience I needed. it has a wonderful garden outside the hotel that was good for a morning walk to battle jet lag fatigue. Very short walk (2-3 blocks, 5 minutes tops) to the Shingawa station. I enjoyed the breakfast buffet at the Marmalada at the hotel. Great view from my 11th story room with iron-railed balconies. Just a great place. Enjoyed it thoroughly. Internet worked very well.

We stay here for 3 nights. The hotel is huge, comfortable, rooms are clean + spacious, bed & pillows are great. The food is tasty. The only disadvantage is the location being far from central tokyo. A 10 min walk from hotel to Shinagawa station.

Good hotel in Shinagawa, with reasonable sized quiet rooms with a view of the Tokyo Tower from some upper floors. The concierge service was extraordinary and Aki, in particular, is one of the most capable organizers on the planet.

We stayed here for a rushed 3 night stay in Japan. The hotel is very comfortable, the rooms good, bed and pillows great. The food in both room service and the restaurants was nice.The location isn't the best if you are looking for central Tokyo - it felt a bit away from things
user_name:
ShaneH13
Raumati Beach, Wellington, New Zealand

review_body: It was much better than what I've expected. Very very clean! Amenity was from Shiseido, which was quite good in quality. Room service was good as well. Again, very clean! Location of the hotel was good. It was 20 mins from Haneda international airport and 12 mins if you take the express train. From the station, it was about 5 mins walk to hotel. Beautiful garden and beautiful view from the hotel. Since it was located in Shinakawa, it was good to travel both to East and West. Room was bigger than what I've expected. I will come back to this hotel again for sure :)

Lovely hotel very nice, spacious rooms. The hotel is massive with two sister hotels set on a very large plot. There are lovely gardens joining the three hotels and you are free to use the facilities in all three hotels. It's conveniently positioned for the railway station, it's about 5 or 6 minutes walk away, it's also handy for shops and restaurants. The only fault, if you can call it a fault, is that the reception is very uninspiring and lets the rest of the hotel down.

it is very good hotel. The hotel to train station is only 8 min by walk. The facilities in the hotel is great! The sakura in the garden is beautiful.Even the staff not speak fluent English . No free wifi in the room and only in the lobby .

Stayed at this hotel in a twin room with my son who is 10 years old. I made reservation directly with hotel through a promotion that they were running. Similar prices were on Agoda and also Expedia. At check-in, they told me that my son was considered an adult and that they needed to charge me more for the room. When booking, I saw nothing as far as rate per person and I recall seeing the age being around 12 years old for children. Either way, management worked with me on the situation and check me in under the room rate that I had reserved originally. It was a bit confusing but I am glad that management worked with me versus wanting to charge me more.The basic rooms was quite nice and roomy. The balcony is a nice. There us a desk in the room which is helpful for any work or planning you need to do. The room was modern with a nice flat screen TV set and a safe and a small sofa to separate out the room. Overall, for the price, the room was quite good and I would stay here in a second on my next return trip back to Tokyo if the room rate was reasonable.Another consideration for this hotel is how close this is to the train station and that the hotel has a shuttle service running to the train station every 10 to 15 minutes. One suggestion is that it when you do get off the NEX, from the airport, if you go to the exit, a bus will come along and take you to the appropriate Prince Hotel. This is a lifesaver versus having to tote your bag up the hill which would take about 10 minutes.The Japanese gardens were beautiful and we enjoyed our stay here in the month of April.

Large lobby. We stayed here while on tour. The room was dusty, the sofa was stained,carpet was not vacuumed properly,the decorative pillows on the bed were torn and worn at the ends. Very disappointing to walk in a room that was not maintained properly for a new guest. The breakfast buffet was good. I would not recommend this hotel.

Booked into the hotel at the last minute during a busy period. Room was good value for money with clean, comfortable rooms, free wifi and decent service. Hotel is part of a vast complex with two other hotels on site, and scenic gardens which are worth walking around.For the location, there was a bit of hesitation as on the map it appeared to be a fair distance from the Tokyo station hub, but given the proximity of Shinagawa station and efficiency of the train network we could get to most places within 30 minutes. Main (and only) gripe was the heating system which we couldn't control and was way too hot for us.

I do not remember if I wrote a review on this hotel but I went back recently and it was a good surprise to me. Maybe because I was at the Club floor but the rooms were large enough (although still small) and very comfortable, fully refurbished and well. Free wifi, good bed, eerything we need. Only thing poor is this big unpersonal lobby with hundreds of people hanging around at some time.I recommend to upgrade the Club Floor breakfast on level 16. Choice is really poor as this is a very good alternative to busy and far away breakfast restaurant.I will certainly come back if prices remain under control.

it s a huge hotel, old that make you feel not very confortable. It is ok for one night, but such as desapointement when I landed in the breakfast area and I saw 20 people waiting for breakfast. I was in the 15 floor...executive room, in fact it is like 4 starts hotel...therefore I can imagine how bad are the first price room...The executive breakfast area has only juice and 3 types of breads....a joke.Indeed there is a small garden in the middle of the complex which is nice....an what else? when you cross it once..it is a big complex for big meetings...not good for couple or family

An enormous hotel, in a large complex of Prince hotels. Good location, just across the road from Shinagawa station, however, quiet as on top of a small hill and on one side surrounded by the Tea Gardens. Good quality and large rooms with all the facilities. Staff were very helpful and available. Stayed here for 7 nights on business - could not fault any of the time spent at the hotel. Had a rate which included breakfast; breakfast was buffet style with a good selection across Japanese, Chinese and Western style foods - sometimes a queue to get into breakfast though. I had booked online with a smoking room, but upon request at check in, the staff provided me with a non smoking room.

I only stayed here for two nights on a business trip in Tokyo, and the hotel is good. It is posh as many other hotels but all the basics are there. The spacious room in Tokyo is really worth it. I have a good view of Tokyo tower at night, and it's just a short distance walk to the Shinagawa station. There were many tourists staying in this hotel in big groups.

THis hotel is located in an area clustered with 3 other hotels with almost the same. So you must spelled out the full name of this hotel when you buy limo bus transport from Narita (fare is 3,000 Yen). I made the mistake of not putting in the word " New ", as I was sent to another with same name i.e.without "new".This confusion aside, I would advice that if you have considerable lugagge, do not use the train becuase eventhough JR Shinagawa station is just miuntes of walk, but the walk is up-hill and amonst large crowd of pedestrains. Take my word you will regret it, if you ignore my advice.Hotel itself, have a huge lobby. Service from all staff are just fantastics, keeping the Japanese standards of efficiency. Check-in was fast, but you have to wait or come back after 2.00 pm as they practiced strictly their rules.Rooms are large, for Tokyo standards. Beds are comfortable and warm toilet seats are a great welcome. But make sure you had allow enough time for your breakfast as crowds seems to be high from 7,00 to 8.00. Breakfast is at Edelwise but the spread is too normal.

This is the best situated hotel I have ever stayed in. Literally 5 mins walk from Shinagawa Station, from where you can go anywhere. The staff are very helpful, giving directions how to get anywhere. It's not too expensive which is a bonus. Opening windows onto the balcony is great as the rooms are very warm. Didn't eat or drink there, just used as a base which was perfect and exactly what we wanted. Would stay again if ever back in Tokyo.

I stayed here for two nights in a clean and spacious room with two double beds. Location near Shinagawa Station made it very convenient to explore the city. Staff was helpful and friendly when I asked for assistance in arranging delivery for my luggage from Tokyo to my next hotel in Kyoto. Leaving the luggage at Grand Prince to be picked up for delivery made my traveling to Kyoto (via Shinkansen) much more comfortable. I didn’t need to stop by my hotel in Kyoto which saved a lot of time because I could go sightseeing straightly from Kyoto station.

Lucky enough to spend two nights here during a stay in Tokyo. Friendly staff, clean facilities. Very close to the JR train station, which gets you to virtually all of Tokyo. Comfy beds, and a great garden. Good breakfast service too!Tried out a new service they were offering for hotel to hotel luggage shipments. I've never considered doing this back home (USA), since shipping costs are so high, but it was only $17USD (regardless of weight) to ship my giant suitcase from Tokyo to Kyoto over two days. Allowed me to take an overnight day trip on the bullet train with a night in a small traditional Japanese village without lugging around a huge suitcase. Made the whole experience much more pleasant, only needing to carry a change for the next day. All my skepticism about the shipping was washed away when the hotel staff had my suitcase ready for me without me mentioning a thing! Very cool service to consider if staying at GP New Takanawa. Overall very nice hotel, would recommend this place to a friend.

My room was very comfortable and clean. My room had two double beds and was quite spacious. I stayed at this hotel 5 years ago and everything is exactly the same. You can not alter the temperature setting in your room, it was set on 25C. Every night I would turn it off and open the balcony door to cool down and finally by the last night it was set on 20C. The breakfast buffet was fine but do allow at least a fast paced 5 minute walk to get there. It's way over the other side of the hotel and down a flight of stairs through a coffee shop. It opens at 6.30am.

Two nights in "The Prince" confirmed that it offers excellent value with good comfort.An added bonus is that rooms actually have a balcony where you get both fresh air and great views.This is especially relevant as Japanese buildings tend to wildly overheated in winter and over cooled in summer. Turning off the heating and leaving the door to the balcony open makes for a comfortable sleep.The executive lounge in one of the smallest I have found, but still friendly and offering a simple continental breakfast and also a free beer or two in the evening.The hotel is close to many good restaurants as an added bonus.

The staff is badly trained and rude, and they treat their customers like school children and boss them around. Very disappointed, I used to stay here frequently because it's conveniently located, but I will definitely not stay here again!

After staying at St Regis and Westin in Osaka we felt like a downgrade staying at prince. But we soon overcame the feeling and realised it's not fair to compare these hotels and it was like comparing apples and oranges. The stay was pretty businesslike went around Tokyo and came back to sleep and bathe. Not that we have any specific grievances but the stay was kind of bland. One grouse I have is I ordered coffee in the lobby and was charged 1400 yen which I found outrageous, I advice guests to stay away from ordering anything when you are passing through the lobby.

Have stayed here a few years ago. Not changed at all. Rooms are clean but smallish. Beds comfortable. Convienent location for subway access. Western breakfast is good. Staff friendly but not all speak English well enough to be understood on some basics.

I stayed here about 10 years ago, and returned recently. It really hasn't changed much. I imagine once that is was fresh and modern, but is not starting to look very dated. Location isn't bad and as with almost everywhere in Japan, staff are efficient and attentive, but this definitely isn't a place I'll be returning to. And unfortunately their WiFi is terrible. I had an iPad with me and was told I had to rent a router for the room (seriously, in 2013, in central Tokyo?). Even then, I struggled to get online. This place is neither grand nor new.

This was my second stay at this Hotel, the last being 12 years ago. Amazingly, the hotel is in exactly the same state it was the last time. The Hotel is located up a slight hill about 10 minute walk from Shinagawa Station. This is useful because Shinagawa is one of the stops on the Narita Express route from Narita Airport after Tokyo station. In addition, Shinagawa is on the JR Yamanote line that circles Tokyo so its a brilliant location as a base to explore Tokyo. I prefer being in Shinagawa as I don't enjoy the assault on the senses being in some of the other popular accommodation options in Tokyo ie Shibuya, Shinjuku etc. The hotel is part of a larger complex of 3 hotels under the Prince Group on the Takanawa side of Shinagawa Station. In between the 3 hotels, there is a garden where you can have your own private cherry blossom viewing if you are in Tokyo around April.I booked everything online and opted for the Club floor whilst booking the children in a standard room.
