Having seen both rooms, I would recommend that one just sticks to the standard rooms and save a bit of money. Check in was a breeze with the receptionist able to speak passable English. The hotel also has a Convention Centre on the grounds so is adept at handling large Groups. I had opted for the breakfast option at the hotel for convenience but there were breakfast options at a much cheaper price down the road towards Shinagawa station.The room was reasonably spacious and more importantly was one of the few hotels in Tokyo with a balcony. We had many of our dinners at Wings Building directly opposite the Shinagawa Station, next to the Hollywood Pachinko parlour. We were not disappointed with the meals we had and found the prices quite reasonable. One tip however is have dinner early as the restaurants all fill up by 7pm everyday.All in all was very happy with the Hotel and it's location. So I now have two hotels I enjoy in Tokyo, both have balconies for the smokers out there, the Prince New Takanawa and also Nikko on Tokyo Bay.

I ever stay in Grand Prince New Takanawa Tokyo, Japan in 2010. And it was amazing for me to stay in this hotel! Very glamour, unique, tasty cuisine, and very welcome staffs! Also, Tokyo is beautiful and clean city! Thank you for being my best stay!Aziel-Indonesia

No doubt this hotel offers only the best. From the comfortable yet firm bed to the friendliness of Princes' staffs. However, it's disappointing that they doesn't have international tv channel. They have 2 pools which are useless during winter, it will be great to have a indoor pool and also a fitness center.

In walking distance to Shinagawa Station, we were very happy to have chosen this Hotel for our 3 night stay-over in Tokyo.Everything was in an easy reach for exploring the city. We occupied 2 rooms (Parents, 3 Teenager) and were given a room just next to each other. Breakfast was great and good value at the Edelweiss Restaurant

This hotel has very spacious, clean and comfortable rooms, at very reasonable rates. The hotel personnel is very helpful and service quality is as good as you can expect in Japan (customer satisfaction oriented). The hotel is connected with other hotels from the same chain in the same complex and this increases the options for on site restaurants and bars. If you are in the mood for a quick snack, there is a 7 Eleven shop inside the hotel premises, which I found very convenient.The location of this hotel is great, as Shinagawa Station is reachable by foot and in case of bad weather, the hotel has a shuttle to the station every half an hour. Access to and from Narita and Haneda airports is convenient by airport limousine, just make sure that you book your ride in advance. During my stay, there was only one negative aspect: breakfast at the Marmolada Restaurant. The variety of the buffet is poor and the taste is anything but unforgettable. The quality is simply not at the same level of the hotel.I certainly recommend this hotel. You get great value for your money and the location is excellent to move around Tokyo

This hotel strikes an almost perfect balance between price, quality and convenience in Tokyo. From check in to check out it was great! The bathrooms are a cool blend of western plumbing and Japanese ingenuity. The heated toilet seat bidet combo made me laugh at first but was sure missed when down the road. I experienced never ending hot water and a great shower head in a spacious tub were a rarel treat in Tokyo. The in room elements are excellent! The kettle fast, quiet and clean. The TVs clarity was outstanding. Comfortable sheets and pillows on a super firm mattress. Internet speeds were fast enough to support voice aps. No faults found. Check in and out was a respectful, quick Japanese style experience. The lobby is often busy yet never felt crowded and offered plenty of space. Its only a short walk to the trains and a short walk from the hustle and bustle of Tokyo to its peaceful tranquil rooms,

We paid extra to have a view from the 15th floor. This is also a club floor so there is a continental breakfast available and limited bar in the evening. The rooms are bigger and very comfortable with a king size bed and a bigger than normal bathroom for Japan. There is an onsen available in an adjacent building. We didn't use the restaurants but there are plenty close by near the station. Shinagawa is great for access to the Shinkansen and for all the other trains. The staff are helpful. We were also able to stay for a late checkout until 3 PM for an extra ¥45,000. The hotel doesn't have a great ambience but that didn't really concern us.

My friend and i stayed there for two nights. we thought we would get an average room since we were with a tour and on a budget but when we realized we were on the top floor and went in to the room, OMG! it was more than we expected. We eventually realized that we'd been upgraded for some reason i cannot explain) to the executive club twin room. and the view of tokyo was amazing from the balcony, both day and night! no hotel we stayed at later could match that! it was spacious and had all the facilities we needed and more not to mention there was a little shopping corridor on the first level where there was also a convenience store. And the staff were extremely welcoming and helpful! there is not one thing my friend and i could find to complain about even if we tried. Would go again in a milli- heartbeat!!!

The hotel is located in the large complex of hotel together with 2 others hotel.This hotel accommodate more tourist group than the other two hotel.Average standard services, average look of lobby, breakfast not very good because you have to que quite long but if you read the coupon carefully actually you can have your breakfast at the other two hotel.The park outside the hotel is excellent place, great to enjoy green area of Tokyo !
user_name:
Gregorius S
Greater London, United Kingdom

review_body: I was looking for an economic option that would allow me access to the main tourist attractions in and around Tokyo. This is an older style hotel - no question - but it is clean, rooms are spacious and staff are helpful.This is a short walk to many, many restaurants in and around the Shinawaga station. I would not recommend eating in the hotel restaurants, take a short walk and benefit from a much better ambiance, choice and selection.I would return.

We were in Japan on a Friendship Force exchange, and Tokyo was our last stop. Our Exchange Director found this hotel after much consultation with Friendship Force club people in Japan and lots of internet searching.The main point is that we ended up with a first-rate hotel at bargain-rate prices. The staff was competent and friendly - willing to go the extra mile for us. And its location, only a few blocks from the Shinagawa Railroad station made it a perfect choice. The rooms were generous and well-equipped. I could not believe that I was getting a 4-star (maybe even 5) room for the price.The concierge was most helpful in making sure that we had the right train directions, and the staff carefully set up our transportation to the airport. We couldn't have had a better experience.

I'd call it a ten minute walk up the hill from the JR Shinagawa train station. The New Takanawa Hotel is not as close to the station as the original Shinagawa Prince Hotel, but there's a free shuttle that goes around the cluster of Prince hotels every 20 minutes taking you to JR. Just make sure you have the exact name of this place because the name of another shuttle stop is very similar and you could end up at the wrong hotel. The room is ridiculously large and well kept, if a bit dated. The TV has BBC and CNN. Staff speaks very good english. Breakfast is not included but there is a 7-Eleven on the ground floor where one can get good sushi rolls and sandwiches. JR Shinagawa is the southern-most station on the Yamanote loop - a frequent train service that goes around the Tokyo area in a complete circle serving most of the toursit spots. JR Shinagawa is also a stop on the Shinkansen coming from Hiroshima and Kyoto.

I won't repeat what others have observed: it's well located, has a beautiful garden, no wifi in the rooms, etc. I'm deeply grateful to the hotel for the extraordinary service they provided me. I left my iPad and over $250 in the hotel safe when I checked out. They sent them to me overnight, so I had them in my hands the following evening in Kyoto. Thanks!

Stayed for a couple of nights on business in October. The top floor rooms with king size beds are spacious especially for Tokyo hotels. Hotel is only 5 minutes walk from Shinagawa station making it convenient for travel in and out of Tokyo.

Arrived approx 11 pm after flying from LAX. Staff helpful and courteous and check in was swift and easy.Booked 2 x triples for the whole family and whilst rooms were small this was expected. Everything was well appointed and no issues with rooms with view from 14th floor very nice. Had a nice balcony too.The Japanese Gardens were very enjoyable and provided an oasis from the hustle and bustle.Relatively easy access to Shinagawa station which is on the main "circle" line and also easy access to the Narita Express train being second stop

Nice view from the little balcony. The room was nice, good bed and pillows. Hallways long and too warm. No wireless Internet in the room, definitely a negative. Hotel staff very friendly. Our rooms included breakfast, which was adequate.

The hotel is located at a walking distance from the Shinagawa station. You could take the Narita Express and reach Shinagawa station without having to make any hops at any intermediate station if you are flying into Tokyo.The hotel has very spacious rooms and superb internet connectivity. The staff is very courteous and most of them speak English. The breakfast spread has some continental options. There are multiple hotels of the Takanawa brand around the area, so the options for eating out are plenty. The hotel is close to the office location near the Shinagawa station. So if you have your office I would definitely pick this hotel for another stay at Shinagawa.

The hotel and room was very comfortable, especially the swimming pool. It is close to a main station so very easy to get into the centre of Tokyo. It was comfortable walking round the area at night and there were plenty of restaurants close by. The breakfast wasn't very good and definitely not worth the money!

Located very near shinagawa station, the hotel makes for a comfortable stay all together. This is because it is located very near a main tube and JR railway station, in a lively area, surrounded bay very relaxing japanese style garden. The room was spacious with a very comfortable bed and with an touch inside of warmth, as if you are a room in a private house instead than at a hotel. Room had free wired internet or wi fi only for 10 USD for all stay and accessible in the lobby which was nice to sit to people watch. Bathroom was big and clean, shower was hot & had good pressure (which is important to me). We had a view of the Tokyo Tower which we enjoyed looking at from our balcony. Bed was HUGE and very comfy

Stayed here for 3 nights recently on a business trip to Tokyo, and compared to usual hotel-experiences in most other countries, this leaves a lot to be desired. However, this seems to be a fairly standard experience at most Tokyo hotels, so perhaps expectations need to be recalibrated when you travel here. Check-in took more time than usual, probably due to it being handled by a trainee with very-limited english-language skills. After a 20minute processing time, I was finally on my way to my room. Do note, though, that the room numbers here do not tally with the floor numbers! :-) - I had room number 34xx, which happened to be only the 14th floor (and not 34th as I imagined!) The room in itself was just OKAY, a bit dated and worn at the edges. It definitely needs a good spring cleaning (carpets were stained and dirty, and the bathtub was chipped in places). See attached pictures. What was quaint, though, was that each room comes with its own little Juliet-balacony - however, with no view to enjoy, this is a no-brainer. Everything other than the room was chargeable as extras! :-) - Breakfast costs extra (and the quality is rather poor!), using the pool costs extra, and internet costs extra too!... There was no iron in the room (something that I consider a basic requirement on most business trips)... and ironing was always at extra cost. Choice of restaurants in the hotel were a bit dicey, and the meals I have had at the Grand Prince are best described as sub-standard (both in-room and in the restaurants). The hotel is conveniently located just a 5-minute walk from the Takanawa exit of Shinagawa station, which really is a boon since the Narita Express as well as most major JR trains stop here. The walk up to the hotel is uphill, though - so better to take a cab if you have a lot of luggage. The area is always busy, so it is fairly easy to find a restaurant to dine in if you are not keen to partake of the poor food at the hotel.... many restaurants nearby, and more opposite the Konan exit from the station... I do not look forward to staying here again, and will probably look for a different hotel on subsequent visits.

Less than 5 minutes walk to the major Shinagawa Station where you can get trains to all over Tokyo (and Japan) the location of this hotel is ideal. Use the Yanamote line which has trains every 4 minutes on a circular you all around the main areas of Tokyo. It is one of the best city hotels I've ever stayed in with a huge selection of restuarants (okay they aren't cheap) and large, clean rooms. It has a large Japanese garden and pool, although they do charge for the pool which was odd. Also, the staff spoke some of the best english we encountered in Japan, which was extremely helpful for us whos Japanese was less than upto scratch. A classy hotel which serves as a great place to sleep while you are out exploring Tokyo during waking hours.

I stayed here on the first part of - 9 Day tour of Japan and was at this hotel from August 19th - 23rd 2013 --I actually was in Japan for 18 days but the first 9 were with a tour with Gate1 Travel. I was more than pleasantly surprised at how large the room was as I believed guide books that warned of extremely small accommodations in Tokyo. The room looked modern and it was immaculately clean. Our tour included the breakfast buffet daily at this hotel and it was always very good as well. The beds were comfortable, the linens were nice and I can't think of a bad thing to say about the accommodations here. I loved the proximity to Shinagawa Station and all of train and the dining options so near by. I would stay here again in a hear beat a I would recommend it.

This was my 2nd stay. Since 1st time was pretty good I wanted to book this hotel again. But I was not able to book non smoking room for weekends via RAKUTEN.When we checked in I asked if they could change to non smoking room. First the clerk told me they need 30-45min to readt the room. We were totally fine with that. But she wast still checking the system because we walked in the rain fron Shinagawa station to the hotel. Then she found an upgraded room was almost ready! I've got free upgrade and no waiting time! The room was absolutely gorgerous. We love this hotel!

There are shuttle services from Shinagawa Station or it is an 8 minute slight uphill climb to Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa. There are a number of towers and different brands of Prince hotels in the area, so do spend some time to know the restaurants, bars, and short-cuts around the properties.We picked this property because of its large room size, discounted rate (-60%) for advance booking (3 weeks), proximity to major train station and because it was recommended by our local business contacts.The hotel has a very large lobby and at 2pm, we had to take a cue and line-up for check-in. There were at least 10 front desk staff helping with check-in and over 60 people in the lobby waiting. Maybe it was the weekend, there were lots of families with kids in the public area and getting to/from the pool. Surprisingly, the place is not noisy, everyone is well mannered, and it was a very comfortable environment.

Hotel is very convenient and in walking distance to Shinagawa Station. The airport limousine shuttle bus from Narita Airport takes you to the door. The rooms are a reasonable size and bigger than most hotels in Japan. I would highly recommend this hotel and will definitely stay here again on my next visit to Japan.

This is my family's favorite hotel and we always try to stay here during our stay in Tokyo. The rooms are gigantic, including the bathroom with a bathtub! The room was very clean, bed quality was okay. The location is extremely convenient within a 5 min walk to Shinagawa station. Wing dept store was conveniently located next door to Shinagawa station where we could buy food and drinks from the supermarket. (The prices at Wing were much cheaper that the food shops within the train station). Shopping is not extensive as Shinjuku but I prefer Shinagawa station because it's not as crowded and is located only a few stations away from Shinjuku.The concierge staff were so courteous and spoke exceptional English. The only minor drawback was the walk from Shinagawa station back to the hotel is up hill. This could be exhausting if you and your kids try to drag your heavy suitcases with you.

Good location, just a 5 min walk to Shinagawa station. The airport limousine shuttle bus leaving Narita Terminal 2 takes about 80 mins, depending on traffic , to get to the hotel. I was pleasantly surprised at the size of the rooms, certainly bigger than I am used to with other hotels in the local vicinity. The hotel has two outdoor pools, although you need to pay 2000 Yen to visit them. The hotel also has shops located within which come in handy. The only negative I can report is that the hotel has no gym. Having said that, on my next trip to Tokyo, I'll probably choose this hotel again.

This is a behemoth of a hotel - hundreds of rooms, a gigantic foyer and endless passages, but the lifts were frequent and our room was spacious, clean, quiet and comfortable with its own dinky little balcony. the scale of the hotel could feel impersonal, but the helpful, courteous staff more than compensated for its size.The location is perfect, and an easy walk to Shinagawa station with its access to the rest of the extensive rail network. The multi-level station is huge, and with many levels, but not at all daunting thanks to the hotel's concierge's printed instructions on platform, level and entry/exit points at Shinagawa Station itself, as well as for stations at the various districts of the city. Thanks to these instructions, we were able to negotiate the rail network with confidence to visit all over Tokyo. Don't be put off by the uphill walk from the station back to the hotel. We did the walk a few times (though with nothing heavier than hand luggage), and had no problems at all.The hotel is set in an oasis of gardens. We felt quite safe walking through them at all times of day or night. They are especially lovely after dark when they are lit by unobtrusive lightingThe hotel caters for business and tourist guests. Its décor is rather dated, but clean and well-maintained. There is an outdoor swimming pool, but don't count on it being available. We were unable to access it in June, with temperatures in the high 20s and low 30sC, because it had not been opened for the season. It was disappointing that WiFi is not available in the rooms, but is available in the lobby at no cost.The breakfast room is a long way from the rooms and breakfast itself is overpriced at $27, and nothing special. For example, the Western breakfast did not make eggs to order, and the bacon was cold and soggy. However, these shortcomings were made up to some extent by the staff's efficiency and helpfulness. The hotel's restaurants were nothing special, and were not really needed. There is a great variety at the station, and between them and the little convenience store in the hotel's basement, our food budget went a long, long way.Great location and service. I would not hesitate to come back.

As the title says, you simply can't beat this place for the location and price alone. You are literally 5 min walk from shinagawa station which is a main hub to basically the rest of the country. If you bought a JR pass and plan on hitting up the rest of Japan this place is the PERFECT home base.The service is perfect (dood its Japan...), the rooms are clean, comfortable and rather spacious for a Japanese hotel. The staff is respectful and professional and eager to hell you with your tourist needs.I also happened to experience an earthquake of magnitude 5.6 at the time of my stay. I can safely tell you this hotel can withstand it lol. I didn't even feel it until the photographs on the wall started rattling.My only gripe about this hotel is that if you want to use the gym its 26$ for a single entry which is ridiculously expensive.

Very comfortable hotel located up the hill approx. 5 minutes from Shinagawa station. Hotel is massive and rooms are clean and spacious. Each room has a a balcony which is quite a novelty. The breakfast room is just located on the other end of the hotel and is quite a trek in the mornings. One of the best elements is the convenience store within the hotel where you can pick up all sorts of snacks up until 1am
user_name:
Warlock7
Jebel Ali, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Hotel is in a great location, about a 10minute walk away from the train station at Shinagawa which is only about 10 minutes away on the train from Tokyo Station. Hotel is a little dated BUT it is clean and staff are very helpful and friendly so I dont know what people complain about! The gardens surrounding the hotel are beautiful and peaceful, great for a stroll at night as its very pretty when the lights are on. We got a great deal and stayed in the Club Double Room which was clean, comfy and huge! Yes, not all rooms in Japan are small as so demonstrated here at the GPNT. Staying on the Club Floor meant we could access the Club Lounge so we got breakfast in the morning and snacks and drinks (juice, soft drink, beer etc) from there all day long. The lady in charge of the Club Lounge was extra helpful - I had an adaptor BUT it was a 3 prong one and all the outlets in our room & the lounge were all 2 prong outlets so she tracked down a 2 prong outlet for us which we were very thankful for as my laptop needed charging. Room had free wired internet and wifi was only accessible in the lobby which was nice to sit to people watch. Bathroom was big and clean, shower was hot & had good pressure (which is important to me). We had a view of the Tokyo Tower which we enjoyed looking at from our balcony. Bed was HUGE and very comfy. Problem was the pillows. Like pretty much all the hotels we stayed in in Japan, they were very hard so gave me neck pains and headaches (one side is traditional Japanese pillow of buckwheat and the other side of the pillow is hard rubbery "western" style)Plenty of restaurants in the hotel and all around the hotel. Like all train stations in Japan, it has lots of places to eat and theres a shopping complex opposite the train station that has many more restaurants. On the walk back to the hotel from the train station, there is a an Outback Steakhouse (yummy!), TGI Fridays and and many more. We caught the train to Haneda International Airport from here which was quick, cheap and easy to do so there is no need to take a shuttle bus or taxi there. We would recommend to others to stay here as its lovely and great vallue for money.Word of advice - take a taxi from the train station as the hotel is up a hill and its a trek when you have luggage. Taxi is only about $7 (and make sure you specify The Grand Prince New Takanawa as there are 4 Prince Hotels next to each other) Also, staff are friendly but strict - we had a flight at 11pm and asked if we could check out a little later than the checkout time (which we were confused as to what it was - in the room info file it said 12noon and desk said it was 11am). We only wanted to check out at 1pm (as we thought it was noon) BUT were firmly but friendly told "no, checkout is 11am". We left our bags there so we could explore more of Tokyo for some hours.AND for those with dogs, this is a dog friendly hotel. They have rooms where you can stay with your dog and also have a doggy day care where you can leave your beloved furry friend whilst you go our touring or have work meetings.

This is one of many Prince Hotels located on this property. It is a 5 minute walk up the hill from Shinagawa Station where there are many shops and restaurants. The club level rooms are modern and clean, but during the summer the AC cools the room to only 74F and turns off at night, and during the winter it is turned off and the rooms get to about 78F (nice for those that like their room on the warm side, but not so nice if you like it cool). The lounge does not have a good selection. Breakfast is merely bread, pastries, cereal and drinks, and in the evening it is only beer, whiskey, and small snacks. The gym is located in the Sakura tower and costs about $22 a day but is very well equipped and the club level rooms have free access to the sauna and lockers.

Our room (on 5th floor) was comfortable and fairly spacious. The bathroom was clean and bright. The shower was nice and water temperature easy to control. The beds and pillows were very comfortable. The staff were polite and helpful, as one would expect from a Japanese hotel. Every room has a balcony which is nice, although being only on the 5th floor, the view wasn't great. But it was a quiet room.The room rates did not include breakfast but there were cafes in the vicinity - Tulley's was very good. There was also a 7 Elevens store in the hotel which was very handy.The gardens connecting the various Grand Prince Hotels is worth a walk through. It is nicely laid out and tranquil.The less satisfactory points - The wardrobe/closet was miniscule - more like a bar with enough room for a few shirts. They obviously don't expect guests to stay for no longer than a night or two. We were travelling for two weeks so there simply wasn't room to hang all our clothes up.Likewise there weren't enough drawers either.We were surprise that they did not provide moisturiser amongst the toileries. I was rather banking of it, so didn't bring any with me. But I bought some at a chemist later, so it wasn't a big deal.I will be happy to stay here again, but I might ask for a higher floor room

My daughter and I stayed at this hotel during our stay in Tokyo. Room didn't have Wi fi which was a real pain and there was no breakfast restaurant in the hotel, you had to go to a neighbouring hotel although the walk through the lush Japanese gardens separating the hotels lessened the pain. The staff were helpful enough. They were often dealing with large numbers of people because it was a big hotel but they always did their best to help you. The room service staff were the standout for us. They went out of their way to make sure you were satisfied with their service. This hotel badly needs it own restaurant next to the lobby. They certainly had the space for it.

Disappointed as they had renovated rooms and we asked for one and were refused. Hotel was not full.staff very helpful apart from the above. Room large comfortable but tardy and worn, unusual to have a balcony on 11 floor but great view of tokyo tower. Shinagawa station very busy so miss rush hour but great central location for underground routes, hotel was expensive for food but down the hill a great breakfast place. Would recommend if you can get a renovated room.

Walking distance from Shinagawa station if you travel light. We were upgraded to the club floor as our anniversary gift, Our room was a good size room, really nicely decorated and clean. The view from the terrace was also very nice. It is a very big hotel and there a number of prince hotels in the area so make sure you arrive at the correct one!

Stayed here for 2 nights. The hotel boasts very convinient location near Shinagawa JR hub and surrounded by a charming Japanese garden. There is even a Sinto shrine with a huge antique bell and a big pond with Koi fish. The hotel style is quite modern, though somewhat impersonal, like most of Japanese standard hotels are. The rooms are fine - enough space to live in, convinient bathroom with all the supplies including toothbrushes and combs. The breakfast is served in a cosy restaurant with a terrace overlooking the garden. The food is fine too. The hotel is quite popular with local airline staff and local businessmen, though there were enought tourists too. The airport limo bus also stops there. I would recommend this hotel for sure.

Located very near shinagawa station, the hotel makes for a comfortable stay all together. This is because it is located very near a main tube and JR railway station, in a lively area, surrounded bay very relaxing japanese style garden. The room was spacious with a very comfortable bed and with an touch inside of warmth, as if you are a room in a private house instead than at a hotel. Furthermore, the hotel has a sall but well sourced convenient store at the first floor with food and drins for any emergency.

We really liked Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa. The location is great, just up the hill from the station. The area it is in makes it very convenient, close yet far enough away. The room was nice, the most comfortable I have ever slept in Japan. Loved having a balcony and the bathroom was very nice and well finished for Japan. The room did look worn, it needs some deep cleaning. We didn’t even sit in one of the chairs, just looked horrible. Service varied a lot. Have to give props to one of the ladies in the lobby. She was great and always helped us out. Several times she went I n the back to research and print information for us.

We Arrived at about 10 AM when we arrived and told the rooms have not been clean yet they would try and have a room ready just after 12 noon ( we had been offered an early check in at home at a cost of around $230.00 before we left home )when I inquired about 12.15 Pm the shift had changed and nobody new anything We got int our room at 2 PM normal time the room was spotless The staff were always nice I think we where a bit tired

This beautiful hotel was a superb place to stay in Tokyo. It isn't on the Ginza but that is only a couple of stations away. This hotel is 300 metres from the station but a world away. It was our first night in Japan after a long flight so we ordered room service: it was delicious and served on white linen with silverware. Just the thing for the weary traveller. To be fair the décor is a little dated but it is in excellent and spotless condition. For a plethora of cheap eat choices venture down to the station.

I always check for hairs. Lifted both bed sheets and saw hair on both beds. Maybe i was being too clean, so i just unpacked. Then i saw a big piece of booger on the wall dried up for days. Then i smelled some dinginess on the carpet, looked closer and saw a lot of hair on the floor, dirty balcony... Real bad way to start my first day in Japan. Disappointed. I let the front desk know. I did not want a new room because i did not expect it to be any cleaner. Staff was very kind and helpful, just that the dirty room ruined their image for me. Price of rooms, its size, location,staff was great, but all that us defeated when i cannot be comfortable in my room.

Every traveler arrives in Tokyo absolutely tired , if its not from travelling its from the hussle bussle of the worlds biggest city ,even tho its on time and a world of its own like no other on earth. But arriving at Shinagawa 's huge train station and needing to check in and go out ..there is no way Im walking .. so I take the courtesy bus...trouble is the courstey bus has about 4 Prince Hotels in Shinagawa area , Now was it Shin Pri ? The Prince Tower ? Grand Prince or the Grande Prince ? or The Grand Prince New Takanawa ? Turns out to be the last on the list ...oh well.. Im glad Im not walking . Room is clean , bed is good , bathroom is fine , not one of those old instant toto yellow ones either . Food was reasonable , theres a small store on the 1st floor ( ground Floor to us ) where you can buy some snacks , sando or pretty much anything from a saftey pin to omiyage. The hotel staff were courteous and well mannered of course.. I had to get to Haneda for an ungodly 6:30 am flight ... thought I was close so I took a taxi , I pre booked it it still cost 5400¥en at that time ...lucky the roads werent busy .. The hotel was fine but a little too far to walk from the eki ...where did the other hotle go ..its been renamed gooy or something silly ...its right oposite the station..

We stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa for 8 nights in April 2013. The room itself was big and spacious with comfortable beds, a balcony (our only wish is that we were on a higher floor as we didn't have much of a view), and the kimonos were a nice touch and great to put on at the end of the day. The rooms were cleaned well too. Some of the staff spoke better English than others, and were always compliant and hardworking. They rang our tour operators for us whilst we were out one day to confirm we would be going on our trips. We didn't try the restaurants, only the bakery at the front of the hotel which did a breakfast deal of three pastries and unlimited drinks for 1000 yen. Their pancakes were amazing too. The shops in the hotel opened later (10am) so we didn't get a chance to look round because we were out all day. Our only negative is that there were no English channels on the tv, not even news channels, but the Japanese games shows were quite amusing even if we couldn't understand what was going on. The Japanese garden in the middle of the hotel and nearby hotels was beautiful, we went there on our last day and it felt so peaceful and quiet. Shinagawa station is a 5 minute walk down the road, very convenient, and there is a mall with lots of souvenir shops across from the station. There's also a TGI Fridays and an Outback Steakhouse within a 2 minute walk. Overall, this hotel is in a great location, the service was very good and we thoroughly enjoyed our stay. We would recommend this hotel and we would return if we ever decided to visit Tokyo again.

Spent 5 nights on executive floor (15th) in April. I booked through their own website on a promotional spring 20% discounted rate which was about GBP 95 per night which was a great deal for the quality. The room was spacious with a very comfortable king size bed, comfy chair, desk and chair, TV (Japanese channels only), fridge, fitted wardrobe. It was nicely decorated and had a good view from the small balcony. The bathroom was also nicely appointed. I enjoyed the access to the executive lounge (7am-9pm) on the 16th floor which offered free snacks, drinks and a light breakfast. There was free wifi in the lobby downstairs but not in the executive lounge which was a bit inconvenient. Unfortunately no gym and the swimming pool is only open in the summer. The location is great, just a short walk up from Shinagawa station which gives you access to the Narita Express, Shinkansen bullet trains and the JR Yamanote line and many other subway lines. I didn't eat at any of the hotel restaurants but there is a convenience store in the lobby which is handy. I didn't find too many good dining options in Shinagawa but there are so many options elsewhere this doesn't matter.

We stayed there for 7 days in late March 2013. The hotel was relatively old, but well maintained. The room have been updated with very comfortable beds and bathroom. The room was relatively small compared to typical US hotel rooms, but 3 of us were able to spend the night comfortably. I heard that the restaurants in the hotel didn't have a good cost/value. We only ate breakfast there and I agree. Having said that, the 1,000yen breakfast set at the hotel bakery was worth the cost. You get three pieces of pastries and all you can eat soup, salad, and drinks. The hotel sits at the top of hill near Shinagawa station. The walk was about 5 min, but the hill was pretty steep coming back from the station to the hotel.

Very big hotel , big rooms, but necessary need updating! Confusing numbering of the rooms. Terrible toilets in the lounge. Wonderful garden with blossoming cherry trees and lake full of fish improved the impression. Breakfast ok, but nothing impressive.

Big hotel, just up the hill from Shinagawa station. Close to restaurants and shopping. Other than that it's a throw-back to the glory days of the early 1980s. Internet is wired in the rooms, but there is no WiFi in the room unless you bring your own hotspot, or you rent a wireless router from the front desk (1000yen per night). The lobby does have free wi-fi, though, so you can check your messages on your phone There is a convention center on the premises and three similarly named a steady stream of pedestrians walking through the lobby. All day and night, it looks like a line of dark-suited ants walking in from the street, up the stairs, and disappearing down the hallway past the elevators. Fascinating.One last note, make sure you know which Grand Prince has your reservation! Otherwise you'll be walking all over the area, going from hotel to hotel. Come to think of it, that must be the reason for all the foot traffic passing through the lobby.

The hotel is really big... Is in strategic position, close to the Shinagawa station, equipped with everything that make this hotel perfect. The staff speak english very good, the rooms are clean, and they have lan cable and wifi acces to the web. The unique thing to mention: there is a couple of very similar named hotels in the area, you must concentate in search the Grand Prince Hotel NEW Takanagawa, because there is other Gran Prince Hotel Takanagawa, and even a Grans Prince Hotel Sakura in the same area.The garden of the hotel is one of the best point, you can relax a little bit in a calm and silent are in the heart of the noise city...

As Tokyo hotels go, its not bad. The rooms are nice and spacious and clean. There are just a few things that let it down:1. Limited wifi access (you have to ask for a router and they are frequently "out").2. Bureaucratic and slow check in/check out. OK, its Japan so this is normal.3. Awful western breakfast choices. They used to let you use the breakfast coupons in the seven eleven, but they stopped that, forcing you to have a fried egg and one strip of bacon in the Marmolade restaurant.Having said all that, its nice and close to the station and its quiet. I will keep on using this hotel and all the while wishing that the management would just step it up and create a great hotel instead of settling for "good".

The hotel was really excellent in all aspects. It was a 5 min walk from the Shinagawa station on JR line providing easy access to the main city areas like Harujuku,Tokyo Station, Shinjuku and Akhiabara without the hassle of changing to another Metro line. It is also an extremely peaceful location away from all traffic which is a great plus in Tokyo. The beautiful Japanese garden at the entrance further ehances the grandeur and serenity of the place. the room size by far is one of the largest you might get in Tokyo in the $175-200 price range. They even have a 30 minute free shuttle service from the hotel to Shinagawa station in case you are tired after walking around the very beautiful and busy Tokyo. Front office staff was very helpful and could converse well in English. There was free Wifi in the lobby and cable LAN Internet in rooms. It was the perfect place to end my wondeful Japan trip as it had all the elements of Japan, The most courteous people in the world, Beautiful Serene Japanese Garden with wonderful Japanese structures and perfection in everything around.

I stayed here two nights while visiting my company's office in the Shinagawa area of Tokyo. Location was very convenient. Took the express train from Narita Airport to Shinagawa Station (just 1 stop) and walked from the station to the hotel. The hotel itself is fine. As noted in other reviews it is showing its age but I found it perfectly fine. The room size was generous. No Wi-Fi connectivity in the room but a wired connection was available. There were several small restaurants within the hotel including a European-style bakery/cafe (convenient for breakfast). And the room rates were very good for Tokyo.

The location for Bullet train, subway, Airport connection is excellent, away from the city or financial centre, rooms pretty average and old, ambience is pretty ordinary, lobby is spacious, but room comfort is opposite, bathrooms very old fashioned similar to business type hotels, though it has lovely garden but lack the importance of rooms being of any value, money wise it is just Ok, surrounding areas are good with plenty of Restaurants and transport

I was hesitant at first to book this hotel after reading the reviews but I was running out of options having to make a last minute trip to Tokyo where all the other recommended hotels by our local Japanese friends were fully booked. I am happy to say I'm very pleased with my decision. Like other Asian metropolitan cities such as Hong Kong, Tokyo is not that big and public transportation is very convenient. The nearest station is just a short 5 minute walk from the hotel which connects you to the subway in less than 4 short stops and there are plentiful taxis waiting outside at the front lobby, also the airport limo express picks up/drops off at this hotel. We reserved a superior triple suite because I was traveling with my teenage daughter, the room is very spacious with a separate lounge area, private balcony, and a modern updated bathroom. Sundries are provided by Shiseido and a 7-11 convenience store is located downstairs which carries everything from snacks to ready-made bento boxes. We also tried Edelweiss Cafe which sells baked goods, but because there's more than one Grand Prince Hotel in the vicinity, many more dining options are available as well as the mall next to the Shinagawa station. Don't bother to try communicating with the operator and just dial concierge if you need assistance in English. Unfortunately, the outdoor pool is only seasonal so we didn't get to utilize their other facilities besides the tiny self-service business lounge. Wifi is only free in the lobby.

On the plus side. This hotel is situated in urban Tokyo but is situated in a garden complex, until you slip out of a side door you feel you are staying in the country.The hotel has great views of the city from the higher floors.On the downside, I'm not sure if this is indicative of hotels in Tokyo but it felt dated and old. Many people were smoking in the lobby. I did not manage to locate a health club. THERE IS NOT WIFI!!!! The breakfast was poor.

Stayed here for a total of 3 nights in Jan of 2013. Cute lil hotel and not as small as the other Prince Hotels in the Shinagawa area. Not too bad at all to be honest. THe price is about $200/night and there is nothing fancy about this place. But the location is superb, there are tons of places to shop and eat at within 5 minutes and the station is only 5 minutes down the hill. staff were good, the rooms were clean and there is a small lanai out there too so I can get some fresh air. I liked it and if you see my other reviews, you know I dont like all hotels! oh the other bad thing.. internet is free but you need a router or something. cause there is no wifi cept for the lobby. there is free wired internet in the rooms though

The location of the hotel is great ! It is a short walk (up the hill) from the Shinagawa Train station.The hotel itself is gigantic but has nothing much to offer in terms of ambience and decor ! Good place to sleep and get out. The breakfast was average at best and the shopping facilities inside is below average. There is a 7-11 conveniently located within this building !There are some good restaurants on your walk to the Shinagawa Train station as well. If you would like to go where the locals go for food, take the train to Shibuya train station and go downstairs (basement of the Shibuya train station). It is a food paradise ! All local food freshly made and it is a great way to experience Japanese cuisine.The Shinkansen is also conveniently located in the Shinagawa train station.

Location - far from city centre . Property very nice . Language is a problem . Staff friendly and helpful . Rooms good but not very well equipped as are most hotels in Japan . Breakgast very good but could have more non - Japanese / Chinese and particulary for vegetarians .

I think this may be the biggest hotel I've ever stayed in: it was absolutely huge. You walk into an enormous lobby, and there are about a million rooms. Possibly more. It's part of a larger complex with some other Prince hotels too: keep a note of the exact name so you don't end up in the wrong place.We stayed as part of a family holiday during which we stayed in three hotels in Tokyo and one in Kyoto. This was a large hotel that looks to be set up mainly for conferences and businesspeople, although as we were there during the week between Christmas and New Year, it was a lot less businessy than I suspect it usually is. In spite of the size, service wasn't impersonal or unfriendly: all of the staff went out of their way to be helpful. Check-in and check-out were surprisingly fast and easy given the very large number of guests. We had asked for two interconnecting rooms, but the hotel doesn't have any. Instead, we got two double rooms. Both were large, clean, comfortable, and had loads of storage space. The outside of the hotel looks a bit 70s, but our rooms were extremely modern: they seem to have been very recently renovated. The beds were very comfortable. My only real criticism of the rooms would be that they were far too warm. Even though it was late December, I had to keep my window open. We couldn't do that in the kids' room, though - it was a full-length sliding door onto a balcony, and it wouldn't have been safe. There was free, fast, wired Internet. There was a reasonably big TV with CNN and BBC. The location is great: it's about five minutes' walk from the Takenawa exit of Shinagawa Station. The bullet trains to and from Kyoto and Osaka stop there: if you're travelling to the hotel from another city, get off the bullet train at Shinagawa station rather than Tokyo station. There was a 7-11 convenience store on the ground floor, and an ATM that took a full range of international cards (something of a rarity in Japan): both of these things were incredibly helpful. This was a high-quality, no-nonsense, business-focused hotel. I'd be happy to stay here again.

I stayed in this Hotel recently for more than a week. This was a great business type hotel located within a 5-minute walk from the train station Shinagawa. Nothing about the hotel was extravagant yet up to standard. There are plenty of malls and other eating spots around. Rooms was clean and basic. Great view from the room in mornings and evenings. We could view the Tokyo tower from our room. There were little areas to socialize other than the lobby. Food was excellent. Both Western and Japanese food are served in the hotel restaurant. There was a lot of variety. I very much enjoyed breakfasts at Marmolada, which was tasty and great value for money. WiFi was available for free in the lobby area but not in the rooms. A cable connection is provided for rooms. Great service and the reception staff are well spoken in English which made life easy.However, the feel of the hotel was more western than Japanese for me.I had a lovely stay here and probably go back if and when I go to Tokyo again.

Outlook very nice but not the hotel room , may need upgrading inside the room , furniture look old .free Wifi only available in Lobby , not convienience for people who want suftnet in the room. Staff is very helpful. Standard breakfast nice with street view.

I would certainly recommend this hotel, even after a reservation mix-up. We booked our hotel reservation via Booking.com several weeks before arriving at the hotel. We had a printed confirmation with us when we checked-in. The hotel had the wrong check-in date, which caused some confusion. After a twenty minute wait in the lobby, the error was corrected. Since the hotel was responsible for the error, I requested a room upgrade for our inconvenience. The request was honored, and my wife and I enjoyed a larger hotel room overlooking the Tokyo skyline. We loved our accommodation and the location of the hotel. It is very close to the Shinagawa Train Station, which is a stop for the Shinkansen to Kyoto and Osaka.

Pros: Located near the Shinagawa train Station which is convenient for accessing other parts of Tokyo. Take the west exit from the station and go up the street where you can see Prince Hotel buildings. Go past Outback, Singapore Seafood, TGI Fridays, etc and you'll find the hotel on the right.Con: Located uphill from the train station. At night, lugging heavy luggage, it seemed like a long way. Should have taken a taxi. In the morning without luggage, it was a pleasant downhill walk. We didn't actually do anything in the Shinagawa area, though, other than eat and sleep so next time I might try to find a hotel in another part of Tokyo.Pros: Convenience store located onsiteCon: Food is expensive but there are many, many options only a block or so away.Pro: Nice size room; nice shower flow and hot water; robes & tea providedCon: Furnishings are rather industrial and the public areas are a little tired. This is a convention type hotel.Pro: Limousine Bus is available to the airport.

Conveniently located next to the Shinagawa Train Station and to the Takanawadai Subway Station, you can reach a lot of places from here.The rooms are big and clean. There's a small balcony available as well, and the bathroom has a big space.The internet is fast, and as common with Japanese, the personnel are very welcoming and sympathetic.Do be aware of breakfast, though. It is not included, and there's a restaurant on a lower floor from the lobby that serves it. You end up paying 27€ for a breakfast that is only “normal”, and that it certainly doesn’t live to the standards of such requested price. You better just buy stuff from the convenience stores located on Shinagawa Train Station. There's an Outback Restaurant just across the street in case you're in for something more western.I'd definitely stay here again.

Stayed here during my trip in November for 4 nights and booked the superior twin room with 10% discount of the normal rate. Counter staffs were very polite and efficient, they will always greet you whenever they saw you. But command of English still need slight improvement. Room was in a great and clean condition when I checked in. Surprised at how spacious and clean the room was and there is even a balcony. The view from the balcony was great and the leaves on the tree was starting to turn red. The facilities in the room: mini bar fridge, safe, hotflask, 32" LCD TV, a big n clean bathtub, closet for clothings, a desk for writing, a single seater sofa, a coffee table and 2 super spacious bed etc.Location wise is not bad, but if you are with a heavy suitcase, then the gentle slope to the hotel from Shinagawa JR station might prove tiring and abit challenging. Getting to the hotel from Shinagawa JR station is around less than 10min and to Takanawadai subway station is nearer. The vicinity of the hotel is full of restaurants and cafes but nothing much for you if you want to shop. There is a 7-11 convenience store in the hotel which opens till 2am so no worries if you are hungry at night. Sadly, there is no free wi-fi. You can bring a laptop and connect using your own ethernet cable. If you do not have a laptop, you can use the desktop PC at the business lounge (100yen for 10min). You can also book the airport limousine bus ticket from the hotel as it is one of the boarding point to Narita or Haneda airport. Overall, this is a great hotel with good service and nice rooms but location wise is ok if you do not mind daily traveling to Shibuya, Shinjuku, Harajuku etc. It will be great if wi-fi is provided free.

We recently decided to spend a week in Tokyo on our way back from a trip to Canada, we asked our travel agent to book as 3-4 star hotel close to transport and she recomended the Grand Prince New Takanawa.We found the hotel to be very pleasant, and definately handy for Shinagawa Station, only about a 3-4 minute walk away.The guest relations manager Nami Kawano was a gem. She was extremely patient with my constant hassling for information, gave us maps for everywhere we wanted to go, wrote notes in Japanese for us to give to taxi drivers, etc, and recomended some awesome places for us to visit.Food at the hotel was excellent, breakfasts at Marmolada was excellent quality and great value for money.Our room was always spotless and we had a (little) balcony to take in the morning air and got some great sunrise / sunset views. The gardens between the Grand Prince & Grand Prince new were out of this world, we actually walked the long way to the station just for the pleasure of walking through the gardens! all in all great value!

Great, very nice hotel. Good staff. Very clean. Located a 5-minute walk from the station Shinagawa. A direct train NEX or bus from Narita airport to the station. Superior rooms are located on the upper floors, large room , with a balcony to the garden. The room has a teapot, green tea, slippers, yukata. Comfortable beds, stylish design of the room. Good varied, delicious Breakfast.

The hotel is in a good location if you like quite places with proximity to public transport. You can get to pretty much anywhere in the city from the nearest Shinagawa station. Very convenient if you are arriving into Haneda Airport, taking only a 15 minute train ride on the Keikyu line. The hotel is a 5 minute uphill trek from the station. If you are arriving with more than a hand-luggage or luggage with no wheels, spend the $9 (minimum fare) and take a taxi. You will arrive in the hotel less exhausted. The hotel has a bus service but runs very infrequently, like once every 30 minutes.Must have been a grand hotel in its heydays but is now quite faded. The service is professional and courteous, but not personal. Everything works for the larger average, but not necessarily with your convenience in mind. One feature of the hotel is the beautiful Japanese Garden in the back, part of the larger Prince property of 3 hotels. Definitely worth a walk around it.A typical Japanese business hotel where you get a clean room and that's it. The room I had must have been updated sometime in the last 1-2 years. The room has a small balcony that looks over the neighbourhood buildings. The most frustrating experience was the temperature setting in the room. When I checked in, the room was at a smoking 28 degrees on the thermostat. It was some 12 degrees outside. After attempting many times to set it down to a more comfortable 24 degrees I called the front desk to get some help. The person on the other end repeatedly told me that as it is winter only the heater would work and I cannot use the cooler (!!!!!). Now, this was my plight when I was speaking to the guy in Japanese. After a few attempts explaining to him that I want to use the heater with a lower setting, I was politely told that the temperature cannot be adjusted in the room and if it is too hot, I can turn it off (!!!!!!). Even after turning off the thing, I had to leave my windows (thank god they could be opened) open most of the time. So, I had to use the windows as a manual thermostat throughout my 5-night stay :-(. I was reminded of a cheap hotel I once stayed in Sapporo back in 1995. At least in that hotel they did not claim that they provide air-conditioned rooms and did not have a dummy thermostat in the room. I remember sleeping with my window loosely shut all night, when the outside temperature was sub-zero.If you can afford a few dollars more, stay at the Prince Sakura Tower next door. The rooms are larger and nicer. I have stayed there a number of times and the air-conditioning works. If you cannot afford the dollars, go for a smaller 2 or 3 star hotel. You probably will get better value for money as you won't be paying for the name and features that really are not delivered or don't add real value.

LOCATION – This hotel is not in the city centre, but it is 5 mins walk to Shinagawa station which serves the Shikansen bullet train and a number of other lines. It is also a 10 minute walk to Takanawadai subway station. This makes it really easy to get to most parts of the city. There is a free shuttle bus connecting the hotel with others in the “Prince” chain and Shinagawa station. The airport limousine from Narita airport drops off right outside the hotel. To walk from Shinagawa station to the hotel come out of the west exit, cross the footbridge and walk up the Zakuro-Zaka “slope” next to the Wing Store. I have mobility problems and walked it easily in 5 mins. I don’t know if the other reviewers walked up the hill where the airport limousine route is rather than the slope.ROOM –Large double room with nice décor with a decent sized bathroom which is unusual in Japan. Small balcony with sliding doors, small fridge, kettle and TV with limited English language channels. Hairdryer in bathroom with nice toiletries and other products. Bed very comfortable and no outside noise to disturb sleep.HOTEL –Large reception area, pools, nice gardens. Business centre to print airline tickets etc and a 7-Eleven convenience store selling beers/wine, sandwiches and ready meals that they will heat up.SERVICE – Extremely good. Front desk spoke very good English and were very pleasant. Bell captain very helpful, storing luggage for us and arranging airport limousine tickets.VALUE FOR MONEY –I was booked here as part of a tour, and would normally choose a lower class of hotel in a more central location but I would say it was good value for money.

My husband and I stayed at this hotel as part of a 5 week trip from the UK to Australia including stopovers in Hong Kong and Tokyo during October and November.We caught the airport limousine to the Hotel, took about 1hr 20mins. Its about 5 mins walk to Shinagawa station.Stayed for 3 nights, in superior room which was on 11th floor, with balcony and view over the gardens shared with the other Prince hotelsOn arrival early morning we paid for a few hours early checkin 1000yen per hour before 2pm.We also booked through the hotel guest services an afternoon tour with Grayline, to give us a brief look at part of Tokyo Very nice room huge very comfortable bed and lovely bathroom with Japanese toilet!All the facilities you would want on a long trip e.g. ironing boardHotel is huge, free wifi in the lobby, although for the size of the hotel not many seatsWe used the Cafe Eidelweiss for breakfast on the floor down from lobby near the exit towards the Station, 1000yen, gave coffee/tea, fruit juice, soup and a choice of three pastries from a large selection. There's also a large buffet restaurant available.Lots of multinational restaurants on road down to the station less than 5mins walk, we had good meals at the Outback, and next door french restauarant as well as an Italian near the station entrance.We bought a day ticket on the JR line and used it on the Yamanote circular line and got off/on at various stops along the line before coming full circle back to Shinagawa.On our 3rd day we had a day trip to Kamakura, which had been recommended to us by a Japanese family we met on our travels in Australia.Its about 50mins by train and has enough temples to last you a week of sightseeing. We visited two plus the large Budda.Got the Limo bus back to the airport for our homeward flight, which took around 1hr 40mins in the morning rush hour.The NEX train does go to / from Narita / Shinagawa but we decided to go door to door and use the Limobus.

My girlfriend booked this hotel as we were on a tour and it was convenient for the Narita Express and Shingkansen stations. How nice to have a balcony in a City hotel with great views. This hotel isn't a boutique hotel so what can you expect. The bus service to town is great - remember to book the outbound journey as this is not a 'turn up' service. For what we paid we got what we expected, good value for money and very polite and able staff. Great room, disappointing Club Lounge in terms of variety of offering, but what was there was good quality.

I stayed in Tokyo recently for 4 days. My travel agent did the booking as I new nothing about where to stay. This is a great hotel. Feels Japanese but very Western. Has lots of facilities, including in-house "7 eleven", 3-4 restaurants, shops, humungous lobby (which is just great for waiting for your tour bus to turn up). Rooms are large, clean, and bathroom has all the necessary bits for westerners. No wifi but there is a free cable in the room.Staff here are great. My room had a great view of Mt Fuji (waaaaaay off in the distance - on a clear day of course).This hotel was close to Shinagawa train station which is on the JR line (bullet train stops here), and its only a few stops from Tokyo station. Everyone seems to know Shinagawa!All the tour buses seem to stop at this hotel and there are heaps of restaurants (including western) and nice shops nearby. Only bummer was I could only get Japanese TV, which is no biggie as you shouldn't be spending all your time watching CNN anyway.

At the price equal to 150 EUR/night for a standard room without breakfast this hotel is on the expensive side by the European standards, but this seems to be the low end for Tokyo. Located next to Shinagawa station, in the Minato-ku southern district of Tokyo it does not give you immediate access to the main Tokyo sightseeing locations (I have chosen the locations for business reasons), but with the Yamanote line you can get virtually anywhere in Tokyo relatively easy. There is Narita express train going from Narita airport to Shinagawa station and then it is about a 10 minute walk uphill to the hotel if you choose the West exit of the station. Altogether, a very easy, non-complicated journey from the airport.As some of the reviewers already noted, it is not that easy to figure out which of Prince Takanawa hotels you are going to stay in, I was sure I made a booking for Grand Prince Takanawa, but it turned out it was Prince Takanawa New. The receptionist and hostess girl were very helpful nevertheless and accompanied me to the entrance of the New Takanawa hotel though the beautiful Japanese garden, as well as brought my luggage there. The parcel that I sent for myself in advance to the 'old' Takanawa hotel was promptly brought to the New Takanawa and given to me right away at check in even before I asked for it. Check in was no thrills, and they ask for smoking/non-smoking room preference. The lobby of the hotel is huge and looks like a business center, but inside the room gives an impression of old Japan of the 50s. At least the furniture is in this style, but it does not look dated or too old and everything is perfectly functional. A nice balcony with a view to bamboo garden is a plus. There are yukata sleeping kimonos provided and a tea kettle (that warms up the water and keeps it warm while plugged) and a nice complimentary tea set with green and black teas that they replenish every day. There is a mini-fridge (useful, when you get something to eat for breakfast the night before).The bathroom is small, but everything functions perfectly. There is only cable internet in the room, the speed is quite fast.The room is clean and they offer an option of skipping the daily cleaning if you wish in return for the bonuses in their spa. It is very quiet on the floor and I heard no noise during neither day or night.Check out was also no thrills and they kept my bags for extra 5 hours free of charge. On the way to Shinagawa station and next to both exits of the station there are shops, japanese and other restaurants, supermarkets etc. At every floor there are vending machines with water, tea and other soft drinks. Drinking water is provided every day in the kettle.Altogether it was a very pleasant no-thrills stay and I very much recommend this hotel if you are looking for something in Minato area.

We picked the hotel for its location, next to the rail station. That is the ONLY thing we found good about the place. Our room had furniture right out of the 1950's, stains on the carpet, light fixture held together with tape, faded and worn bedspreads, mold in the bathroom, bugs in the light fixtures outside the room. This was not an acceptable room at any price, and it was not inexpensive. Worst of all, when I expressed my dissatisfaction to the hotel in their survey, their response was only to recommend that I come back in the spring after they remodel. They should not be renting these rooms out until they complete the remodel. Maybe the other rooms would be ok, but DO NOT reserve a standard room.

My husband and I stayed here for 3 nights at the beginning of an 8 night first-time holiday to Japan. We chose this hotel because the rooms appeared to be a bit larger than typical sized rooms in Tokyo and we are glad we did. The "Airport Limousine" bus from Narita dropped us right off at the hotel (3000 yen pp). So convenient! Upon arrival, a friendly female hotel employee whisked our luggage onto a cart while we checked in then escorted us to our room, refusing to take the tip we offered her. We later learned that Japan has a non-tip culture! I think we booked a "deluxe king" on Expedia but when we checked in, the front desk staff informed us they had upgraded us to superior on the 15th floor which is the "Club floor" but without the club privileges. The room was a comfortable size (considerably larger than the Sunroute Plaza Shinjuku Hotel we stayed at our last night which is small but less expensive which I would also recommend - see separate review). The room had two chairs, a safe and a little balcony which was really nice to step out onto for fresh air and take in the view of Tokyo and the gardens below. We even tended to leave our balcony door open while in the room for fresh air. A tea and coffee station were provided, along with a stocked fridge of beer/cold drinks (for a cost of course) which allowed enough room for us to put a few things into. His and her PJ's were provided! The bed and pillows were sooooo comfortable with nice crisp white linens/comfy duvet. The bathroom provided an abundance of complimentary amenities and the shower was awesome!This is a great hotel to make as a "home base" while travelling in Tokyo. Nearby Shinagawa train station is an easy 5 minute walk and is a hub where you can take a train to virtually anywhere in Tokyo from. I wouldn't be concerned by some of the comments made on TA about "the hill". I had injured my knee prior to our holiday, and although it was bothering me, I had no problem walking to and from the station. Likewise, I would disregard any complaints people have made about the large convention centre like lobby in the hotel. It's fine. We never dined at the restaurants in the hotel but instead ate at a number of places in and around the large shopping mall across the street from the train station which we liked. (There are also a lot of restaurants on route from the hotel to the station including an Outback Steakhouse!). We frequented the little supermarket at the train station to purchase yogurt, fruit and cold drinks for breakfast and beer and wine for our room. There are tons of shops in the train station including an amazing french pastry shop (Anderson's?) which has pastries to die for!Upon checkout, we took the free hotel shuttle to the station with all our luggage to continue on with our travels. If you were leaving the Prince to return directly to Narita, the hotel would make a reservation for you on the Airport Limousine bus. Departure times are posted in the lobby.I would highly recommend this hotel and if I were to return to Tokyo, would definitely consider staying here again.

Position was great as very close to major train station, and close to shops, restaurants etc. We had twin non-smoking room and found we had plenty of room and were very happy with everything. Complimentary shuttle to station was good when we had suitcases, but otherwise we didnt bother with it. We didnt find noise a problem, so obviously it wasnt.

Its a 10 minute walk uphill from Shinagawa Station, but the location is excellent and the Japanese garden is an oasis in the concrete jungle. The refurbished Superior Room is a good size and comfortable, though not luxurious. The bathroom is rather small and the shower equipment dated. This is a Japanese hotel so don't expect international standards, but service is good and Wifi is available in the room on request at a very reasonable cost. The lobby is rather cavernous - more like a transit lounge - and lacks atmospher and the restaurants are better in the neighbouring Grand Prince Takanawa. With PCI membership the rates are reasonable and price to performance ratio is high. This is now my hotel of choice for visits to Tokyo.

Stayed 2 nights on a business trip, very covenient distance from the main train station and business center with plenty of facilities to satisfy needs. I found the breakfast here to be very good, but I do not understand why was I forced to have chinese breakfast everyday while there are some other restaurants to pick from. The receptionist and the information counter were extremely friendly and we could fetch ourselves some local curry dinner from their advices.I enjoy this hotel pretty much except for the breakfast and the lobby only wi-fi, which the quality wasn't up to my expectation either, but the rest is excellent for a business trip.

Nice position, food, well equiped. 100m. from Shibuya metro station. Just I was not happy to pay extra money for Gym (21â¬ for a 1h) i finde to much. No Wi:Fi in room ( just in Hotel lobby) , just conection wit cable in case that you have computer.

Stayed 6 nights on holiday, well positioned and close to major train station. Beds rock hard. Some staff speak a little English. Food prices in hotel make you look elsewhere to eat, nearly $40USD for Buffet breakfast. No laundromat, only overpriced laundry service. No WIFI in rooms or lobby, pay around $12USD for internet access, is this 2012?Only 1 tv station in English, I never want to watch BBC world news again!Hotel has it's own 711 in lobby.Glad we booked elsewhere to stay later when we return to Tokyo, nothing special to make you want to stay here again. Did like a tiny balcony to venture out to.

Nice and clean, wirh a great garden and poolarea, but nothing for the tourist who like to enjoy the "real" Japan even at night. Good location within 20 minutes from most atractions in Tokyo. several restaurants to eat brakfast and as everywhere in Japan serviceminded staff. But where is the TV in English?

We did not choose this hotel as it was part of a convention trip and whilst understanding the demands placed upon the organisers, it did not live up to expectations in any way or manner. Whilst it was clean and the room spacious, the hotel was in no way intimate nor did it give you a flavor of Japan. This is a business-person's hotel The staff tried hard at being efficient however I felt that they were hamstrung by onerous rules placed upon them by management. The main hotel entry leads one into a cavernous area devoid of any ambience and effectively reminds you of entering a Russian State mausoleum. (Sorry Russia, no disrespect). Apart from one large mural on the long hallway, this hotel could have been placed anywhere in the world. In this bleak partially lit cavern you will find lots of chairs for your benefit whilst waiting for the airport limo or taxi or tour busses, but not in anyway personal. As for the "lounge coffee/bar service" in this area, I went there on one occasion at 1:15pm to get some sandwiches only to be informed that they had sold out - OK fair enough I thought, so I asked as to how long before they were able to make up some more (lots of people milling around) the answer - "oh, so sorry Sir, once sold out, that is it!"To be fair, the location of the hotel was reasonably convenient (in a manner), however, should you wish to visit the more vibrant areas, a train or cab trip was needed at all times. The hotel is located just a block from Shinagawa train station, it was easy to take the train to anywhere in Tokyo (on the JR Line - be careful on the trains as several operators and the passes aren't always transferable). Lots of reasonably priced eateries in and around the station, great food located in the supermarket just adjacent to the station (take the escalator down one floor, you will be amazed!). Preferred these to the pricey hotel restaurants. If you are travelling for business, this would be an appropriate hotel. For the vacationers among you, I would choose something far smaller and more intimate. Also, if you want English-speaking TV, choose a room above the 6th floor. We stayed here 5 nights. As for the Club Floor Level - FORGET IT (sorry to shout) this would be the most disgraceful attempt at a club floor that I have ever seen in over 30 years of business travel. The rooms are on the highest two floors, however that is were it ends. No extra service of any description, no wine or nibbles after 5pm, as for breakfast - coco pops and white bread for toast only! Oh, want a swim in the pool? Then only come on the weekend! Also they may close the pool area if they deem it to be too hot. We were a bunch of sun loving Australians and to have our water access cut was like loosing a limb! Also, guess what, as a guest in the hotel you still have to pay for the privilege of using the pool! Like a work out in the gym - same deal for guests, pay, pay, pay. Feel like a drink after a lazy Sunday afternoon, well don't go to the bar in this hotel - it is closed Sunday and Monday's!In nutshell would I return to this hotel - no way! For the price of a club floor room and expected extra services, it was a non event. Tokyo has a lot to offer for the visitor / businessman, however this hotel is one to miss if you desire anything more than a room.

Me, my husband and our child stayed 4 nights at this hotel for our first visit to Tokyo. Considering hotel prices in Tokyo this one is very convenient for what you get. Staff is good and with quite a good English. No wifi in room, not understandable in 2012. Room size good, two single beds close together plus another single for our child, the decor is very 80, the hotel was built 30 years ago. Quite close to Shinagawa station, in a road uphill from the station and downhill from the hotel, from Shinagawa station you can easily reach all tourist locations by tube and also the very fast trains, Shinkansen, stop here. Slippers in room and typical Japanese toilet. Our room had a balcony. We find the location very convenient to sightsee Tokyo

This was my second trip in a few weeks to this area - my first trip I stayed at the Grand Prince Takanawa, which I've also reviewed. This hotel is slightly more expensive (I paid an additional $30 per night), but it is absolutely worth it, particularly in the summer. Staff friendly, but couldn't do early check-in without paying for another night, which is something to bear in mind when your flight lands at 5am! Wi-fi in lobby, but not in rooms (wired in rooms - all free). Decent sized room, but specify if you want a double bed, otherwise you will get 2 singles. Very large complex, very close to Shinagawa station. This hotel is worth the additional money because the air-con is much better (absolutely essential in Japanese summer), the bathroom/products are way superior, and the room is just bigger and better. A balcony on the 12th floor was a nice touch and means you can get fresh air in the room. Would stay here again, definitely in preference to the Takanawa.

Tokyo is famous for their tiny hotel rooms, but this hotel is pretty spacious. It's walking distance to Shinagawa JR station, walking from the hotel to the station probably takes 7 min cos it's downhill, walking back to the hotel probably takes 10-15min. Luckily they have s shuttle bus so you don't have to lug your suitcases uphill, but don't expect the drivers to help you with the suitcases. The rooms were big enough to place a sofa set and we have a pretty balcony (we booked 2 rooms). Service wise was a little lacking, compared to the other hotels I have stayed in Tokyo so far, e.g. Dai-ichi, Villa Fontaine, Hotel Trusty, etc. We had to pay for wifi, it wasn't even free in the lobby.

I stayed with my husband ( a work trip) for 3 nights in a club room. Good room, the club facilities gave you free access to soft drinks/beer and small bisciuts or nuts/nibbles- depending on time of day- then around 6pm 1 bottle of whiskey was put out!--the room was nice/large...great bathroom.We ate breakfast down in the 'normal breakfast resturant' rather than just in the club lounge---not a great breakfast..and a long walk to get to it!!!!!!!!!!!Good location near Shinagawa station, which has links to everywhere in tokyo. Very large-unpersonal-business lobby....efficent staff. No character.The hotel kept our luggage free of charge-as we left to Kyoto for 2 nights...the limousine airport bus was useful and again efficent...

We chose this hotel and while it was clean and the room spacious, the hotel was in no way intimate nor did it give you a flavor of Japan. This is a business-person's hotel The staff was efficient and helpful, but with the exception of one large mural on the long hallway, this hotel could have been anywhere. The lobby is cavernous! Lots of chairs for waiting for the airport limo or taxi or tour busses, but not in anyway personal.The location of the hotel was very convenient, however. Just a block from Shinagawa train station, it was easy to take the train to anywhere in Tokyo. Lots of reasonably priced eateries in and around the station. Preferred these to the pricey hotel restaurants. If you are travelling for business, this would be an appropriate hotel. For the vacationers among you, I would choose something far smaller and more intimate. Also, if you want English-speaking TV, choose a room above the 6th floor. We stayed here 3 nights and the first 2 nights even BBC was in Japanese. We were told one has to stay above the 6th floor to get English stations on the TV. We requested that on the third night.Easy check in and out, plus free storage of luggage. Check-in time is 2pm. If you arrive early and you want to check in, it will cost you an extra 3,000 yen. We waited until 2pm.

I last stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa slightly less than a year ago, and just like my previous visit, this stay was amazing.Getting to this hotel is easy, as it is located very near to the Shinagawa station, a major station that serves many lines. If you are arriving from Narita airport, head over to the airport's JR service counter and ask for a NEX/Suica pass (5000 yen per person).
