This pass offers a two-way airport transfer via the NEX train (just as comfy as a bullet train, but not as speedy) plus a Suica JR train card with 2000 yen credit for you to explore Tokyo. The NEX stops at Shinagawa station, where you can take the free hotel shuttle bus (one bus every half hour) from the station's main exit. Compared to taking a limousine bus (3000 yen one way), you can save about 3000 yen in all.Mirroring my previous trip, I booked a Superior Room with the hotel again this time, and was very happy to find, upon check-in, that I was given a room on the Club Floor. While the Club room featured slightly more luxurious rooms compared to the regular Superior, the experience was mostly the same - it's a really comfortable, beautifully designed space. Rooms also feature a small balcony where you can walk out to take in the fresh air, a very nice and classy addition that I have yet to encounter at any other hotel in Japan thus far.While the room is not exceptionally large, it is still generous by Japanese hotel standards, and there is definitely more than enough space for two people. However, the wardrobe is a little small, and it might be a but of a squeeze especially if you are sharing a room with someone, or when you are lugging along heavy, bulky winter clothes.The service at this hotel is good, almost all the staff speak very good English and are exceptionally helpful and friendly. There was one afternoon when I locked myself out of my room, but the lady at the guest relations counter was able to help me get out of my predicament very quickly. I had also gotten ready assistance from both the front desk staff and guest relations staff for receiving and sending mail during my stay. When I lacked a large enough envelope for my items, a staff member readily provided me with one at no extra charge.Shinagawa is located in the south of Tokyo, making it quite an ideal place to set off from especially if you would like to shop. Traveling time by JR train (Yamanote Line) to both the glitzy Ginza shopping district and the trendy Shibuya/Shinjuku area are an equal 15 minutes in different directions. For families with children, or for the child at heart, the Tokyo Pokemon Center is at Hamamatsucho, about 10 minutes away by JR train.The only gripe I have is that the hotel's shuttle bus ends in the early evening, at about 8 pm or so. Once the bus service ends, you'll have to make your way to the hotel yourself. While this road is brightly lit and never quiet, the uphill climb can be pretty tiring especially if you're lugging lots of shopping bags, or when the weather gets very warm in the summer. While this short hike will take you about 10 to 15 minutes at most, there are always cafes, restaurants, and even vending machines along the way up should you need to stop and take a break.

The first impression on check in is a rather large, somewhat gloomy lobby,seeming like a remnant from the 60s or 70s. Very crowded when we checked in, but we later realised delegates from the adjacent conference center we passing through.That said, check-in formalities were handled nicely and efficiently. The 'superior' room was large (by Tokyo standards) and overall very comfortable. As small balcony afforded some fresh air and views. No wi-fi in the room, only (free) hardwire internet.The hotel is 5-10 mins walk directly up a gentle hill from the surface rail station and about 15 min walk in the opposite direction to the metro. Pretty convenient although you might struggle to find the hotel from the metro the first time without good directions.There is a bus service to both airports from the hotel costing about the same as Narita Express train. The actual journey takes a bit longer but by the time you walk to the station, wait on the platform and maybe transfer at Tokyo station, the bus would be the more convenient option.Overall a good, convenient to stay in Tokyo and the price reflects that you are not right downtown.
Absolutely excellent location. Upgraded rooms are very nicely done & for Tokyo, cheap. Only glitches ....no free wifi & the lobby's a bit dingy. Fantastic views facing north. Will keep coming back!

We spent 4 nights in this hotel, in "superior" standard rooms (ie the 7th floor upwards). The rooms were bigger than the average Japanese hotel room and very nicely furnished, although clothes storage is always a bit of an issue in Japanese hotel rooms and this was no exception. The beds were marvellous; we didn't investigate but they appeared to have memory foam mattress toppers on, and were really blissfully comfortable to us Western softies, and we all slept extremely well every night. They have a scheme whereby you can decline to have your bedlinen and towels changed and they give you a 500 yen voucher to spend in the shops for each day you do this. We didn't opt for it, but it's not a bad idea. The little 7-11 convenience store in the hotel was really good and the prices were modest; we bought breakfast materials there rather than spending £20 per head in the coffee shop. The lobby is vast, like an airport lounge, and the hotel is busy and bustling all the time, but the staff are extremely helpful and English is spoken. Luggage storage before checkin and after checkout was no difficulty, the airport limousine bus calls at the hotel and tickets for it can be bought directly from the bell desk. The hotel is a 5-minute walk from Shinagawa station and in a complex surrounded by other Prince hotels, with access to their guest facilities. There are various restaurants around, and a nice Chinese eating place on the station frontage, plus a handy food court in the Shinagawa Prince hotel shopping complex just down the hill, with sensible prices and a variety of outlets where you can get soba, ramen, takoyaki, okonomiyaki, pizza, katsu and other fast food. All in all it was an excellent base for exploring Tokyo, using our JR passes on the Yamanote line from JR Shinagawa station. And we got an excellent deal (buy 4 nights save 40%) which meant we paid a remarkably low price. We would very happily return to this hotel.

A friend put us up at this hotel and I was somewhat hesitant given the mixed reviews here. I did notice how dated the lobby was, but any thoughts were put aside once we got to our room! We stayed two nights in two different rooms (7th and 16th floors), and both were far bigger and cleaner than what I was expecting (especially the room on the 16th floor, which I think was the club floor). The room on the upper floor also had a great city view. I would stay at this hotel again, it seems like a good deal for the size and cleanliness of the rooms.

Very Large hotel in a group of similar hotels in the Prince hotel chain. Make sure you know the exact address of the hotel as there are a few in the same area with similar names. We chose a room on the club floor, which I am glad we did. Walking on some of the non club floors the corridors looked a bit dated and run down, certainly frayed round the edges. Not sure what the rooms inside were like, but if the outside were anything to go by.Club rooms were a reasonable size with King bed and seating/desk area. Bathrooms were not big but adequate. The balcony was great and allowed good views of the Tokyo skyline.There was a club lounge for these rooms. This was only open from 2pm to 8pm where hot drinks were complimentary. There were cold drinks in a fridge, which included beers. At around 5pm they got out a bottle of whiskey. It was the same bottle they got out during my stay. If you like other alcoholic drinks to that bottle of whiskey and beer you are out of luck. There were a few snacks, but the selection was limited. This club room could do with a breakfast service and a better service throughout the day. In the 5 nights I was there I only saw one other person using the room. It would also benefit from having computers and printers/copiers to use. There is a business centre, which is chargeable by putting coins into the slot, where you can use the internet and print things off. Getting things off the printer is quite a task in itself, you might need to go headhunting at NASA to get someone to help you. I eventually managed to get what I wanted printed but I think it was more luck than good mangagement.The plus side of this hotel is the convenience store which sells food and drinks at a fraction of the price from room service or your mini bar. There is also a good shuttle bus that takes you to Haneda and Narita airports (two separate buses). There is a shuttle bus down to Shinagawa train station but its only a 5 minute walk and not really worth it. On the walk down there are a few eating options as well as at Shinagawa station.Enjoyed my stay here, but I think the rooms need updating. If the Clubroom was better I would consider staying here again, But otherwise probably not.

I have been two times in this Hotel during my last Business trip to Tokyo and Hong Kong. The Hotel is huge and has a small market inside where you can buy water, beer or other stuff once the mini bar in the rooms are empty. In the first time I stayed it was at the 8th floor, the room was pretty good, modern and confortable, it also had a nice view to the Mont Fuji and Tokyo skyline. The second time the room it was on the 4th floor, it was an old room, with very old furniture, but the whole floor seems to be under reform, so it could be soo those rooms will have a better look, anyway in this floor I had no view to the city. Also it is amazing how a Hotel of this level in Tokyo has no Wifi available for their guests and you still need to use the old cable conection, what may fit for a note book, but definitely not for iphones, tablets and ipads...

We spent 3 nights in this very large hotel and found the room to be very good, good size, very clean, nice view - would like to see the gardens in spring. room servicing was to a high standard and the room was quiet and very comfortable. Would stay again.

They offer me to upgrade my room at Yen2000 per night. The room is spacious and should be newly renovated. Wash room is important for me and counter top is usually small in most Japan hotels. But I found their wash room is large and in a careful layout. Their staff speaks good English and polite as other Prince Hotel. The only thing is their restaurant is too small that I could hardly found a seat for breakfast and the food quality is not as good as other Prince.

Grand Prince Hotel New TakanawaThis 3-4 star business hotel is part of the Prince Group, in a large complex sharing a Japanese garden and some facilities. The other hotels in he complex are the Prince Sakura Tower and the Grand Prince Takanawa (be careful when you make a booking as the names are very similar. This is a very large hotel, huge but rather spartan lobby, adjacent conference centre, floors up to 6 are standard and not worth staying in for the price in my opinion. Floors 7-14 are superior, floors 15-16 are the Club rooms. The Club lounge is only open 2-8pm, has a few snacks, tea and coffee and cold drinks, TV and Wi-Fi. Unfortunately not open for breakfast even though the hotel room compendium states this is open from 7am-10pm. There is also an on site convenience store and a ATM machine.Try and get a room facing North towards Tokyo Tower for the best night view. There are small curved balconies for fresh air. The club executive rooms are spacious with a lounge, 2 large 50 inch flat screen TVs, large bathroom with double sink and walk in shower and a bath. There is also a desk,  comfy chair and 2 seater settee. Free bottled water available.Breakfast for ¥2500 at Marmolada Restaurant or you can also go to Patio Grand Cafe in the Grand Prince Takanawa (nice walk through the Japanese garden - if it's raining, just ask the Bell Captain for an umbrellla.  Or there is Japanese breakfast at the Prince Sakura. You can go to any of the 3 restaurants for breakfast as they all are part of the same complex, just show your room card. For my money the Patio Grand is nicer and less crowded. Wired Internet is free in the room but wi-fi costs ¥1000 per stay, so the longer you stay the cheaper it becomes. We had 2 adjoining rooms and only paid the fee for 1 room as we could get connection through the wall.Access to Shinagawa station is via 10 min walk downhill or a 15 min walk uphill coming back with all your shopping. There is a free shuttle bus that picks you up outside the station, 1st pickup is 8. 10am then half hourly, eg 8. 40, 9. 10 ... then 13. 10, 13.30, 14.00 ... 21.00. If you have a JR rail pass you can get on the JR Yamanote line for free by showing your pass to the guard at the barrier. Alternatively you can buy a Suica card at the station and load this up. This can also be used on the subway and at some shops.Overall this is a good but very large business and conference hotel. Shinagawa station is one of the major stops on the Shinkansen train route and has the benefit that is smaller than Shinjuku and Tokyo stations and also has only 2 exits (most people go out the west exit). Tip- upgrade your room if you can afford it. PS: You can claim a tax refund of 5% at major department stores as well as Tokyu Hands and the Loft if you spend more than ¥10501 at the same store on the same day. Bring your passport and receipts to the tax refund counter (usually on the top floor or the basement floor) and they will give you your refund in cash as well as attaching your refund receipt to your passport which is taken off at customs. The good thing is that you can buy several small items as long as the total is over ¥10501 and you do not have to show the items to Customs as you do in Australia.

We stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa in the Superior rooms which were nothing luxury but acceptable (although a little small). The hotel has a very good location, but in general looks a bit tired, particularly the common areas. Service was a bit slow but not so bad; the bell boys (or girls) are actually friendlier than the staff at the reception (also not enough always long queues for check-ins and check-outs).The breakfast (which cost 2500JPY) is not impressive at all... for that price you could probably do much better outside the hotel.

Unusually, I troubled to take photos here. The first night, I almost cried - a grown man of 54 on business trip. But when you need to keep your socks on in the bedroom as the old carpet is actually sticky, when the 'room service' menu is a virtually illegible single photocopy, when breakfast evokes life in a detention centre or boarding school in the 70s, and when everywhere is dirty, dirty, dirty (see my shots of inside the lift, in the 'restaurant' etc)... I have not seen a foyer like it for queueing, and for foetid dusty staleness. In short, do not go to this place. The Intercon nearby is a dream.

This hotel's English and Japanese websites have different packages. Packages on the Japanese website better. This is a good hotel. I stayed in both Superior room and Standard room during the three weeks there. The Superior room is much better. The bed, desks, chairs in the standard room seems to be a bit aged. But both rooms are clean. The hotel is 15 minutes walking from the train station. I went to Tokyo for business so it was fine to walk a little bit everyday after work. But if I go to Tokyo for shopping (and with a child) I probably won't stay here because from the train station to the hotel is uphill . I know the hotel has free shuttle service between the train station and the hotel but I didn't use it.

Well, these are all minor things but all add up. First of all, it's 15min walk from the station, it's actually quite a long walk if you are all tired from your trip during the day. The closest coin laundry is 15min walk away as well. And they have a "main switch" to control the electricity. So once thats off, everything else is. E.g. if I want to go to toilet at night, I have to turn it on, and that turns on every single light in the room. Well, they did give us a torch, but..really? And the LAN net was very bad. It's not the speed, it gets error all the times and sometimes it doesn't even load Google. They provide us with tea cups but no spoons or stirring rod.The mini balcony was actually quite a nice space to have. They provides green service (means no cleaning on that day of service if you choose) and you are given voucher to be used in the hotel's restaurants.

When I decided to book a room at this hotel, pictures of the standard rooms did not impress me, so I booked a superior room instead. This proved to be one of the best decisions I've ever made in more than a dozen trips that I've made to Japan.I was in Japan to watch a concert, and had arranged for the ticket seller to deliver tickets to the hotel prior to my arrival. I wrote an email to the hotel shortly after making a booking about this arrangement, and the hotel manager followed up with a call the very next morning. He had some difficulty understanding me, but after explaining my request using simpler words, he had no problems making the necessary arrangements.The Prince hotels are not exactly a luxury chain, but the experience of staying in a superior room comes pretty close. I got the concert tickets as promised during check-in. However, as I had arrived earlier than the check-in time, I was required to pay ¥1000 per hour for early check-in. Once the paperwork was done, a baggage handler escorted me to my room.The room was large and spacious, and the furnishing was new, modern and hinted of luxury. My only gripe was the leatherette chair at the desk, which had armrests with frayed stitching and was starting to peel. The king sized bed was very comfortable and I had many a good night's sleep.The service was good, and the Internet was free as well. I really liked this feature as I use the Internet a lot. When I wanted to watch a DVD in the room, housekeeping was very quick in sending someone up with a DVD player and fixing it up for me. The service was free and there was no rental charge. I ordered a room service breakfast on quite a few mornings during my stay. The food was not the best, but the price was affordable and the meal was always served on time.The hotel is located in an up-class residential area that can get a little quiet and dark at night, but it is only a short walk to the station and the area is safe. However, the hotel is situated on a slight hill, which means that walking out of the hotel and downhill is a breeze, but going uphill with a ton of shopping can be trying if you are not as fit. There is a shuttle bus that takes you to the station, but they do not come as often as I would have liked.

I knew that the standard rooms in this hotel are not very impressive, so I specifically chose a superior room. We had a toddler with us so it was important that our hotel room was big enough for our child to move around. I was very satisfied. The room was nicely decorated and spacious. Hotel staffs are nice as well. It is a nice short walk from 2 subway stations and free shuttle bus to/from the train station was a plus. A small Japanese garden was a nice addition.A few things we did not like was that (as with many places in Japan) they allow smoking in the lobby cafe so you could smell smoke a second after you step in the hotel. WiFi in the lobby was extra (500 yen) even for the hotel guests (free Internet with LAN in room) which was not that great.

The hotel has a very beautiful big traditional Japanese garden with tea rooms, temples and ponds. The hotel is huge with modern rooms and restaurants. The service is good. At the breakfast you can choose both Asian and Western dishes. There´s also a tiny terrace for the breakfast guests. Pur room was on the highest floor, 15 with a nice view over Tokyo tower, especially at night. Location is practical, near the Shinagawa station.

Stayed three nights at this hotel and had a wonderful experience. The rooms were large and the bed hard but very comfortable. The house keeping service was very good and anything we wanted to do with our room they assisted us straight away. The service at the front desk was very good and they gave us a room with a view looking at a lovely Garden. The meals at the hotel were very good and the service of a high standard.

When I was invited by our local Japanese partner in August 2009, I was very surprised from the first time I came into this hotel....A very nice and greeny place, surrounded by beautiful flowers everywhere.Nice food, nice restaurant, nice rooms equipped with a modern facilities, and serve by a very pleasant staffs...Thanks for your nice service.I hope I could stay in this hotel again one day...

I stayed there the executive room for 3 nights. Room is clean and spacious （~300sqft). I visited japan over 10 times, it's hard to find a room have balcony but room rate is less than £20000 and near JR station. Hotel is newly renovated, furnitures are still in good condition. The only thiing makes it not perfect is the steep long road from entrance to hotel lobby, takes u at around 5 minutes. Walking with empty hands is ok but it's painful if carrying heavy luggages or after crazy shopping. Wifi is free of charge, it saves me a lot money on sending email and browsing Internet. Restaurant is certainly not in Michellin standard. U better make your stomach full before back to hotel. Building is a bit old, but not smelly and stained. Park inside hotel is decorated in classic japan garden style, quite good for slow walk. In all, it's alocation is not perfect for travellers who have tight schedule, but if consider the room rate and condition, stay there is not a wrong decision

Not an hotel I would ever go back too. Staff were unhelpful (the only time in japan we experienced this), if we needed anything it was too much trouble, they didn't understand or tried to charge extra. Our room was probably the hight of luxury in 1960's but now shabby, worn and just plain tired - so were we after a night on the aged matters with the clock in the headboard ticking loudly. Slept upside down on the bed to avoid, unplugged the fridge as even noisier! Room was big but that was it's only merit! Offered another refurbished room at a lot more money, guessing part way through refit and there are decent rooms there somewhere, but had already paid a lot through Hayes and Jarvis so felt we were being ripped off. Stay at Monterey le sour in ginza instead
The hotel is rather old with a funky smell. It doesn't look as good as the pictures. The staff barely communicates in English and the hotel looks decades old. There so many better hotels in the area.

Stayed here for one night (last Saturday) and was shocked at how stuck in a time warp this place was! Sad old 1970's decor with bed and furnishings that looked like they had come out of a Blackpool B&B from a bygone era. Plus they had the audacity to charge us for an early check in after a 13hr flight!! Not good, avoid.

I visit Tokyo once or twice a year and have stayed at this hotel since 2002. A few years ago, I became weary of the miniature furniture and false promises to renovate. After staying away for two years, I decided to give them a try again as their website shows pictures of beautifully renovated rooms. Sadly, the miniature 1950's furnishings and RV like walls are still here! Perhaps, they have renovated some of the rooms, but not mine. The service continues to be excellent, the size of the rooms for Tokyo is very nice, the common areas have been updated, the proximity to Shinegawa Station and international cuisine is extremely convenient and I love the setting with the beautiful trees and garden. Now, if they could just update all of the rooms!

Stayed at this hotel in November. It is conveniently located near the Shinagawa Station, which has bullet train and metro connections to everywhere. The hotel is large and obviously built for conventions, but it was obviously built many years ago. Rooms are a good size, but poorly fitted out by modern standards and you may have to walk quite a distance to get to your room.Tried their Japanese restaurant. I am not a Japanese food expert - although I love it - and I have to say that I have had better meals at many, many other restaurants. TV is very poor for those who don't speak Japanese. Only one or two English language channels.

It's my first visit to Tokyo. Throughout my holiday, I have meant numerous friendly Japanese people except for this hotel. Their counter staff wear a sour face everyday. Everything is just a NO NO NO. NO adaptor for my cellphone battery charger, NO aircon in the room. It is so warm that we have to sleep with the balcany opened. Our room is cramp and the carpet look very old and dirty. Every evening, we drag to return to this hotel. Surprisingly, NO smile, not even a good morning by the staff. NO late check out. Everything is a NO. Location is very poor and inconveneient. Their free shutter bus is so small and driver do not help us with our big bags when we have young children in our arms. etc etc etc.... worse experience ever. Never this hotel again.

I stayed here for two weeks whilst touring with The Australian Ballet. The service was excellent, the rooms were very clean and a good size with nice little balconies and a good bathroom with shower/bath. It is about a 10 minute walk to Shinagawa station - very handy for the Shinkansen and it is also on the JR Rail Yamanote line - access to Harajuku, Ueno, Shinjuku and Shibuya. It was a very leafy area so a nice break from the hustle and bustle of central Tokyo. Shinagawa station has a Wing supermarket and good selection of bars, restaurants and karaoke at the opposite end of the station from the hotel. The staff were very friendly and the breakfast had great variety, although some mornings there were lengthy queues to get a table. There is a patisserie next to the breakfast restaurant and you can use your breakfast vouchers there if you want a quick getaway.I was staying on the 8th floor and I believe lower floors had not been refurbished yet, but my room was very modern and also included free internet access (via cable - not wireless)They have some beautiful Japanese gardens which I recommend you explore. At the time, the pool was closed and there is no gym at the hotel.

Arrived at around midnight straight from Haneda Airport. Its quite close to the station where you can catch airport expresses and the JR line and Shinkansen. SO it's quite convenient. Furthermore, there are restaurants just around the corner. Even though it is a steep uphill climb to the hotel, it was quite okay. Rooms were large and comfortable. The service of the staff were excellent and they spoke excellent English which was helpful. But for some reason, the corridors had a bit of haze and smelt of cigarette smoke.

i really love this hotel.. especially with the staff's service ^ ^wish i can stay in this Hotel again in the future with all of JENESYS participants from Indonesia batch 2, 2010. please pray for me.. :))okay, once again.. I LOVE GRAND PRINCE SO MUCH !!you must stay in there if you go to Tokyo .

Rooms had been refurbished. Close to Shinkansen and Tokyo trains. Some restaurants nearby. English speaking staff. Bus transfers available to airport. This is the second time I've stayed here and will stay there again.

Modern,spacious hotel 5 minutes walk from Shinagawa Staion and close to subway. We stayed on the Club floor- spacious room, very comfortable bed, modern bathroom.Close to everything but not right in the middle of the noise and crowds. Great if you are using a JR pass because the station is so close by.

For business, the New Takanawa Prince (aka Shin-Takanawa Prince) is one of the best choices in Tokyo. Located conveniently close to both Shinagawa JR station (yes, it's a steep uphill to get to the hotel) and the Toei Asakusa Gotanda Hills station, the convenience is definitely there.The rooms are very good; I usually book a superior double, available for around JPY 12,000, which has modern decor and a decent amount of space for a Tokyo hotel. The view is either over the Japanese garden (and the Takanawa Prince), or toward the Shinagawa district. The beds are firm as can be expected in Japan but I find the comfortable. The flat-screen TVs have mostly Japanese channels but also some English-language ones.The high-speed Internet works well (though it's wired only), the bathrooms are clean albeit on the small side, and the hotel also offers JPY 1,000 coupons should you choose to skip room cleaning on alternate days.By far the best value of the four Prince hotels clustered near the Shinagawa station, and also the closest to the Toei Asakusa line.One downside is that the fitness centre requires an additional fee -- I normally run outside instead.

Very clean, well managed, and lovely gardens. However, we chose the hotel because of the pool, because Tokyo in August is so hot, and we were really annoyed to find that the pool access costs Y1,000 per person per swim, which for a family of four works out at almost $50 per swim - and that for what is really a very small pool. I complained and pointed out that although I have stayed in thouands of hotels I have never had to pay for use of the pool before, but there is no flexibility on this. If you want to use their pool, budget for this!

Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is part of complex of 5 hotels that prince hotel runs in Shinanagawa. The rooms are good deal for the price and have all of the expected features in four-star hotel. What makes this hotel special is the location. First there is peaceful japanese garden located next to the hotel. in just two minutes you can relax in such a serene setting. I absolutely love these japanese gardens. There is even a small shrine that was moved to this garden. Also the Epson Aquairum is located within a 5 minute walk from the hotel and you even get a discount when staying at two nearest prince hotels. The dolphin show was absolutely amazing. The hotel is located 5 minutes from the Shinagawa station. From here you can get to Narita or Haneda airport with a fast strain or use the shinkansen. Nowhere else are you so well connected. The only downside were the restaurants in the hotel complex. They were nice but abit overpriced. I would recommend eating at a restaurant near the station.

Great concierge service, swift handling from the receptionsts as well.The rooms are dated, but spacious. We chose this hotel mainly because of its central location (just 5-10 mins walk uphill from Shinagawa Station) and the reasonable room rates.We stayed here for 6 nights, and must say that we got fed up of the breakfast in the end. It was by no means bad, but the restaurant offered the same every day. Thumbs up for the chef who made us omelets every day.

I stayed in this hotel with my husband and in-laws for three nights in Tokyo.The location is superb - just 10-15 mins on foot from Shinagawa Station. It's a bit of an uphill from the sation, but you can easily manage. The hotel always looked really busy. I'm not a fussy travellor, and this was not a problem for me at all, but some people might find it a little bit frustrating. You'll have to wait in the queue no matter what time of the day it is. We chose newly refurbished rooms to stay - they were so nicely decorated that we all felt very spoiled ! They were very spacious with a decent-sized desk on which you can comfortably deal with your paper work . The decor was like that of designers' hotels. We were also lucky to have great view of Tokyo Tower from the balconies. As it's such a massive hotel, breakfast can be busy as well. I guess you can't really have a relaxing meal in a chain hotel in Tokyo. One more thing to add is this hidden gem. There's a beautiful Japanese garden next to the hotel. It's very nice to have a wee stroll there after a hectic day.

We absolutely loved this place. It is located in one of the busiest areas of Tokyo without being in the city centre. The hotel is only 5 minutes gentle walk from Shinagawa station which is one of the main stations in Tokyo and where there are plenty of good, cheap eateries.The club lounge is definitely worth the extra money as it provides you with a reasonable breakfast as well as all day refreshments and alcohol in the evening. Because we paid for the club facilities our check-in and check-out were efficient and professional.Our room was roomy, the bed extremely comfortable and the high-speed free internet was a bonus. Like other reviewers, our room had a little balcony which overlooked the beautiful gardens that separate the three main hotels in the area. A morning stroll in the garden was a must.We would definitely go back.

Location is ok. If you either don't mind walking uphill with the luggage or know Tokyo well enough to use Toei Asakusa line which is very close by. Club floor room is ok. Small compared to nicer non-Japanese brand hotels. Bathroom is really small, only bath-shower combination. The air con seems not to be able to control from the room despite the presence of the control panel on the wall. The most ridiculous thing is the club lounge. No wonder there's no one there. It consistes of 6 tables each with 2 chairs set up as close as possible to each other, so that it's impossible to walk without touching them For the advertised evening drinks and snacks there's canned beer and a miserable bottle of whiskey. The selection of snacks includes packaged salty nuts and bananas. What a nice combination - beer and banana. Worse booking a club floor room.

If you are on a moderate budget travelling to Tokyo, then this is a reasonable hotel for US$180 a night. Most of the rooms have balconies, a great Plus for those who hate heaters in winter. Most hotels in Tokyo at this price range, like Keio Plaza, Century Hyatt and Shinjuku Prince, do not have proper climate control. They only have central heating and can become unbearably hot at night. With a balcony, you have more options, you can turn on the heater whilst you can keep the room termperature under control by opening the balcony door.The rooms are reasonably comfortable and given its location, the size of the room is larger than those in Keio Plaza and Century Hyatt. The hotel and the rooms are a bit old, though they were renovating back in December 2008 and hopefully that has imrpoved. I did not use the facilities here because there are not that many, and there is little night life around the area. Transportation wise, it is far from Shinjuku and if you miss the last train, then it will be a very expensive cab ride. It is a bit closer to Ebisu, Ropponggi Hill and Ginza and also to Haneda Airport (10 minutes) so it is a nice hotel for a 1-2 nights stay before travelling domestically to other cities in Japan via Haneda airport.

This is a very large hotel in a complex of other hotels around an exhibition centre. In the centre of the complex is a very pleasant Japanese garden - a rare feature in a concrete city like Tokyo. Hotel rooms were a good size, and include many features (eg light sticks by the bedside to use at night). There are some restaurants in the hotel, including a breakfast bar with some strange but tasty Japanese bread. The hotel is up a hill from the huge Shinagawa railway station, which has a direct link to Narita airport. Staff in the hotel are extremely polite and helpful, even to the extent of driving my wife to another hotel to pick up a jacket my some had left on the airport bus when we arrived.

We stayed three nights in this hotel for a sightseeing trip to Tokyo. The hotel room is clean, spacey (considering this is Tokyo). The decor, and the carpet are dated, and really need renovation. The room does not have an iron, and iron board. The Japanese garden is beautiful. The staff are helpful, and most of them can hardly speak English. The location of the hotel is about two blocks from the JR and bullet train Shinagawa station. While it is o.k. to walk from the train station, the steep incline sidewalk makes it impossible to drag a luggage larger than a 20 inches carryon suitcase. The Japanese garden is beautiful. The staff are helpful, but most of them can hardly speak English. This is at best a three star hotel.

We arrived at the hotel about 9.30am in the morning, and our flight out of Narita was only at 7pm.Plus:The room was a great size considering its in Japan - It fit two huge luggages open (of course we had to move a little furniture around)The bed was huge, and comfortable.The bathroom was small but had every essential you would need. Great shishedo products in the bathroomLove the bidet and heated toilet seat (especially when i was there in January and it being cold)Minus:Most hotels (in other parts of the world) would give you a room if it was available before the check-in time, and extension to check out time is usually optional, decided by the hotel. In this case, they wanted to charge us 1000yen for every hour extra that we would like to have the room for (for early check in and late check out)The distance to the train station may only be under 10mins, but on returning (after a full day of walking, and yes... you will be walking alot in Tokyo), its a slight uphill slope and you won't be happy about it, especially if you've been walking in heels for the whole dayWifi, which is usually free in hotel rooms, has to be paid in this hotel. Not expensive, but the point being you HAD to pay for it.

We went to Tokyo for a friend's wedding. Our first time in Japan. We brought our 6, 3 and 18 month old. Chose this hotel because it was close to my friend's house and all the reviews were great. Good stuff - hotel beautiful; rooms nice and clean; service polite and generally helpful; convenient store useful; close to train station; guest service helpful; shuttle to Disney Land nice;Bad stuff - small room with tiny beds (but this was the first time I've been to Japan so I'm probably not appreciating the size; service polite but not that friendly (I am Chinese American and everyone in Japan expected me to speak Japanese and appeared bewildered when I spoke English); souvenir store was closed on Sunday when we were leaving and were trying to pick up last minute gifts; We have a 3 year old with type 1 diabetes and need to eat at specific times. At the end of an exhausting day, we found out they didn't have room service at night. When we tried to get delivery, we were told it's not allowed and to desist from our efforts. Tried to get a crib for the 18 month old and was told that their cribs were for up to 9 month olds. Saw one of the cribs at the hotel and it was normal crib size. We didn't have to lug a portable crib all that way.

Stayed in Room 3266, 12th floor,double room. Book online through their internet site for best rate. Very nice size rooms,efficiently appointed, clean and spacious. Definitely western style everything. Decor is akin to what you would find at a Hard Rock Hotel in the US. Loved the Shiseido bath products and panasonic hair dryer.Location is up the hill from Shinagawa station. Slight uphill, but grade of hill was not horrible. Front desk personnel were kind, polite and helpful with our basic questions.Business center had internet, 100JPY for 5 min. There is a gift shop and tiny convenience store in the hotel. We used our free 1000 JPY there (was part of the Hotel's eco program)

This is my second visit to this hotel. I really liked it the first time and loved it the second time. We were upgraded to the executive rooms or maybe the club rooms. The rooms on the 16th floor. This was the top level of the hotel. This room was awesome. It had a separate lounge area. Two double beds. Two sinks in the bathroom with two showers and a makeup counter inbetween the two sinks. It was fantastic. Plus we had a great view of Tokyo tower. We originally booked for the superior rooms, but I had no idea why there was a upgrade. Nevertheless, this hotel is the place to stay. It may not be in the center of all the action like shinjuku. But it has free bus transfer to disneyland and shingawa is still part of the jr yamonte line.

My husband and I stayed at the Grand Price Hotel New Takanawa for 5 nights at the end of October. We found an excellent deal for a Club room for only a little more than the price of a regular room, so jumped at the chance. The club rooms include use of the club lounge, continental breakfast, drinks all day (till 9pm, which is when the club lounge closed), and free high speed internet in the bedroom. For us, the free internet and drinks were what made these rooms worthwhile (there is internet in the regular rooms, but it is not free). However, without the deal price, I do not believe that the club room prices are worth their normally high price.Our room (and all those on the side of the hotel looking out over the garden) had a nice little balcony, and the room facilities were excellent. Staff were very fast and helpful with anything we needed. We had a large twin room, with 2 huge beds - both at least Queen size. Fabulously comfortable, and very conducive to jet-lagged over-sleeping on our 2nd and 3rd days, when it finally hit :-)The proximity to Shinagawa railway station and to the Takanawa metro station are very useful. When arriving at Shinagawa, try to take the hotel shuttle back to the hotel, as the walk uphill to the hotel can be quite rough, especially if you have luggage, shopping, or are at the end of a long day of sightseeing. The last shuttle (at least when we were there) leaves the station at 9pm. The walk to Shinagawa is all downhill, and since we did it only in the mornings when we were fresh, it is quite ok. If you want to take the shuttle from the hotel, you need to book it in advance - for the morning trips, do so the day before.The hotel does not have a spa, but you can use the spa at their sister hotel across the garden (the Grand Prince Sakura, I think it's called). You have to check in there at least 1 hour before they close, and we never got back in time to do that (plus we didn't have the strength to walk over, after a long day out in the city).There is an outdoor swimming pool, but it was closed while we were there - low season. From our room it didn't look terribly clean, so I hope they clean it out before opening it up to guests. We didn't use any of the other facilities of the hotel, as we were out all day, every day.All in all, we had a very good stay, and good value for money.

Whilst not located in a real hotspot like Shibuya or dirty old Ropongi, the location is central, convenient to Shinagawa station (and all the restaurants, shops and supermarket adjacent to it), and is a quiet oasis in the city.The rooms are huge for Japan, the king beds soft and cosy (lovers of really firm mattresses beware), the bathrooms, water pressure, lighting, work desk, everything is easily four star. Cable broadband costs a few bucks and is very fast.This is a very big hotel, with several towers spread around a beautiful garden. Because of the size, it requires a bit of orienteering skills to navigate, and queues can form for check-in and check-out at certain times. Facilities:The two swimming pools are open to the elements and therefore only open in summer. The one gymnasium is located in the basement of the northernmost Prince Sakura tower and costs ¥2100 to use. Once you have paid that, there is another fee to use the gym's sauna. Extortionate! Plus, they do not allow people with tattoos to use the gym or spa. No yakuza allowed.There are so many restaurants in the complex it would take a week to review them all. There is a good choice of eateries just down the hill near the station, within two blocks. The supermarket sells very good take away sushi! I had breakfast in the hotel's Marmolada buffet which was fine without being great, serving omelettes, many fruits and juices, miso soup, salads, English breakfast items, cereals and a range of pastries. The salads and soups were very Japanese in construction and there was thankfully no attempt to create a more bland choice for foreign guests.The main bar, Asami, is intimately lit, wood-panelled, leather-upholstered, and quite 1980's "European businessman" in decor. The satisfyingly expensive cocktails and whiskies go down easier accompanied by the soothing sounds of the in-house pianist and jazz singer, leaving one with a sense of deja-vu, until you recall that your memory of the scene came from watching Lost In Translation.

We really enjoyed our stay at this hotel. We had a room with twin beds and it was quite large, especially compared to other hotels in Japan. It was extremely quiet and very comfortable. Each room has a very tiny balcony (not large enough to sit outside, but you can get some fresh air if you wish. The hotel staff was extremely courteous and competent and the lobby is huge. The hotel is a short walk (uphill) from the Shinagawa train station and across the street from a building with a number of shops and restaurants, including a great sushi restaurant on the lower level. We hope to stay at the Grand Prince New Takanawa again.

I had the best time. This place is so close to the train station and a 7/11 right down the street. I don't know what the other person wrote about no outside food is allowed to be brought in the rooms, I did every day. No one said anything about it, they even offered to help. I may have had a better time than most, you see my girlfriend is Japanese . The Japanese garden the have there is so beautiful and very big. There is no ice machine! No problem, call down to the lobby and they bring it up to your room within 3 minutes. All the staff was great and so very nice.

The moment we were greeted, they explained that we had been upgraded to a better room. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The room service was outstanding. Had a gorgeous garden attached which allowed my husband several nights of quiet moonlit walks. The room was extremely comfortable. The bathroom more than meets my requirements for clean - plus it is modern and has fancy Japanese gadgets that were adorable. Truly, truly wonderful stay. Very, very grateful.

This hotel is charming, fantastic, beautiful. Close to Shinagawa station so very easy to get everywhere in Tokyo. The staff are superb. The lobby and bar are beautiful. The swimming pool only open during summer months though (not in June when we were there). Overall fantastic and very pleasant experience. Strongly recommend it.

It was my first time to travel to Japan. I would say that this is one of my most memorable trips I ever had, and the success of this trip is largely contributed by the excellent service of this hotel. Since we don't know how to speak Japanese and we don't know how to travel around, the guest officers were very helpful. They were so patient and they really tried their best to make us understand. They provide step by step instruction on how to go to one place to another. I also appreciate the free shuttle going to Disneyland and DisneySea. Since going to such parks requires a lot of walking, I can't imagine taking the train after a long day at the park.My only complaint with this hotel is during our first 2 days, the towels smelled bad like they weren't cleaned. However, apart from that, I have nothing to complain.

I want to write this review since I did benefit from reading the reviews made by others as well. So in appreciation of others that took the time and effort plus I would like to give my due praise to this hotel for their outstanding service and help. We stayed at this hotel for a week during our Tokyo trip due mainly to its good neighborhood accreditation which means it has a free shuttle to Disneyland/Disneysea theme park. We went to Disneyland/DisneySea for 3 days of our 6 days trip. I book the hotel via Expdia and we got a decent price of $134/night. We had a king size bed which we requested and the room has a good size for a Tokyo hotel. All rooms have a balcony I think. We were staying at the 12th floor. I do believe that the rooms below the 8th or 7th floors were older and not fully renovated yet. Our room were modern with flat screen TV, complete ammenities such as slippers, towels, shampoo conditioner, liquid bath soap, razor, comb, cotton buds etc. The toilet is heated with bidets. There were 3 of us with a 3 year old child and we felt that the room has ample space for our kid to play as well. The best thing I would say with this hotel is that the service given by the Guest officer is very good. Everyday we will ask them where they would recommend for us to visit, and they will give us every detail including which trains to take, which platform and even the prices were accurate. There is no free wifi in the rooms and the wifi in the lobby has a fee so we use the free internet at their business center. This is a bit of a down side to this hotel. But it is still free so that's ok I guess. The major inconvenience for this hotel is that it is about 5-7 mins of an uphill walk coming back from the shinagawa station. Most of the restaurants, and groceries, newsday stores are in the shinagawa station and it is a hassle to walk there and carry some heavy water and snacks going uphill back to the hotel. Plus having a 3 year old is a bit of a hassle after coming from a busy day of touring around then having to walk uphill back to the hotel. They do have a free shuttle that goes to the hotel but on a certain time period only so we never really timed the free ride. Anyway, the major reason why we book this hotel was because for the price and the location (a minor sacrifice) we have a free shuttle to disneyland we decided to go with this hotel. If we will be touring disneyland for more than 3 days we would have opted to stay in any of the nearby Disney Resort hotel however, we also want to visit some other nearby cities in Tokyo so we decided to stay in this area. We also spend half a day at an Aquarium nearby the hotel and this was really appreciated by my kid. Although they spoke mainly Japanese but seeing lots of fish and stingrays, sharks and dolphin show it was enough for my kid to enjoy the day. Also, I would like to add that they have an incentive for a non-cleaning day they offer to give you Y1000 rebate which we used in their bakery for breakfast. The breads there are great and priced at around Y200 per piece. However they don't allow you to have a successive days of non-cleaning. Only alternate days are allowed. I would rate this hotel as a 3.5 * to borderline 4* hotel. The lobby and coffee shop is quite large but it feels very lonely. They have a nice garden as well...

I had read other reviews and was not sure what to expect. Since we stayed 4 nights, I got a special rate at Expedia and so was unsure of the room we would get. When we got there, the staff was very helpful and friendly and told us our room had been upgraded. Which I believe it meant that instead of getting the old rooms, we got a newly renovated one. It had two queen beds and ample bathroom, a desk/sitting area and a small balcony. The hotel has a several restaurants; we tried only the cafe which had a reasonably priced breakfast (around US$8) and the Japanese restaurant which was good and as any hotel restaurant, over priced. The hotel gives you the choice to opt-out of having your linens changed and gives you a voucher for the restaurants (around US$10). You can only do this every other day. They give you the daily newspaper in English or Japanese, and the toilettries include evrything form hair brush to shaving cream. Since the hotel is part of a complex of Grand prince hotels, guests have access to all of the hotels and internet facilities. The one at New Takanawa has staff on hand to help you with your needs but closes at 10PM. The other ones are 24 hours but there's no one to assist you. Internet, printing, and fax services are provided free of charge. The central garden surrounded by the hotels is really beautiful, so much that my Japanese friends tell me they come to visit it when seasons change. We were in full cherry blossom season and it was amazing.Location wise- I would say it is not right next to transportation but I believe other reviewers exaggerate the distance. It is only a 5 min walk to Shinagawa train station, perfect if you're traveling to Kyoto and surroundings. If you're healthy and young the walk is really nothing, there is a bit of a slope but nothing major. There is also a shuttle bus to the train station and you have to reserve it. We took it only on the day we checked out and had our luggage with us. It is also a 5-minute walk to the Takanawadai subway station. We used this option frequently because we had a two day metro pass and there are no slopes here.Regarding the renovations, we noticed that the lower floors up to the 7th floor have not been renovate since the 80's (judging by the Miami Vice colors) so your experience may be quite different if you're assigned to one of these rooms.

My wife and I stayed at the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa in March 2009 and we were very pleased with our experience. A wonderful place to stay and one I would readily recommend to other travelers (with 1 minor exception). I will review by section:-- Staff: The staff at the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa (henceforth referred to as 'New Takanawa') are top notch! Professional, courteous, friendly, knowledgeable and very eager to assist. From bell service to room service, I was absolutely pleased with the staff. Even though my wife and I did not speak Japanese (outside of a few common phrases), the language barrier wasn't a significant issue and there was always someone who had enough of a command of the English language to take care of our needs. Special mention goes to the concierge staff that went out of their way to assist us in getting around Tokyo.-- Room Quality: Very good room quality with standard features I expect from a nice hotel: Flat screen TV, large bed, room safe, desk, etc... The rooms are smaller than Western hotel rooms (and this was to be expected), but this does not diminish the comfort or quality I expected or experienced. I found the carpeting, drapes/curtains and walls to be new and recently renovated. There was nothing that was gaudy, run down or cheap in appearance (to the contrary, the rooms looked quite modern, even elegant). There were also a lot of little "nice touches": Although there was a mini-bar (avoid!), they provided 4 bottled waters every day - Free! A free English newspaper was provided every day. The rooms have doorbells. The balconies are very nice and afford good views of the city. -- Bathrooms: Although small, the bathrooms were fantastic! Hot/Cold running water, shower and sink. Every day, toiletries exceeded hotel standards (including daily toothbrush/toothpaste, travel kit and travel hairbrush). The toilets are amazing - best ever experienced in a hotel - Eastern or Western: Warmed seats, scented and came with a variety of added functions (bidet, mist, etc...). If you use the toilets in the club level, the lid will automatically open for you. Nifty!-- Club Level: I would recommend paying a little extra to have access to the club level. The club level gives one access to reserved check-in/check-out and hotel services. There was an excellent continental breakfast in the mornings and in the afternoon/evening, free snacks and drinks (including alcohol). A very good place to warm-up before, and unwind after, a long day of exploring.-- Location: The location is a double-edged sword and requires more detailed information. The Pros and Cons:Location Pros: The area of Shinagawa is a good general "launching point" for travelers as it is near the Shinagawa Station (a major hub with access to the JR Yamanote Line: A line that takes you to most of the major areas of the city). If you are looking to explore the city or need to be located near a major transportation hub, then Shinagawa is a very good area to stay.Location Cons: While the New Takanawa is within walking distance of Shinagawa Station (about 5-10 minutes), from the station to the hotel, it is uphill (a minor incline). For me, this wasn't a problem. For my pregnant wife who was tired after a long day of exploring, it was a problem. Elderly or people who have trouble with mobility may find this to be an issue. -- Business Center: The hotel has a business center with high-speed internet access. There was no additional charge for this service (always a plus). It was in a small, open area that afforded no privacy. There was a limited number of computers, so you may have to wait. But this is more than adequate if all you want to do is print airline boarding passes, online RSVPs, online maps and directions, etc... It served my modest needs.-- Restaurants and Room Service: There are several restaurants at the New Takanawa, but to be honest, for the price and quality, they really aren't all that special. Don't get me wrong: The food and quality are good (not great), but one would really be better off dining in the city for the price, quality and experience. I found room service to be speedy, but once again, average - not exceptional. My advice: Leave the hotel. Explore Tokyo. Enjoy the local cuisine.Before closing, I would like to dispel a big rumor I've read about concerning this hotel: Renovation. Prior to my visit, there were a lot of rumors/reports is that there was a lot of renovation going on and there are many areas that were not yet renovated. Fact: The reality is that all hotels undergo renovation from time to time. However, during the time my wife and I were there, we did not see any active renovation occurring. The hallways, elevators, public areas, shops and restaurants all looked modern and clean. Our room looked also looked clean, elegant and new.Conclusion: The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is a wonderful place to stay while in Tokyo with exceptional staff, fantastic rooms, wonderful service and good location. For a seasoned or savvy traveler, this is an excellent place to stay and I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Sakura 2009 was the best sakura season in years and the Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is perfect for travelers seeking quality & location. All of the staff were very friendly and spoke english well. I had a medical emergency early in my stay and the hotel's Guest Relations Staff made me comfortable as they set up an appointment with a doctor. I was seen by an english speaking doctor, treated & released in a half hour. Good luck finding that in the States. The rooms were large & clean. The Sakura Garden was superb. The Business Center was on top of their game. All of the restaurants in the hotel served auethentic japanese cuisine. Security was tight. Bell Service was very efficient & polite. The Grand Prince Hotel New Takanawa is where you should stay in Shinagawa ! Duomo Arigatou, Duomo Arigatou !!!

A large hotel situated within walking distance of the Shinagawa JR Yamanote line station. This made traveling around the city very easy. The facilities are well maintained, the rooms look recently remodeled. Our rooms were actually reasonably sized and clean and comfortable. The staff, from the front desk, to the wait staff and housekeeping are absolutely wonderful. We had the daily breakfast and it was varied and satisfying. While there are a number of onsite restaurants we only tried one and it was good but not spectacular. Not many other restaurants nearby for dinner would be my only slightly negative comment. We would be happy to stay here again.

We stayed at the Grand Prince New Takanawa Hotel for 5 nights in mid-March 2009. For the price that we paid which was approx AUD$160 per night, we were pleasantly surprised by the room and the hotel's facilities. We had a room on the 12th floor with a balcony overlooking the garden. The staff were polite and helpful at all the times and the rooms were always immaculately serviced. After a long day spent walking around taking in Tokyo's sights, it was good to know that we had a nice, comfortable room to come back to. The hotel is about a 5-10min walk to Shinagawa JR station, which is about 4 or 5 stops from Tokyo station and Shinjuku.

Like my last stay at Hakone, at Tokyo, our group was given the 4th floor, with other foreigners, so we would disturb their locals.First thing when we get our room key card, they mistake many of us as Mr. printed on the envelopes.I was suprise by the little gate we all have in front of our door, very cute, and a little gate that can be opend or closed for our next room.Pretty roomy in the room and at the bathroom, but we had to get a guy to come up and switch a lightbulb because it went out before we went in.It's about a 5 minutes walk to the Shinagawa station, there's convenience store in the hotel at the lobby floor. A bakery at the hill-side.My friend had a room with a malfuntion toilet that won't stop flushing in the middle of the night.Provide umbrella at the front deskIt's a big hotel, so there were many people staying and it took a bit to check out.

After spending many many hours on the internet looking for our accomodation , we finally deceided on this hotel , mainly due to price. Not sure what we would be getting for our money . it was a wonderful surprise to be staying at such a lovely hotel. We being my friend and her 7 and 9 year olds and myself and my 10 and 13 year old. we had next door rooms on the 12th floor with views out to the tokyo tower. each room was spacious, extremely clean and had a very very comfy king size bed, plenty room for each family to sleep. the bathroom was also spacious with plenty of supplies, don't worry about taking shampoo, conditioner or shower gel, as all these are refilled when ever the room is serviced. the hotel do a wonderful thing, they have a green scheme where by you nominate to not have your room serviced or towels/bedding changed and they give you a voucher for 1000yen to spend at the hotel. you can only do this every other day and they still come in and empty your bins for you. we did this evey other day, the 1000 yen allowed us to purchase breaky from the bread shop below the lobby , with the best pizza bread i have ever eaten and the best chocolate croissants according to my daughter. most of the items in this little shop are around 180-200 yen each. thats the only place we purchased food from in the hotel, every day for breaky and to buy extras for our morning tea on day trips. there is a little convienince store in the hotel , its open late so purchase you drinks from there and your juice for in a morning , it dosnt open until 8am , that was too late as most days we were out by then. on that note , most of tokyo does not open until 10 or 11 am as the shops don't close until 9 or 10pm. we caught the limosine bus from narita direct to the hotel and had it pick us up for our return transfere, a much easier option than the train , especially with kids.this hotel also has the free disney bus , which needs to be booked in advance, we booked the first one in the morning and was to return the last one at night , but it was freezing, snowing actually , so we got back to the bus stop early and the earlier bus had room to fit us on.most of the tokyo tours also do a hotel pick up from here. very handy for those early starts.the hotel is about 5 min walk from shinagawa station , the hotel also has a free shuttle down to the station if you pre book. we used the jr train line one day and found it very easy, we purchased a daily discount ticket to hop on and off when ever. the train people are also very very helpful and will do there best to get you to where you want to get too. that day we visitied the pokemon centre( huge shop selling everything pokemon) imperial gardens, ginza and harajuku ( a heaven for any girls aged 8 to ?). the following day we had a day on the subway , a 5 minute wlak in the opposite direction from the hotel. equally as easy to use, that day we visited tsjinku fish market ( a brilliant experince for all ages) and ate the freshest sashimi i have ever had, senso ji tempel and akasuka where we spent many hours looking around the stalls and little shops.more onto the hotel , the staff were very accomodating and helpful, they made you feel very important. this hotel is not in a nightlife district , but after a very full day sightseeing thats not what we wanted. it ticked all the boxes for a family stay, we felt very safe here. on a last note, therres this little japanese restaurant right out the front of the shinagawa station that sells reasonably priced food not too dear, but also sells pancakes , great fort he kids and theres a macdonalds accross the road from the station too along with a great 7eleven store for snacks and drinks.

This is a great place to stay. The rooms have a lot of space, the king beds are very comfortable and the staff incredibly friendly. It is a little walk from Shinagawa JR station (about 5 minutes), but this isn't bad.One word of advice about the lower-level rooms with a queen bed. Those are older, not renovated rooms and they show their age: the carpeting is badly in need of freshening and the furniture is worned out. The prices can be a good deal though (specials run at ~$100) if you don't mind giving up a bit of comfort..

We stayed in this hotel for Christmas 2008. The room was so nice and cosy and after a long tiring day in Tokyo it didn't feel like the standard hotel room. We stayed on the 12th floor and the view was just FANTASTIC. The bed was big and the bathroom was a good size. The restaurants within the hotel are nothing special but there are many restaurants and coffee shops around that area. The location of the hotel is just perfect. It is next to Shinagawa station - 5 min walk - which is one of the main stations in Tokyo. Also it is very convinient for excursions outside Tokyo. I highly reccomend this hotel.
A great hotel. Nice clean rooms. Nice size rooms for tokyo. Close to the sinagawa train station. Friendly staff.

We were worried about staying here after reading some of the reviews but we LOVED it! We must have gotten one of the brand new remodeled rooms because it was beautiful, had a nice little balcony overlooking the garden, gorgeous big bathroom and our room was very large by Japan standards with a desk, big flat screen tv, frig, comfortable and immaculate. The beds and bedding were spotless and sooo comfortable. (our stay at a hotel in Kyoto paled by comparison and was a big disappointment for the same price.) The bus from the airport dropped us off at the lobby almost first . The lobby is very large and grand!! Beautiful. We were greeted warmly and the people were so helpful and kind. I cannot say enough good about our stay. The location is wonderful for getting around with restaurants and shops all very close-by and in the hotel itself. Our room was quiet and they brought us in a DVD player at no charge. We didn't eat at the hotel so I can't comment on their dining. But the hotel was wonderful and our room was a definate value at a bit less than $200 for a superior twin. Could not have asked for more.

we arrived in Japan just a week before the sakura festival. The hotel was spruced up with anything and everything about cherryblossoms. The Prince chain of hotels pride itself of its gardens, which is so huge, it would be a shame to not explore. It would already provide you a glimpse of Japan. Since its has a small temple, a japanese bridge, a pond with tons of huge koi fishes, and ofcourse cherryblossom trees.The staff of the hotel were friendly, but some do not really speak good english. The hotel lobby is by far one of the biggest i've seen. Good sitting area, especially if you're waiting for your tour group or friends. Breakfast is included w/ the package, and you have 3 restaurants to choose from (western, asian and japanese). We didnt try the japanese breakfast though, but we have a feeling that they would server a similar fare.The room is quite small, the bed is very low, i've heard a couple of guests complaining about the pillow. The bathroom is also small, sink is also low. But it comes with complimentary toiletries and towels. Interesting to note that the toilet bowl is very high tech. The room is quite shabby and outdated. Each rooms on our floor has a fence before the door. I suggest you get a room on the club or upper floors to provide a better view of the city. But you cant complain about the staff, they were all very friendly even if you have to do hand signals to communicate.The hotel is located near the Shinagawa station, which has an isetan dept store and other stores inside. There are a couple of nearby restaurants and convenient stores as well. The hotel is also part of the friendly neighborhood disney hotel, so there are free trips to and from Tokyo Disneyland.Overall I would recommend this hotel to anyone who's not fussy with their rooms but puts convenience and a good location as priority. Good for first timers.

As part of our tour, the agent suggested the New Takanawa for its close position to Shinagawa train (good for subways, local trains and Shinkansen - not to mention convenience stores, coffee shops and multiple food outlets and delis). Reading the reviews here, I got concerned and requested they re-book a renovated room at a slightly higher tariff.As a result, our room was well appointed and average in size by international standards but large as Tokyo rooms go. They provided us with harder pillows as requested and had a convenient ice machine. On the scale of things, a clean and well re-decorated room within a tired shell of the main hotel; it was apparent from other floors that old wallpaper and tired carpets were still evident.One of four big hotels in the block, it is an uphill walk from Shinagawa station and dragging wheelie bags is less than pleasurable, but I guess catching a taxi for 600 metres is a luxury for some.The rest of the area had little to recommend to tourists, but the trains make it extremely easy to travel around.

Overall the hotel is able to meet our needs and expectations, with some rooms for improvements. We had a pleasant stay.Pros(1) Free bus to/from disneyland & disneysea.(2) Easy to arrange for the Airport Limousine to/from airport to hotel.(3) Near Shinagawa Train Station.(4) Nearby restuarants, food outlets and convenience shops. Also has a convenience shops and some gift shops within the hotel.(5) Staffs are friendly and helpful.(6) Clean room.(7) Big lobby. With plenty of sittings. Gd while waiting for transport.(8) Has an money exchange counter (we didn't use it but would be convenient if there is a need).(9) Enjoyed the hotel's toiletries (the aromatic bubble bath gel and shampoo).Cons(1) Requested for late check-out but was asked to pay instead.(2) Mini fridge didn't seem to be working (not cold).(3) No spare pillows. Mattresses were quite hard and pillows were 'flat'.(5) 'Old' looks (in need for a renovation).

I would recommend this hotel to anyone, it was clean, the room that we had (which was an upgrade when we got there to the club floor) was excellent. The staff were all very accommodating and polite. There is free internet use in their business suite. There is also a convenience shop and small gift shop. The only downside was that you had to pay 1,000 yen to use the swimming pools, plus unfortunately, they close pools early in Japan (September). Tokyo itself is very clean, people are friendly and trains run on time!!

Stayed at this hotel as it was part of an "All inclusive" tour of Tokyo. The hotel is part of the "Prince" hotel chain in Tokyo.Check In was quick and very efficient. Rooms are in need of major renovations/makeovers. Carpets in hallways need to be replaced as they are worn, stained and musty smelly. Rooms are no better. 1970's decor. The carpets need to be replaced as they are worn, stained and in need of TLC. The beds are no better. The bed is very low to the ground and the matresses are paper thin. I woke up every morning with back pain :(It appears the bathrooms have been recently upgraded. As per the last review, the only rooms that have been revamped are the "Club floor" rooms located on the 15th and 16th floor only.This hotel offers a snack shop and botique shopping. Plenty of restaraunts to choose from, however they are very pricey. Take advantage of the shopping mall and restaraunts near by the hotel..a half block down the street. (Outback Steak House, TGIF, McDonald's and restaraunts in the shopping mall."Shingway" Subway station (major connection hub) is a 3 minute walk from the hotel. Hotel also participates in the "Good Neighbour" Disney shuttle service to Tokyo Disneyland, the bus shuttle is free :)I would only consider staying at this hotel again if the rooms have been gutted and remodeled.
The rooms in this hotel were remodeled in April 2007. So rooms are quite new. If you sleep late and missed your breakfast, you can use your breakfast boucher for lunch of 2500 yen.

The hotel is situated on a hill so you have to climb up for about a city block to reach it from Shinagawa station. There is a shuttle bus between the hotel and the station and Shinagawa Prince if you time your arrival well. The front desk staff were very friendly and helpful and took our luggage and escorted us to our room. The corridor is quite unique with metal french style gates infront of each room.The room was massive by japanese standards - even for 3 people - with a small balcony. The buffet breakfast was simple with a standard mix of japanese and western - nothing special. The bell desk was very helpful in booking our airport shuttle bus to Narita and handled everything for us.

My husband and I just got back from a weeks stay in Tokyo and the New Takanawa Prince Hotel. We were in Tokyo namely to visit Tokyo Disneyland and Tokyo Disney Sea. We found this location to be perfect for getting to the Disney parks AND expirence the rest of Tokyo. There is great shopping in and around this hotel and the train station is just a little bit of a walk, about 1/4-1/2 mile down a slight hill. It is close to Tokyo Station (the major hub to other districts in Tokyo and not too far from the Imperial Palace), Shibuya (a wonderful shopping district), Harajuku (another WONDERFUL shopping district), Ginza (more shopping). These are the districts outside of Disney that we visited. The train system was very very easy to navigate from the Shinagawa train station.The hotel's staff were wonderful and we did not find it hard to communicate with anyone there. The room was very nice, clean, the shower and bathtub were fantastic! We received an Japanese newspaper written in english every morning. There were a couple of television stations on the t.v. that had english speaking news programs and we loved watching the Japanese t.v. programs. There also were several American baseball games on Japanese stations that we were able to follow along with!We will definately stay at the New Takanawa Prince Hotel when we return to Tokyo!!!

This hotel is located conveniently literally 5 minutes away from Shinagawa station. It's a slight slope uphill - annoying while lugging baggage but not difficult. Pretty comfortable stay.HOTEL LOCATION:- Close to Shinagawa Station for easy travels- Close to many American (Outback Steakhouse & TGIF) and Japanese restaurants as well as shopping centers (at the Wing Takanawa located across & in Shinagawa Station)SERVICE/STAFF:- Fluent in English (for the most part)- Great guest services who are fluent in English and provided information, maps, and directions to wherever you would like to go. Even helped to make bus reservations to Lake Kawaguchi, a great place to view Mt. FujiROOM:- Standard twin rooms were spacious with 2 beds bigger than twin but which are rather low to the ground- Has a sitting area fit for anyone wishing to eat in the room- Each room has a balcony that you can open the window and walk out to- Bathrooms were spacious & clean- You have your own doorbell & gate outside your door!- Air conditioning doesn't work and the room can get stuffy- Decor is a bit too floral and looks dated but it's not as retro as it seems- Some furniture does show some wearADDITIONAL GOODIES:- If your stay is longer than 2 days and you don't mind your room being cleaned every other day, you can apply for a 1000 yen voucher that you can use on any of the shops or restaurants in the hotel. Best bet is the bakery downstairs where you can get a lot of good pastries/cakes/bread for 1000 yen. A form is in the room.- Free shuttle to and from Disneyland and Disney Sea- Free English newspaper
Old, outdated, not much english spoken, beds are awful, carpets were dirty, coffee shop is a rip-off. Only thing going for it is the location, near Shinagawa station and a few restaurants.

Walkable uphill from Shinagawa Station where the bullet train arrives/departs. Aiport bus stops outside which must be booked in advance for departure. Rooms are fine all have small balcony and small seating area. There is a no smoking floor. Each room has a small cool box which can be stocked (beer/wine/soft drinks/food etc)from hotel shop (not too expensive)or from outside (frowned upon). This was very useful during our stay. Although only a short walk from restuarnts/cafes and bars breakfast is either do it yourself in room or taken within the hotel which was quite expensive.Good 'guest relations team' who provided local and not so local photcopies of maps to aid our travels. With the JR line on the doorstep travel around the City was easy.Although the hotel is not in the centre of the action it provided a good base for 4 days in the city.

We stayed in this hotel primarily because we got a good deal on the price--13000 yen per day (plus 15% service) for what Orbitz claimed was a five-star hotel (it wasn't). This is primarily a business hotel and is not located in a part of Tokyo that sees a lot of tourists. The clientele appeared to be mainly Japanese businessmen, although there was a German tour group there as well. I don't think the hotel is used to Western tourists. English was barely serviceable. Our room looked like it had been decorated around 1970 and not touched after that. The bathroom did have one of those smart toilets, which was the most modern thing about the room. The air conditioner didn't work--it apparently does not turn on unless the room temperature is 73 degrees or higher. Since it was very humid for several days, it resulted in fairly uncomfortable evenings. The hotel is a couple of blocks from the Shinagawa station, which is handy for catching the Shinkansen or the subway. The airport bus also stops here, which is handy for arriving from or going to Narita. I give this hotel an "above average" rating because of a combination of price and amenities; if this hotel were in the US or elsewhere, I would give it a "neutral".

A good choice for a stay in Tokyo--not a top luxury hotel, but very good The rooms are clean and each comes with the standard tea set and "smart" toilet as well as a tiny refrigerator. Every room has a small balcony--a plus when traveling with a smoker. The hotel is set in a small parklike area along with other "Prince" hotels--nice as a small refuge from the city. The hotel is only a couple of blocks from the Shinagawa station--handy, but, unfortunately, somewhat uphill on the way back from the station at the end of a long day. I never tried the hotel restaurants because there were so many interesting nearby neighborhood restaurants so can't render an opinion on the food quality. Most of the staff speak English and are very helpful. I would definitely stay here again.
